reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints.  

Tasks in order:  
1. Framing (F)  
2. Wallboarding (W)  
3. Taping (T)  
4. Sanding (S)  
5. Priming (P)  

Constraints:  
• T and P on different days.  

• Sanding on day 3 (given).  

• Each task by exactly one worker, one task per day per worker.  

• Each worker does at least one task overall.  

• At least one task per day.  

• Installation takes 3 days.  

Step 1 – Place Sanding on Day 3  
Sanding is task 4 in sequence.  
So tasks before S: F, W, T must be on days 1 or 2.  
Tasks after S: only P (task 5) must be after S, so P is on day 3 or later, but only 3 days total → P must be on day 3 as well? Wait: S is on day 3, P must be on a different day than T, not necessarily different from S. But P is after S, so P cannot be before day 3. If S is on day 3, P must be after S, so P must be on day 3 after S? But only one day left (day 3) and two tasks S and P — yes, they can be same day if order within day: S then P.  

So possible day arrangement:  
Day 1: some of F, W, T  
Day 2: rest of F, W, T  
Day 3: S, P  

But T and P on different days → T cannot be on day 3. So T must be on day 1 or 2.  

Step 2 – Possible task-day assignments  
We have 5 tasks, 3 days, at least 1 task per day.  
Day 3: S, P (2 tasks)  
So days 1 and 2 together: F, W, T (3 tasks)  

Possible splits for F, W, T between day 1 and 2:  
Case 1: Day 1: two of F, W, T; Day 2: the remaining one.  
Case 2: Day 1: one of F, W, T; Day 2: the other two.  

Also, T cannot be on day 3 (already fixed), so T is on day 1 or 2.  

Step 3 – Who can do each task  
F: Inga, Kelly  
W: Leanda, Olaf  
T: George, Leanda  
S: Helena, Kelly, Maricita  
P: Helena, Inga, Olaf  

S on day 3: possible workers: Helena, Kelly, Maricita.  
P on day 3: possible workers: Helena, Inga, Olaf.  

But S and P on same day, different workers.  

Step 4 – Who works on day 2?  
Day 2 tasks come from {F, W, T} (since day 3 is S, P).  

We need to check options:  

Option A) Inga  
If Inga works only on day 2, she does one of F, W, T. But Inga can only do F or P. P is day 3, so she can’t do P on day 2. So she must do F on day 2. Possible? Then F is on day 2. Then day 1 must have W and T (since 3 tasks F, W, T; F on day 2, so day 1: W, T). But T and P diff days — P day 3, T day 1 — okay.  
Check workers:  
Day 1: W (Leanda or Olaf), T (George or Leanda) → if Leanda does W and T, she’d need to do two tasks same day? No, each worker ≤1 task/day. So W and T on same day must be different people. So possible: W: Olaf, T: George on day 1.  
Day 2: F: Inga.  
Day 3: S: (Helena/Kelly/Maricita), P: (Helena/Inga/Olaf) but Inga already used on day 2, so P by Helena or Olaf.  
But Inga must do at least one task (she did F on day 2), so fine.  
But wait — Inga can do P, but if she’s only on day 2, she doesn’t do P. Then P on day 3: Helena or Olaf. S on day 3: the other of Helena or Kelly or Maricita.  
We must assign all 5 workers? No, crew of up to 5, not necessarily all 7 people. But “Each crew member does at least one task during the installation” means whoever is in the crew must work. The crew is selected from the list, but not necessarily all 7 are in crew. So we can choose crew to fit.  
So A is possible. But let’s check others.  

Option B) Kelly  
Kelly can do F or S. S is day 3, so if Kelly only works day 2, she must do F on day 2. Then F day 2. Then day 1: W, T. Day 3: S, P.  
Kelly does S on day 3? No, she’s only on day 2 per option. So she can’t do S. So she must do F on day 2. Then S day 3: not Kelly. Possible.  
But Kelly must be in crew, so she does F day 2. Then S day 3: Helena or Maricita. P day 3: Helena, Inga, or Olaf.  
Workable. So B possible? Wait, but if Kelly only works day 2, she does F. Then W and T day 1 by others. Seems fine. So A and B both possible? Question says “could be a list of all the crew members who work on the second day” — so maybe more than one option possible? Usually exactly one. So maybe one fails.  

Option C) Olaf  
Olaf can do W or P. P is day 3, so if Olaf only day 2, he must do W on day 2. Then W day 2. Then day 1: F, T. Day 3: S, P.  
P on day 3: but Olaf does P? No, he’s only on day 2, so P done by someone else. Possible.  
So Olaf does W day 2. Then F day 1: Inga or Kelly; T day 1: George or Leanda.  
Day 3: S: Helena/Kelly/Maricita, P: Helena/Inga/Olaf but Olaf not available, so Helena or Inga.  
Possible. So A, B, C all seem possible individually. That’s suspicious.  

Option D) George and Helena  
Day 2 workers: George, Helena.  
George can only do T. So T must be on day 2.  
Helena can do S or P, but S and P are day 3, so she can’t do them on day 2. So Helena cannot do any task on day 2 — contradiction.  
So D impossible.  

Option E) Leanda and Olaf  
Leanda: W, T. Olaf: W, P. P day 3, so Olaf on day 2 can only do W. But Leanda also can do W. They can’t both do W on same day (task needs one worker). So one must do other task. But Leanda’s other task is T. So possible: day 2 tasks from {F, W, T}. If Leanda does T, Olaf does W on day 2, then F must be on day 1. Then day 1: F only? That leaves day 1 with 1 task, day 2 with 2 tasks (W, T), day 3 with 2 tasks (S, P). That fits. So E possible.  

So impossible one is D.  

But the question: “which could be a list of all the crew members who work on the second day?” Means given the scenario, the set of people working on day 2 is one of these. We test each.  

We must ensure all constraints: T and P different days (ok if T day 1 or 2, P day 3), and tasks in order F-W-T-S-P.  

Let’s test A: Inga only day 2 → she does F day 2. Then W, T on day 1. Possible workers for W: Leanda or Olaf; T: George or Leanda. If W and T same day, need two workers. Choose Leanda for T, Olaf for W on day 1. Day 3: S: Helena, P: Inga? But Inga only day 2 — so P must be Helena or Olaf. Olaf used day 1, so P: Helena. S: Kelly or Maricita. Works. So A possible.  

B: Kelly only day 2 → she does F day 2. Then W, T day 1. Workers: W: Leanda/Olaf, T: George/Leanda. Choose George T, Olaf W day 1. Day 3: S: Helena/Maricita, P: Helena/Inga/Olaf but Olaf used, so Helena/Inga. Works. So B possible.  

C: Olaf only day 2 → he does W day 2. Then F, T day 1. F: Inga/Kelly, T: George/Leanda. Choose Inga F, George T day 1. Day 3: S: Helena/Kelly/Maricita, P: Helena/Inga but Inga used day 1, so P: Helena. Works. So C possible.  

So A,B,C,E possible? That’s too many. Did I misorder tasks?  

Wait — tasks sequence: F then W then T then S then P.  
If W is on day 2 (Olaf), then T must be after W, so T cannot be on day 1. So my earlier arrangement for C is wrong:  
If Olaf only day 2, does W on day 2. Then T must be after W, so T can’t be day 1. So T must be day 2 or 3, but T can’t be day 3 (P day 3). So T must be day 2. But then day 2 has W and T. That’s two tasks on day 2: W by Olaf, T by someone else. But option C says only Olaf works day 2 — but T needs a worker on day 2 (George or Leanda). So contradiction: there must be another worker on day 2 for T. So C impossible.  

Similarly check B: Kelly only day 2, does F on day 2. Then W must be before T, and T before S. If F day 2, W must be before F? No, W after F. So W can be day 1 or day 2? If F day 2, W must be after F, so W can’t be day 1. So W must be day 2 or 3. But W before T, T before S (day 3), so W day 3 impossible (S day 3, W would be after T). So W must be day 2 as well. So day 2 tasks: F then W. Then T must be after W, so T can’t be day 1, so T must be day 2 as well. Then day 2 has F, W, T — that’s 3 tasks day 2, days 1 and 3 empty? No, day 3 has S, P. So day 1 has no tasks — violates “at least one task each day”. So B impossible.  

Check A: Inga only day 2, does F on day 2. Then W must be after F, so W day 2 or 3. But W before T, T before S (day 3). If W day 3, impossible (T after W but T before S can’t happen). So W day 2. Then T after W, so T day 2 or 3. T day 3 impossible (P day 3). So T day 2. So day 2: F, W, T — all three early tasks same day. Then day 1 has no task — violates “at least one task each day”. So A impossible.  

So only E works: Leanda and Olaf day 2.  
Day 2 tasks from F,W,T with order constraints:  
If day 2 has two people, possible tasks:  
We need F day 1 (since F first, so day 1 must have F because if F day 2, then W day 2 or 3, but W day 3 impossible, so W day 2, T day 2, then day 1 empty — invalid). So F day 1.  
Then W day 2 (since after F), T day 2 (since after W, and before S day 3). So day 2: W and T. Workers: W: Leanda or Olaf; T: George or Leanda. To have only Leanda and Olaf on day 2, assign W to Olaf, T to Leanda (or vice versa? Leanda can do both but one task/day). So Olaf does W, Leanda does T on day 2. Works. Day 1: F by Inga or Kelly. Day 3: S and P by others. Satisfies all.  

So only E possible.  

The correct option is: E

question: Which one of the following could be a pair of members of the crew both of whom work on the same days as each other and each of whom perform two tasks?
options: A) George and Maricita
B) Helena and Kelly
C) Inga and Leanda
D) Kelly and Leanda
E) Leanda and Olaf
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1: Understand the constraints

• Tasks in order: Framing (F), Wallboarding (W), Taping (T), Sanding (S), Priming (P)

• 5 tasks, 3 days max, at least 1 task per day.

• Taping and Priming are on different days.

• Each worker does at least 1 task total, at most 1 task per day.

• Each task done by exactly 1 worker.

We are looking for a pair of crew members who:
1. Work on the same days as each other (their workdays are identical sets).
2. Each performs two tasks (so each works 2 days, or possibly 2 tasks in 2 different days, but since max 1 task/day, that means they work 2 days each, doing 1 task each day).
3. They are in the crew of up to 5 workers.

Step 2: Who can do what?

George: T  
Helena: S, P  
Inga: F, P  
Kelly: F, S  
Leanda: W, T  
Maricita: S  
Olaf: W, P  

Step 3: Days constraints

T and P on different days.  
Tasks in fixed order F-W-T-S-P.

Possible day splits:  
Option: Day1: F, W; Day2: T, S; Day3: P (3 days)  
Or Day1: F; Day2: W, T; Day3: S, P (but T and P diff days? That’s fine here: T day2, P day3)  
Or Day1: F, W; Day2: T; Day3: S, P  
Or Day1: F; Day2: W; Day3: T, S, P (T and P same day? Not allowed)  
So T and P must be separated.

Step 4: What does “both work on the same days as each other” mean?

It means if one works on Monday and Wednesday, the other also works on Monday and Wednesday (and possibly no other days for either). So their set of active days is identical.

Step 5: Try each option

A) George and Maricita  
George: T only. But George must do 2 tasks. Impossible because George can only do T. So no.  

B) Helena and Kelly  
Helena: S, P  
Kelly: F, S  

They can share days only if they work on days when their tasks are scheduled.  
Kelly’s tasks: F (must be day1), S (could be day2 or 3).  
Helena’s tasks: S, P. P must be after S, and T before S? Wait: order F-W-T-S-P. So S before P. So Helena’s S and P must be on different days (since S before P in task order, but could be same day if S then P same day? No: each task completed before next begins, so S and P same day possible only if they are consecutive tasks and no other task between them. That happens if T is earlier that day or previous day. Let’s check: F-W-T-S-P. S and P are consecutive tasks, so they can be same day. Yes! So Helena could do S and P on the same day (last two tasks of the project) if T is previous day. Then she works only 1 day but does 2 tasks? No: max 1 task/day. So she can’t do S and P same day. So Helena’s two tasks must be on two different days.  

So Helena works 2 days: one with S, one with P.  
Kelly works 2 days: one with F (day1 necessarily), one with S.  

For them to have same workdays:  
Kelly’s days = {day1 (F), dayX (S)}  
Helena’s days = {dayY (S), dayZ (P)}  

For these sets to be equal, they must both work on exactly 2 days: {day1, day3} possible?  
If Kelly: F day1, S day3.  
If Helena: S day3, P day1? Impossible because P after S. So Helena’s S day3, P day4? Only 3 days max. So P must be day3 if S day3? No, P after S, so if S day3, P can’t be day3 (1 task/day). So S day2, P day3.  

Then Kelly: F day1, S day2.  
Days Kelly: {1,2}. Days Helena: {2,3}. Not same. So impossible.  
Thus B is impossible.

C) Inga and Leanda  
Inga: F, P  
Leanda: W, T  

Order: F then W then T then S then P.  
Inga’s F must be day1, P last (day3 likely). So Inga’s days: {1,3}.  
Leanda’s W must be after F, could be day1 if F morning, W afternoon? No: each task completed before next begins, so F and W can’t same day unless consecutive and no other task between? They are consecutive: F then W. So F and W can be same day. Then W day1, T day? T after W, could be day1 if W morning T afternoon? That’s two tasks in one day for Leanda? Not allowed (1 task/day max). So W and T different days. So Leanda’s days: if W day1, T day2; or W day2, T day3.  

For Inga {1,3} to match Leanda’s days:  
Leanda’s days must be {1,3} too. That means W day1, T day3. But T before S before P, so T day3 impossible because S and P after T must fit in day3 but T is day3, then S and P after? No time. So T day3 impossible. So Leanda cannot have days {1,3}. So C impossible.

D) Kelly and Leanda  
Kelly: F, S  
Leanda: W, T  

Kelly: F day1, S day? S after T, T after W, W after F. So: F day1, W day? W could be day1 (if F and W same day) but Leanda does W, Kelly does F, so they can work same day. But Leanda also does T on a later day.  

Possible schedule:  
Day1: F(Kelly), W(Leanda)  
Day2: T(Leanda), S(Kelly)  
Day3: P(someone else)  

Then Kelly’s days: {1,2}  
Leanda’s days: {1,2}  
They match! Each does 2 tasks on 2 days.  

Check rules: T day2, P day3 (diff days), each worker 1 task/day, all tasks assigned. Who does P? Could be Helena or Inga or Olaf. Crew size: Kelly, Leanda, +1 for P = 3 total, fine.  

So D is possible.

E) Leanda and Olaf  
Leanda: W, T  
Olaf: W, P  

They can’t both do W (task done by exactly one worker). So they must do different tasks.  
Leanda: W and T. Olaf: P and ? He must do 2 tasks, but only W and P available. But W already done by Leanda. So Olaf can only do P and can’t do 2 tasks unless he also does W, conflict. So impossible.

Step 6: Conclusion

Only D works.

The correct option is: D

context: A closet contains exactly six hangers—1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6—hanging, in that order, from left to right. question: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of the hangers to the fabrics of the dresses that hang on them?
options: A) 1: wool; 2: gauze; 3: silk; 4: linen; 5: polyester; 6: rayon
B) 1: rayon; 2: wool; 3: gauze; 4: silk; 5: linen; 6: polyester
C) 1: polyester; 2: gauze; 3: wool; 4: silk; 5: linen; 6: rayon
D) 1: linen; 2: silk; 3: wool; 4: gauze; 5: polyester; 6: rayon
E) 1: gauze; 2: rayon; 3: silk; 4: linen; 5: wool; 6: polyester
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each condition against the options.  

Conditions:  
1. Gauze is on a lower-numbered hanger than Polyester. (G < P)  
2. Rayon is on hanger 1 or 6.  
3. Either Wool or Silk is on hanger 3.  
4. Linen is immediately to the right of Silk. (L = S+1)  

Option A: 1: wool; 2: gauze; 3: silk; 4: linen; 5: polyester; 6: rayon  
• G=2, P=5 → G < P ✅  

• Rayon=6 ✅  

• Hanger 3 = Silk ✅  

• Linen=4, Silk=3 → Linen is right of Silk ✅  

All conditions satisfied.  

Option B: 1: rayon; 2: wool; 3: gauze; 4: silk; 5: linen; 6: polyester  
• G=3, P=6 → G < P ✅  

• Rayon=1 ✅  

• Hanger 3 = Gauze ❌ (must be Wool or Silk) → fails immediately.  

Option C: 1: polyester; 2: gauze; 3: wool; 4: silk; 5: linen; 6: rayon  
• G=2, P=1 → G < P? ❌ (2 > 1) → fails.  

Option D: 1: linen; 2: silk; 3: wool; 4: gauze; 5: polyester; 6: rayon  
• Linen=1, Silk=2 → Linen is right of Silk? ❌ (Linen is left of Silk) → fails.  

Option E: 1: gauze; 2: rayon; 3: silk; 4: linen; 5: wool; 6: polyester  
• G=1, P=6 → G < P ✅  

• Rayon=2 ❌ (Rayon must be 1 or 6) → fails.  

Only A satisfies all conditions.  

The correct option is: A

Check:

Rule 2: L_F? No, ok.  
Rule 3: W ∈ I, Z ∈ F, ok.  
Rule 4: U ∈ F, G ∈ I, ok.  
Rule 5: Z ∈ F → H ∈ F, yes.  

Can we add anyone else to F? Only L and W and G remain in I.  

Add L to F? If L_F → M_I and U_I. But M and U are in F currently. So that would violate. So L can’t be in F unless M, U in I.

We want F large. Put G in F, so H in I.  

W and Z in different committees. To maximize F, put W in F, Z in I.  

Rule 4: U and G different: G ∈ F → U ∈ I.

Step 10: Verify 5 impossible  

If F=5, I=2. W and Z in different committees → one in F, one in I. So I has at least 1 (Z or W). The other 5 people in F? Possibly, but check G and Z conflict: If both in F, impossible. So F = {G, W, two of M, U, and someone else?} Actually 7 people: F = G, W, M, U, and one more? The only ones left are L and ? We have 7: G, H, L, M, U, W, Z. If I = {H, Z}, F = {G, W, M, U, L}. question: If Miyauchi and Wharton both serve on the finance committee, then which one of the following could be true?

B) Guzman and Upchurch both serve on the incentives committee.

reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

Given:  
• 7 people: G, H, L, M, U, W, Z  

• Committees: Finance (F) or Incentives (I)  

• Conditions:  

1. If G ∈ F → H ∈ I.  
2. If L ∈ F → M ∈ I and U ∈ I.  
3. W and Z are on different committees.  
4. U and G are on different committees.  
5. If Z ∈ F → H ∈ F.  

Additional given for this question:  
M ∈ F, W ∈ F.  

Step 1 – From W ∈ F and W, Z different committees:  
W ∈ F ⇒ Z ∈ I.  

Step 2 – From Z ∈ I and condition 5 (If Z ∈ F → H ∈ F):  
Z ∈ I means the antecedent of condition 5 is false, so no restriction on H from that.  

Step 3 – From M ∈ F and condition 2 (If L ∈ F → M ∈ I and U ∈ I):  
M ∈ F means M ∉ I. But condition 2 says: if L ∈ F, then M ∈ I.  
But M ∈ F ⇒ M ∉ I. So L ∈ F would force M ∈ I (impossible).  
Thus L ∉ F.  
So L ∈ I.  

Step 4 – From L ∈ I and condition 2:  
No further restriction from condition 2 (since L ∉ F, the implication is vacuously true).  

Step 5 – From U and G on different committees (condition 4):  
Possible arrangements: (G ∈ F, U ∈ I) or (G ∈ I, U ∈ F).  

Step 6 – From condition 1: If G ∈ F → H ∈ I.  
We’ll check cases later.  

Step 7 – Try each option to see if it’s possible.  

Option A: G ∈ F and L ∈ F.  
But L ∈ F is impossible (Step 3). So A is false.  

Option B: G ∈ I and U ∈ I.  
From condition 4: U and G different committees, so G ∈ I ⇒ U ∈ F, not I.  
So B is impossible.  

Option C: H ∈ F and Z ∈ F.  
But Z ∈ I (Step 1), so C is impossible.  

Option D: L ∈ I and U ∈ I.  
We know L ∈ I (Step 3).  
Possible to have U ∈ I?  
If U ∈ I, then from condition 4 (U and G different committees) ⇒ G ∈ F.  
If G ∈ F, condition 1 says H ∈ I.  
So assignment could be:  
F: M, W, G, (H? no, H ∈ I), so F = {M, W, G}, I = {L, U, H, Z} (7th person? We have 7 total: G, H, L, M, U, W, Z. Let’s check: F: G, M, W (3 people), I: L, U, H, Z (4 people) — that’s all 7. Works.  
Check conditions:  
Condition 1: G ∈ F ⇒ H ∈ I (yes, H ∈ I).  
Condition 2: L ∈ I ⇒ no restriction.  
Condition 3: W ∈ F, Z ∈ I — ok.  
Condition 4: U ∈ I, G ∈ F — ok.  
Condition 5: Z ∈ I ⇒ no restriction.  
So D is possible.  

Option E: Z ∈ F and U ∈ F.  
But Z ∈ I (Step 1), so E impossible.  

Only D is possible.  

The correct option is: D

reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason step by step.  

Step 1 – Restate the conditions in short form  
Let F = finance committee, I = incentives committee.  

1. If G in F → H in I.  
2. If L in F → M in I and U in I.  
3. W and Z are in different committees.  
4. U and G are in different committees.  
5. If Z in F → H in F.  

Step 2 – Given  
G in I.  

From condition 4: U and G are in different committees.  
G in I → U in F.  

Step 3 – Check implications  
U in F → Look at condition 2: If L in F → M in I and U in I.  
But U is in F, not I. So the statement "If L in F" would require U in I, which is false.  
Thus, L in F is impossible (it would make condition 2 false).  
Therefore L must be in I.  

Step 4 – Conclusion  
We have deduced: L in I.  

That matches option B.  

No need to check other options because the question asks “must be true” and we have a definite deduction.  

The correct option is: B

context: Eight people—Fiona, George, Harriet, Ingrid, Karl, Manuel, Olivia, and Peter—are sitting, evenly spaced, around a circular picnic table. Any two of them are said to be sitting directly across from one another if and only if there are exactly three other people sitting between them, counting in either direction around the table. The following conditions apply: Fiona sits directly across from George. Harriet sits immediately next to neither Fiona nor Karl. Ingrid sits immediately next to, and immediately clockwise from, Olivia.
question: Which one of the following could be the order in which four of the people are seated, with no one else seated between them, counting clockwise around the table?
options: A) George, Peter, Karl, Fiona
B) Harriet, Olivia, Ingrid, Karl
C) Ingrid, Fiona, Peter, Manuel
D) Olivia, Manuel, Karl, George
E) Peter, Harriet, Karl, Fiona
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints.  

Step 1 – Understanding the setup  
• 8 people: F, G, H, I, K, M, O, P.  

• “Directly across” means exactly 3 people between them in either direction → positions differ by 4 around the circle (opposite seats).  

• F sits directly across from G → F and G are opposite. Number seats 1–8: if F is in seat 1, G is in seat 5 (or vice versa).  

Step 2 – Other constraints  
1. H sits immediately next to neither F nor K. So H is not adjacent to F, not adjacent to K.  
2. I sits immediately next to and immediately clockwise from O. So O–I in that order, adjacent. That means if O is in seat x, I is in seat x+1 (mod 8).  

Step 3 – Testing each option  
We need 4 people in a row in clockwise order, no gaps, consistent with constraints.  

Option A: George, Peter, Karl, Fiona (clockwise)  
• G and F are opposite. In a circle of 8, opposite people are 4 apart. But here G and F are 3 apart in this sequence (G → P → K → F: F is 3 seats clockwise from G), so they can’t be opposite. Contradiction. → Eliminate A.  

Option B: Harriet, Olivia, Ingrid, Karl  
• Check adjacency: O–I in that order? Yes: Olivia then Ingrid, so O is immediately CCW from I? Wait, clockwise order: H → O → I → K. So O to I is clockwise: O then I, so I is immediately clockwise from O. Good.  

• Check H constraints: H adjacent to F? In this block, H’s neighbors in the circle: one neighbor is O (other neighbor is person before H in circle, not in block). So H’s neighbors are O and someone else. F is not in block, so F could be elsewhere. But H also not adjacent to K. In this block, H’s neighbor in block is O, not K. But K is in block: K’s neighbors: I and someone else. So H and K are not adjacent in this block (they are separated by O and I). So possible.  

• But we must check if this block fits with F–G opposite. Not obviously impossible yet. Let’s keep.  

Option C: Ingrid, Fiona, Peter, Manuel  
• I is immediately clockwise from O? Not necessarily satisfied in this block unless O is adjacent to I outside this block? But O not in block. Could O be placed such that O is immediately CCW from I? That would mean order O, I. But here I is first in block, so O would have to be the person before I (seat before I in circle). That’s possible. But does it violate other constraints? Possibly. Let’s check H constraints later. But no obvious violation yet. Keep.  

Option D: Olivia, Manuel, Karl, George  
• O–I constraint: O in block, I not in block. So I must be immediately after O clockwise. But here O’s clockwise neighbor in block is M, not I. So impossible. → Eliminate D.  

Option E: Peter, Harriet, Karl, Fiona  
• H constraint: H not adjacent to F. In this block, H’s neighbors: P and K. F is at other end: F’s neighbors: K and someone else. So H and F are not adjacent (K between them in block). So that’s fine.  

• But F and G are opposite. In this block, F is 3 seats clockwise from P. G not in block. Could G be opposite F? Yes, if G is 4 seats from F. But in this block, F is last, G would be 4 seats away, so G would be between P and H? Let’s check: seats numbered by block: 1=P, 2=H, 3=K, 4=F. Opposite of F (seat 4) is seat 8. So G is seat 8. That’s possible.  

• But H not adjacent to K? In block, H is adjacent to K: yes, H between P and K, so H adjacent to K. Violates “H sits immediately next to neither F nor K”. So H is next to K here → Eliminate E.  

Step 4 – Between B and C  

Option B: H, O, I, K  
• H not adjacent to F: possible if F not next to H. H’s neighbors: O and person before H (not in block). So that’s fine if that person isn’t F.  

• H not adjacent to K: in block, K’s neighbors: I and person after K (not in block). So H and K not adjacent. Good.  

• O–I satisfied in block.  

• F–G opposite: We can place this block in circle so that F and G are opposite. Seems possible.  

Option C: I, F, P, M  
• O must be immediately CCW from I. So person before I in circle is O. In block, I is first, so preceding seat (seat before block) is O. So O is adjacent to I, good.  

• H constraints: H not in block, so H can be placed not adjacent to F or K. K not in block, so possible.  

• But check: F and G opposite: F in block (second in block). Opposite of F is 4 seats away. If block is seats 1=I, 2=F, 3=P, 4=M, then opposite of F (seat 2) is seat 6 = G. So G is seat 6. That’s fine.  

• But H not adjacent to F: F’s neighbors: I and P. So H is not I or P. So H can be seat 5, 6, 7, or 8 except 6 is G, so H in 5,7,8. Also H not adjacent to K: K not in block, so place K not adjacent to H. Seems possible.  

So both B and C seem possible logically. But LSAT usually has one that works given all constraints. Let’s check if B violates F–G opposite when considering H constraints fully.  

Test B: Block: H, O, I, K in seats 1–4.  
Then O in seat 2, I in seat 3 (good).  
F–G opposite: F in seat 5, G in seat 1? No, seat 1 is H. Opposite of seat 5 is seat 1. So G must be seat 1. But seat 1 is H. So G can’t be seat 1. So F in seat 5 → G in seat 1 (H) → impossible. Try F in other positions: If block seats 1–4 = HOKI, then to have F–G opposite, possible if F is seat 6, G seat 2? But seat 2 is O, so no. F seat 7, G seat 3 (I) no. F seat 8, G seat 4 (K) no. So with that block, F and G can’t be opposite because opposite seats are both occupied by block members or their opposites are in block. Let’s check systematically:  

Seats: 1=H, 2=O, 3=I, 4=K. Opposites: (1,5), (2,6), (3,7), (4,8).  
F and G occupy one opposite pair. The available opposite pairs for F,G are pairs where neither seat is in {1,2,3,4}. But all opposite pairs involve a seat in 1–4: pair (1,5) has seat 1 occupied; (2,6) seat 2 occupied; (3,7) seat 3 occupied; (4,8) seat 4 occupied. So any opposite pair has one seat in block, so F or G would have to be in the block. But F and G not in block (block is HOKI). So impossible. So B is impossible.  

Thus only C remains.  

Step 5 – Verify C: I, F, P, M  
Seats: 1=I, 2=F, 3=P, 4=M.  
O must be seat 8 (immediately CCW from I: seat 8 to seat 1).  
Opposite pairs: (1,5), (2,6), (3,7), (4,8).  
F in seat 2 → G in seat 6.  
H not adjacent to F: F’s neighbors: I(seat1) and P(seat3). So H not in {1,3}. H not adjacent to K: K not in block; place K in seat 5 or 7. If K in seat 5, neighbors 4(M) and 6(G). H in seat 7: neighbors 6(G) and 8(O). Then H adjacent to G and O, not F or K. Good. Works.  

So C is possible.  

Final answer:

context: Eight people—Fiona, George, Harriet, Ingrid, Karl, Manuel, Olivia, and Peter—are sitting, evenly spaced, around a circular picnic table. Any two of them are said to be sitting directly across from one another if and only if there are exactly three other people sitting between them, counting in either direction around the table. The following conditions apply: Fiona sits directly across from George. Harriet sits immediately next to neither Fiona nor Karl. Ingrid sits immediately next to, and immediately clockwise from, Olivia.
question: If Karl sits directly across from Harriet, then what is the minimum possible number of people sitting between George and Karl, counting clockwise from George to Karl?
options: A) zero
B) one
C) two
D) three
E) four
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the setup  
• 8 people: F, G, H, I, K, M, O, P.  

• “Directly across” means exactly 3 people between them in either direction.  

  • In a circle of 8, “across” = seat positions differ by 4 (mod 8).  

  • Label seats 1 to 8 around the circle. If someone is in seat 1, across is seat 5.  

Step 2 – Given fixed pairs  
1. F is directly across from G.  
   • If F is in seat 1, G is in seat 5 (or vice versa).  

2. K is directly across from H (given in the “if” part).  
   • So K and H are opposite each other.  

3. I sits immediately next to and immediately clockwise from O.  
   • So O is immediately counterclockwise from I, or equivalently: I = O + 1 (mod 8) in seat numbers.  

4. H sits immediately next to neither F nor K.  
   • “Immediately next to” = adjacent seats (difference 1 mod 8).  

Step 3 – Arranging opposite pairs  
We have 4 opposite pairs:  
• (F, G)  

• (K, H)  

• Remaining 4 people: I, O, M, P form the other 2 opposite pairs.  

Also I and O are adjacent, so they cannot be opposite each other.  
Thus I’s opposite is M or P; O’s opposite is the other.  

Step 4 – Try to minimize people between G and K (clockwise from G to K)  
We can number seats 1–8. Let’s fix F in seat 1, G in seat 5 (across from F).  

We need to place K and H opposite:  
Possible opposite pairs for (K, H): seats (2,6), (3,7), (4,8) — but not (1,5) because that’s F,G.  

Also H adjacent to neither F nor K.  

Step 5 – Try smallest gap from G to K clockwise  
Clockwise from G (seat 5) to K:  
Gap = number of people between them, so if K is in seat 6, gap = 0.  
Check if possible:  

Seats:  
1: F  
5: G  
6: K → then H is in seat 2 (since K’s opposite is H).  

Check H’s adjacency: H in seat 2: adjacent seats are 1 (F) and 3. Adjacent to F? Yes, seat 1 is F → violates “H not adjacent to F”. So K cannot be in seat 6.  

Step 6 – Try K in seat 7  
Then H in seat 3 (opposite).  

H in seat 3: adjacent seats 2 and 4. Neither is F (seat 1) nor K (seat 7). Good.  

Now I and O adjacent, I clockwise from O: so O then I in consecutive seats.  

Remaining seats: {2,4,6,8} for {I,O,M,P}. Also I’s opposite is M or P.  

We must check if possible arrangement exists.  

Gap from G (5) to K (7) clockwise: between them is seat 6 (one person). So gap = 1.  

Let’s test arrangement:  
Seats: 1=F, 2=?, 3=H, 4=?, 5=G, 6=?, 7=K, 8=?  

Remaining {I,O,M,P} in {2,4,6,8}.  

I,O adjacent: possible pairs in remaining seats: (2,4) no (not adjacent in circle? seats 2 and 4 are not adjacent, gap seat 3 between them), so not possible. Adjacent means diff mod 8
 = 1 or 7. So possible adjacent pairs in {2,4,6,8}:  
• (8,2) adjacent (seats 8 and 2: yes, 8’s neighbors 7 and 1, but 2 is neighbor of 1 and 3, so 8 and 2 are adjacent? Wait: seat 8 adjacent to seats 7 and 1. 2 is adjacent to 1 and 3. So 8 and 2 are not adjacent (they differ by 2 mod 8: 8 to 2 is distance 2). So not adjacent. So no adjacent seats in {2,4,6,8}? Check: 2’s neighbors 1 and 3 (not in set), 4’s neighbors 3 and 5 (not in set), 6’s neighbors 5 and 7 (not in set), 8’s neighbors 7 and 1 (not in set). So indeed none of the remaining seats are adjacent to each other!  

That’s a problem: I and O must be adjacent but remaining seats for them are {2,4,6,8}, none adjacent. So impossible.  

So K in seat 7 is impossible because I,O can’t be placed adjacently.  

Step 7 – Try K in seat 4  
Then H in seat 8.  

H in seat 8: adjacent seats 7 and 1. 1 is F → H adjacent to F → violates rule. So no.  

So K in seat 4 fails.  

Step 8 – Try K in seat 3  
Then H in seat 7.  

H in seat 7: adjacent seats 6 and 8. Not F (1) or K (3). Good.  

Seats: 1=F, 2=?, 3=K, 4=?, 5=G, 6=?, 7=H, 8=?  

Remaining {I,O,M,P} in {2,4,6,8}. Again none are adjacent! Same problem as before.  

So any placement of K that puts both remaining people (I,O) in {2,4,6,8} fails because these seats are every other seat, no adjacency.  

Step 9 – So K must be in a seat such that I,O are in seats that are adjacent in circle  
We need at least two consecutive free seats for I,O after placing F,G,K,H.  

Current: F in 1, G in 5 fixed.  

Possible (K,H) opposite pairs left: (2,6), (3,7), (4,8).  

Check each:  

(K,H) = (2,6):  
Seats: 1=F, 2=K, 3=?, 4=?, 5=G, 6=H, 7=?, 8=?  

Remaining {I,O,M,P} in {3,4,7,8}. Adjacent pairs possible: (3,4), (7,8), (8,3) no (8 and 3 not adjacent), (4,7) no. So possible I,O in (3,4) or (7,8).  

Gap from G (5) to K (2) clockwise: 5→6→7→8→1→2: people between = 6(H),7,8,1(F) = 4 people between. Gap=4.  

(K,H) = (3,7):  
Seats: 1=F, 2=?, 3=K, 4=?, 5=G, 6=?, 7=H, 8=?  

Remaining {I,O,M,P} in {2,4,6,8} → no adjacency → impossible.  

(K,H) = (4,8):  
Seats: 1=F, 2=?, 3=?, 4=K, 5=G, 6=?, 7=?, 8=H  

Remaining {I,O,M,P} in {2,3,6,7}. Adjacent pairs: (2,3), (6,7). Good.  

Gap from G (5) to K (4) clockwise: 5→6→7→8→1→2→3→4: between = seats 6,7,8,1,2,3 = 6 people? Wait count: 5 (G), [6,7,8,1,2,3], 4(K). That’s 6 people between. But we have only 8 people total, so between two seats: #between = (K - G mod 8) - 1. Let’s do mod 8: G=5, K=4.  

Clockwise: 5→6(1), 7(2), 8(3), 1(4), 2(5), 3(6), 4(7th step). People between = seats 6,7,8,1,2,3 = 6 people. That’s impossible since only 6 others total, but F and H are among them. Actually total others = F,G,K,H are 4, so 4 others: I,O,M,P = 4 people. So between any two seats, max between = 4? Wait, total 8 people. If we count between G and K, we exclude G and K, so 6 people remain. But some must be between. Let’s list: all people: F(1), ?, ?, K(4), G(5), ?, ?, H(8). Others: seat2,3,6,7 = I,O,M,P.  

Between G(5) and K(4) clockwise: 5 to 4: going 5,6,7,8,1,2,3,4. Between = {6,7,8,1,2,3} = 6 people indeed. So gap=6? But 6>4, so not possible given only 4 others? Wait, 6 others total besides G and K: F,H and I,O,M,P. Yes 6 people. So gap=6 means all others are between them. That’s possible. But that’s not minimal; we want minimal.  

Earlier case (K=2): gap=4. Try K=6? But K=6 means H=2.  

Check K=6: seats: 1=F, 2=H, 3=?, 4=?, 5=G, 6=K, 7=?, 8=?  

H in 2 adjacent to F? 2’s neighbors 1(F) and 3 → violates H not adjacent to F. So no.  

So only possible arrangements with I,O adjacent:  

Case 1: K=2, H=6 → gap=4 (we saw).  
Case 2: K=4, H=8 → gap=6.  
Case 3: K=8, H=4: check: 1=F, 2=?, 3=?, 4=H, 5=G, 6=?, 7=?, 8=K. Remaining {I,O,M,P} in {2,3,6,7} → has adjacent pairs (2,3),(6,7).  

Gap from G(5) to K(8) clockwise: 5→6→7→8: between = seats 6,7 = 2 people. That’s smaller!  

Check H in 4: adjacent to 3 and 5. 5 is G, not F or K. 3 is not F or K. So valid.  

So minimal possible gap = 2.  

Step 10 – Verify no gap=1 possible  
Gap=1 means K is two seats clockwise from G (G+2 mod 8). G=5, so K=7. But that was impossible due to I,O adjacency. Similarly gap=0 means K=6, impossible due to H adjacent to F.  

So minimal gap=2.  

Step 11 – Match with options  
Options: 0,1,2,3,4. Minimal we found is 2.  

The correct option is: C

context: Each of seven candidates for the position of judge—Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, Li, McDonnell, Ortiz, and Perkins—will be appointed to an open position on one of two courts—the appellate court or the trial court. There are three open positions on the appellate court and six open positions on the trial court, but not all of them will be filled at this time. The judicial appointments will conform to the following conditions: Li must be appointed to the appellate court. Kurtz must be appointed to the trial court. Hamadi cannot be appointed to the same court as Perkins.
question: Which one of the following is an acceptable set of appointments of candidates to courts?
options: A) appellate: Hamadi, Ortiz trial: Jefferson, Kurtz, Li, McDonnell, Perkins
B) appellate: Hamadi, Li, Perkins trial: Jefferson, Kurtz, McDonnell, Ortiz
C) appellate: Kurtz, Li, Perkins trial: Hamadi, Jefferson, McDonnell, Ortiz
D) appellate: Li, McDonnell, Ortiz trial: Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, Perkins
E) appellate: Li, Perkins trial: Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, McDonnell, Ortiz
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

Step 1 – List the fixed conditions from the context.  
• Li → appellate court.  

• Kurtz → trial court.  

• Hamadi and Perkins cannot be on the same court.  

Step 2 – Check each option against the fixed conditions.  

Option A:  
Appellate: Hamadi, Ortiz  
Trial: Jefferson, Kurtz, Li, McDonnell, Perkins  
• Violation: Li must be appellate, but here Li is in trial → Invalid.  

Option B:  
Appellate: Hamadi, Li, Perkins  
Trial: Jefferson, Kurtz, McDonnell, Ortiz  
• Li is appellate → OK.  

• Kurtz is trial → OK.  

• Hamadi and Perkins are both appellate → same court → Violates “cannot be appointed to the same court” → Invalid.  

Option C:  
Appellate: Kurtz, Li, Perkins  
Trial: Hamadi, Jefferson, McDonnell, Ortiz  
• Kurtz must be trial, but here Kurtz is appellate → Invalid.  

Option D:  
Appellate: Li, McDonnell, Ortiz  
Trial: Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, Perkins  
• Li appellate → OK.  

• Kurtz trial → OK.  

• Hamadi and Perkins: Hamadi is trial, Perkins is trial → same court → Violates rule → Invalid.  

Option E:  
Appellate: Li, Perkins  
Trial: Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, McDonnell, Ortiz  
• Li appellate → OK.  

• Kurtz trial → OK.  

• Hamadi (trial) and Perkins (appellate) → different courts → OK.  

No rule about how many positions must be filled, so 2 appellate and 5 trial is acceptable.  

Step 3 – Conclusion.  
Only E satisfies all conditions.  

The correct option is: E

context: Each of seven candidates for the position of judge—Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, Li, McDonnell, Ortiz, and Perkins—will be appointed to an open position on one of two courts—the appellate court or the trial court. question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?

B) McDonnell and Ortiz are both appointed to the appellate court.
C) Ortiz and Perkins are both appointed to the appellate court.
D) Hamadi and Jefferson are both appointed to the trial court.

reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

Step 1 – Restating the facts  
• 7 candidates: H, J, K, L, M, O, P.  

• Courts: Appellate (3 positions), Trial (6 positions).  

• Not all positions will be filled, so not all 9 seats need to be filled.  

• Constraints:  

  1. L must be appointed to Appellate.  
  2. K must be appointed to Trial.  
  3. H cannot be appointed to the same court as P.  

Step 2 – Understanding the “cannot be true” question  
We need to see which scenario is impossible given the constraints.  

Step 3 – Check each option  

A) H and M both appointed to Appellate  
Appellate: L, H, M → 3 people.  
Trial: K, plus possibly J, O, P, but H and P are not on same court, so P must be on Trial.  
This is possible:  
Appellate: L, H, M  
Trial: K, P, J, O (and maybe some not appointed)  
No conflict.  

B) M and O both appointed to Appellate  
Appellate: L, M, O → 3 people.  
H and P cannot be on same court, so if H is Appellate, P must be Trial; if H is Trial, P must be Appellate. But Appellate already full (L, M, O), so P cannot be Appellate. Thus P must be Trial. H could be Trial or Appellate? Wait, Appellate full (L, M, O), so H cannot be Appellate. So H must be Trial (or not appointed). P must be Trial or Appellate? But Appellate full, so P must be Trial. Then H and P both Trial — that violates H and P not same court? Yes, H and P both Trial means same court → violation.  
So H cannot be Trial (since P is Trial), and H cannot be Appellate (since full). So H cannot be appointed at all? But they must appoint H? The problem says “each of seven candidates … will be appointed” → all 7 are appointed. So H must be appointed.  
Thus:  
Appellate: L, M, O (3 people)  
Trial: K, P, H, J (4 people) → H and P same court → not allowed.  
So B is impossible.  

Step 4 – Double-check others to ensure only B is impossible  

C) O and P both Appellate  
Appellate: L, O, P (3 people)  
Trial: K, H, J, M (H and P not same court → okay)  
Possible.  

D) H and J both Trial  
Appellate: L, plus possibly others (up to 2 more)  
Trial: K, H, J, P? If P is Trial → H and P same court → not allowed. So P must be Appellate.  
Possible: Appellate: L, P, M; Trial: K, H, J, O. Works.  

E) O and P both Trial  
Appellate: L, plus up to 2 others (could be H, M, J)  
Trial: K, O, P, and maybe others.  
H and P not same court → H must be Appellate. Possible.  

So only B is impossible.  

Step 5 – Conclusion  

The correct option is: B

A) J and M both Appellate

• Trial gets K, plus H, O, P (but H and P can’t be together, so that’s a problem? Wait: If Appellate is full with L, J, M, then H and P must both be in Trial, because only Trial is left for them. But H and P can’t be on same court. → Violation.  

So A is impossible.  

Let’s verify:  
Appellate: L, J, M (3 spots filled).  
Trial: K, plus the remaining H, O, P.  
But H and P together in Trial breaks rule 3.  
So yes, A is impossible.  

Step 4 – Check others quickly to be sure A is the only impossible one

B) J and M both Trial  
Possible?  
Appellate: L, plus two others from {H, O, P} but not both H and P together in Appellate.  
We can choose Appellate: L, H, O (so P in Trial).  
Trial: K, J, M, P, (and maybe O? No O is in Appellate here).  
Remaining: P in Trial, H in Appellate (OK, H and P different courts). Works. So B is possible.

C) M and O both Trial  
Possible?  
Appellate: L, plus two from {H, J, P} but H and P not together.  
We can choose Appellate: L, H, J (so P in Trial).  
Trial: K, M, O, P, … Works. So C possible.

D) M and P both Appellate  
Possible?

Trial: K, plus H, J, O (H not with P, OK). Works. So D possible.

E) M and P both Trial

Example: Appellate: L, H, J. Trial: K, M, P, O. Works. So E possible.

reasoning_cot:

• Trial court: 6 open positions.

• Li (required)  

• Ortiz (given)  

That’s 2 people.  
There is 1 more appellate spot available (since 3 open positions, but not necessarily all filled? No, they just appoint some of the 7 candidates to either court.) Actually, they can appoint up to 3 appellate, but maybe fewer. But Li must be appointed to appellate, so at least 1 appellate. Step 4 – Remaining candidates for the third appellate spot

Step 5 – Consider possible assignments

If we put P appellate, then H must be trial.  
If we put both H and P appellate → violates constraint. So impossible.  
If we put neither H nor P appellate (i.e., third appellate is J or M or nobody), then H and P both trial → but that’s allowed? Yes, they can’t be on same court, but if both trial → that is same court → NOT allowed. So that’s important:  

H and P cannot be on same court → so they must be on different courts.  

So in any valid assignment:  
• One of H, P is appellate, the other is trial.  

Step 6 – Check implications

So appellate court = {Li, Ortiz, (H or P)}.  
That means the third appellate judge is either Hamadi or Perkins, not J or M.  

Step 7 – Answer the question: “must be true”  
From above: Either H is appellate or P is appellate.  
So it’s not necessarily that H is appellate (could be P).  
Not necessarily that Jefferson appellate (he could be trial).  
Not necessarily Jefferson trial (he could be appellate if they fill 4 judges? No, only 3 appellate spots max, and 2 are Li, Ortiz, 3rd is H or P, so J cannot be appellate). Wait, important:  

If appellate has 3 spots max, and we already have Li, Ortiz, and either H or P, then all 3 spots are filled. So Jefferson cannot be appellate. So Jefferson must be trial.

context: Each of seven candidates for the position of judge—Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, Li, McDonnell, Ortiz, and Perkins—will be appointed to an open position on one of two courts—the appellate court or the trial court. There are three open positions on the appellate court and six open positions on the trial court, but not all of them will be filled at this time. The judicial appointments will conform to the following conditions: Li must be appointed to the appellate court. Kurtz must be appointed to the trial court. Hamadi cannot be appointed to the same court as Perkins.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the condition that Hamadi cannot be appointed to the same court as Perkins, would have the same effect on the appointments of the seven candidates?
options: A) Hamadi and Perkins cannot both be appointed to the appellate court.
B) If Hamadi is not appointed to the trial court, then Perkins must be.
C) If Perkins is appointed to the same court as Jefferson, then Hamadi cannot be.
D) If Hamadi is appointed to the same court as Li, then Perkins must be appointed to the same court as Kurtz.
E) No three of Hamadi, Kurtz, Li, and Perkins can be appointed to the same court as each other.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Original setup:  
• 7 candidates: Hamadi (H), Jefferson (J), Kurtz (K), Li (L), McDonnell (M), Ortiz (O), Perkins (P).  

• Courts: Appellate (A, 3 open positions), Trial (T, 6 open positions).  

• Not all positions will be filled (so not all 9 total positions are filled; only 7 people to place).  

Fixed conditions:  
1. Li → Appellate.  
2. Kurtz → Trial.  
3. Original extra condition: H cannot be appointed to the same court as P.  

That means H and P must be on different courts.  

Effect of original condition:  
• Since Li is fixed in Appellate (1 spot taken there), and K is fixed in Trial (1 spot taken there), the H–P restriction forces:  

  • If H is in A, P must be in T.  

  • If H is in T, P must be in A.  

So H and P are split between the two courts.  

Question: Replace “H cannot be appointed to the same court as P” with an option that has the same effect.  

Option A: “H and P cannot both be appointed to the appellate court.”  
• This only forbids (H=A, P=A).  

• It still allows (H=T, P=T).  

• But original condition forbids (H=T, P=T) as well.  

• So A is weaker; not equivalent.  

Option B: “If H is not appointed to the trial court, then P must be.”  
• “H not in T” means H in A.  

• Then P must be in T.  

• But what if H in T? Then the “if” is false, so no restriction: P could be in T or A.  

• But original condition forbids P in T if H in T. So B allows a case that original forbids.  

• Not equivalent.  

Option C: “If P is appointed to the same court as J, then H cannot be.”  
• This is weird: “H cannot be” what? Cannot be in the same court as J? Or cannot be appointed at all? Likely means: If P and J are on same court, then H cannot be on that same court.  

• This is not equivalent to the original direct restriction between H and P. It involves J.  

• Easy to find counterexample: If P and J are on different courts, then the condition says nothing, so H and P could be on same court — violating original. So not equivalent.  

Option D: “If H is appointed to the same court as Li, then P must be appointed to the same court as Kurtz.”  
• H same court as Li: Li is in A, so H in A.  

• Then P same court as K: K is in T, so P in T.  

• So (H=A) → (P=T).  

• What if H in T? Then the “if” is false, so no restriction on P.  

• But original requires: if H in T, then P in A.  

• D doesn’t enforce that. So not equivalent.  

Option E: “No three of H, K, L, P can be appointed to the same court as each other.”  
• “No three of these four … on the same court” means at most 2 of {H,K,L,P} on any court.  

• Check if equivalent to original:  

  • L is in A, K is in T.  

  • So in A: L is there. Could H and P both be in A? That would make 3 in A (L, H, P) — forbidden by E. So H and P can’t both be in A.  

  • In T: K is there. Could H and P both be in T? That would make 3 in T (K, H, P) — forbidden by E. So H and P can’t both be in T.  

  • So E ⇒ H and P are in different courts.  

  • Also original ⇒ E: If H and P are in different courts, then in A at most 2 of the 4 (L plus one of H/P), in T at most 2 of the 4 (K plus one of H/P). So E holds.  

  • So E and original are equivalent.  

The correct option is: E

Check consecutiveness: P=6, S=2 → not consecutive. So must have P and V consecutive. But P=6, V=3 → not consecutive. Contradiction. So H=5 fails in that try. Try other R positions: If H=5, R=3, V=2: Remaining days 1,4,6 for L,S,P: L=1, S=4, P=6. P=6, V=2 not consecutive → fails. If H=5, R=2, V=1: Remaining 3,4,6 for L,S,P: L=3, S=4, P=6. P=6, V=1 not consecutive → fails. So H Friday seems impossible given constraints. So D is impossible. Step 6: Check L on Wednesday (option A) Try L=3 (Wednesday). Then S > L → S = 4, 5, or 6. But S < P, and P can be 5 or 6. Also V < R < H. We need to interleave V–R–H with L–S–P. Try L=3, S=4, P=5: Then days left: 1,2,6 for V,R,H with V3. Also V3, H>R. So R=4 or 5, H=5 or 6. context: A company's six vehicles—a hatchback, a limousine, a pickup, a roadster, a sedan, and a van—are serviced during a certain week—Monday through Saturday—one vehicle per day. The following conditions must apply: At least one of the vehicles is serviced later in the week than the hatchback. The roadster is serviced later in the week than the van and earlier in the week than the hatchback. Either the pickup and the van are serviced on consecutive days, or the pickup and the sedan are serviced on consecutive days, but not both. The sedan is serviced earlier in the week than the pickup or earlier in the week than the limousine, but not both.
question: Which one of the following could be the list of the vehicles serviced on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Friday, listed in that order?
options: A) the pickup, the hatchback, the limousine
B) the pickup, the roadster, the hatchback
C) the sedan, the limousine, the hatchback
D) the van, the limousine, the hatchback
E) the van, the roadster, the limousine
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1 – Interpret the conditions

Vehicles: Hatchback (H), Limousine (L), Pickup (P), Roadster (R), Sedan (S), Van (V).  
Days: Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat.

1. At least one vehicle is serviced later in the week than H.  
   → H is not serviced on Saturday (someone after H).

2. R is serviced later than V and earlier than H.  
   → V < R < H in order of days.

3. Either P and V are consecutive, or P and S are consecutive, but not both.  
   → Exactly one of these pairs is consecutive in days.

4. S is earlier than P or earlier than L, but not both.  
   → Exclusive or: S < P XOR S < L.  
   → So either S is before P but after L, or S is before L but after P? Wait, not exactly:  
   If S < P is true, then S < L must be false, so S > L.  
   If S < L is true, then S < P must be false, so S > P.  
   So S is between P and L in order: either L ... S ... P or P ... S ... L? Let’s check:  
   Case 1: S < P true, S < L false → L < S < P.  
   Case 2: S < L true, S < P false → P < S < L.  
   So S is the middle one in order of servicing between L and P.

Step 2 – Use V < R < H

Possible positions:  
V _ R _ H _ (with at least one day after H, so H not Sat).  
So H can be Fri or earlier, but not Sat.  
Also, R at least 1 day after V, H at least 1 day after R.

Step 3 – Try each option

We want Tue, Wed, Fri in that order.

Option A: P, H, L on Tue, Wed, Fri

Days:  
Tue: P, Wed: H, Fri: L.  
V < R < H: H on Wed → R before Wed, V before R.  
So V, R on Mon, Tue? But Tue is P, so R must be Mon, V must be earlier than R → V on Sun? Impossible.  
So V must be Mon, R Tue? But Tue is P, so R can’t be Tue. So R must be Mon, V impossible (no day before Mon).  
Thus V < R impossible if R is Mon (V would need to be earlier than Mon).  
So R cannot be Mon unless V exists earlier — impossible.  
So R must be after Mon, but before Wed: only Tue possible. But Tue is P. So R can’t be Tue.  
Thus R has no day before Wed except Mon or Tue, but Mon possible for R only if V on earlier day (none), so R can’t be Mon. So R must be Tue, but Tue is P. Contradiction.  
So A impossible.

Option B: P, R, H on Tue, Wed, Fri

V < R < H: R on Wed, H on Fri → V before Wed, R on Wed, H on Fri. Good: V on Mon or Tue. But Tue is P, so V can be Mon.  
So possible: Mon: V, Tue: P, Wed: R, Fri: H.  
Remaining days Thu, Sat for L and S.

Consecutive condition: P and V consecutive? P on Tue, V on Mon → yes, consecutive. Then P and S cannot be consecutive.  
S < P XOR S < L:  
If P and V consecutive, then P and S not consecutive.  
S ordering: Either S < P and L > S, or S < L and P > S.  
Case 1: S < P and L > S → S before Tue, so S on Mon? But Mon is V. So S can’t be before Tue except Mon taken. So S not < P.  
So must be Case 2: S < L and P > S (i.e., P < S).  
So P before S? But P on Tue, so S after Tue. And S < L.  
So ordering: P (Tue) < S < L.  
So S and L on Thu and Sat: S < L → S on Thu, L on Sat.  
Check consecutive: P and S: P Tue, S Thu → not consecutive (Wed in between: R). Good.  
All fine:  
Mon: V, Tue: P, Wed: R, Thu: S, Fri: H, Sat: L.  
V < R < H: yes.  
P-V consecutive: Mon-Tue yes.  
P-S not consecutive: yes.  
S < L true, S < P false → P < S < L: yes.  
Works.

So B is possible.

Step 4 – Check others to be sure

Option C: S, L, H on Tue, Wed, Fri  
V < R < H: H on Fri → R before Fri, V before R.  
R possible on Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu but before Fri.  
But Tue is S, Wed is L, Fri is H.  
So R could be Mon or Thu.  
If R on Thu, then V before Thu. But H is Fri, so R on Thu works: V < R (Thu) < H (Fri). Then V on Mon, Tue, Wed possible but Tue Wed are S, L.  
If R on Mon, then V impossible (no day before Mon). So R not Mon. So R must be Thu. Then V on Mon, Tue, or Wed.  
But V < R (Thu), so V on Mon, Tue, or Wed.  
Days: Mon: ?, Tue: S, Wed: L, Thu: R, Fri: H, Sat: ?. P and V left for Mon and Sat.  
If V on Mon, then P on Sat.  
Consecutive: P and V: P on Sat, V on Mon → not consecutive. So need P and S consecutive. P on Sat, S on Tue → not consecutive. So neither consecutive — violates “either P-V or P-S consecutive but not both”.  
If V on Tue, impossible (Tue is S). If V on Wed impossible (Wed is L). So V must be Mon, P Sat. Then no consecutive pair P-V or P-S. So fails.  
So C impossible.

Option D: V, L, H on Tue, Wed, Fri  
V on Tue, H on Fri → R between V and H: V (Tue) < R < H (Fri) → R on Wed or Thu. But Wed is L, so R must be Thu.  
So: Mon: ?, Tue: V, Wed: L, Thu: R, Fri: H, Sat: ?. Leftover P, S for Mon, Sat.  
Consecutive: P and V consecutive? V on Tue → P on Mon or Wed. But Wed is L, so P on Mon. Then P-V consecutive (Mon-Tue). Then P-S not consecutive. P on Mon, S on Sat → not consecutive, good.  
S ordering: S < P or S < L but not both.  
S on Sat, P on Mon → S > P, so S < P false. Must have S < L true. But S on Sat, L on Wed → S > L, so S < L false. So fails.  
So D impossible.

Option E: V, R, L on Tue, Wed, Fri  
V on Tue, R on Wed, L on Fri.  
V < R: yes. But condition: R < H. So H after Wed. Fri is L, so H must be Thu or Sat.  
If H on Thu: order V(Tue) < R(Wed) < H(Thu) < L(Fri)? No, L on Fri, H on Thu → R Wed, H Thu, L Fri: possible.  
Days: Mon: ?, Tue: V, Wed: R, Thu: H, Fri: L, Sat: ?. Left P, S for Mon, Sat.  
Consecutive: P and V consecutive or P and S consecutive but not both.  
If P on Mon, V on Tue → consecutive. Then P-S not consecutive. P on Mon, S on Sat → fine.  
S ordering: S < P or S < L but not both.  
S on Sat, P on Mon → S > P, so S < P false. Must have S < L true. But L on Fri, S on Sat → S > L, so S < L false. Fail.  
If P on Sat, V on Tue → not consecutive, so need P-S consecutive: P on Sat, S on Fri? But Fri is L, so S can’t be Fri. So P-S not consecutive. So neither consecutive — violates rule.  
So E impossible.

Only B works.

The correct option is: B

context: A street entertainer has six boxes stacked one on top of the other and numbered consecutively 1 through 6, from the lowest box up to the highest. Each box contains a single ball, and each ball is one of three colors—green, red, or white. Onlookers are to guess the color of each ball in each box, given that the following conditions hold: There are more red balls than white balls. There is a box containing a green ball that is lower in the stack than any box that contains a red ball. There is a white ball in a box that is immediately below a box that contains a green ball.
question: If there are exactly two white balls, then which one of the following boxes could contain a green ball?
options: A) box 1
B) box 3
C) box 4
D) box 5
E) box 6
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

Step 1 – Restating the conditions  
1. More red balls than white balls.  
2. There is a box containing a green ball that is lower in the stack than any box that contains a red ball.  
   • This means: Let the lowest red ball be in box  R_{\min} . Then there exists some green ball in a box  G  such that  G < R_{\min} .  

3. There is a white ball in a box that is immediately below a box that contains a green ball.  
   • This means: There exists some  k  such that box  k  is white and box  k+1  is green.  

Step 2 – Given: exactly 2 white balls  
From condition 1: red balls > white balls → red balls ≥ 3 (since white = 2).  
Total balls = 6.  
Green balls = 6 − (red + white) = 6 − (at least 3 red + 2 white) = at most 1 green? Wait, check:  
If red = 3, white = 2 → green = 1.  
If red = 4, white = 2 → green = 0.  

But condition 2 says: there is a green ball. So green ≥ 1.  
Thus red = 3, white = 2, green = 1 is the only possibility.  

Step 3 – Applying condition 2  
Lowest red ball is in some box  R_{\min} .  
There is a green ball in a box  G < R_{\min} .  
So all red balls are above this green ball.  
So  R_{\min}  is at least  G+1 .  

Step 4 – Applying condition 3  
There is a white ball immediately below a green ball:  
So there is a pair (white, green) with white in box  k  and green in box  k+1 .  

Step 5 – Combining constraints  
We have green = 1 (only one green ball).  
Condition 3: The unique green ball must be directly above a white ball.  
So green is in box  k+1 , white in box  k .  

Condition 2: Green ball is lower than all red balls.  
So all red balls are above green.  

Thus:  
• Green’s position  g  must be ≤ 4 (since there must be at least 3 reds above it, and reds occupy 3 distinct boxes above  g , so  g \leq 3  actually? Let’s check:  

  If green is in box 4, then reds must be in boxes 5, 6, and one more red above green? But only boxes 5 and 6 are above 4. So impossible to have 3 reds above green if green is in 4 or higher.  
  So green’s position  g  must be ≤ 3.  

Check:  
If  g = 3 , reds above: boxes 4, 5, 6 → 3 reds, works.  
If  g = 2 , reds above: boxes 3, 4, 5, 6 but we only need 3 reds, so possible.  
If  g = 1 , reds above: boxes 2–6, possible.  

But condition 3: green is above a white ball. So  g \geq 2  (since white is in box  g-1 , and box numbers start at 1).  

So possible green positions: 2 or 3.  

Step 6 – Check white ball positions  
We have 2 white balls.  
One white is in box  g-1 .  
The other white can be anywhere else, but not above green? Wait, whites can be above green? Yes, condition 2 only restricts reds to be above green, whites can be anywhere.  

But careful: If a white is above green, that’s fine. But all reds are above green, so above green we have only reds and possibly whites.  

Actually, let’s test possible  g :  

Case  g = 2 : white in box 1, green in box 2, reds in boxes 3, 4, 5, 6? But that’s 4 reds, not possible (we need exactly 3 reds because green=1, white=2, total=6). So reds = 3. So if g=2, reds must be in 3 of the boxes {3,4,5,6}. The remaining box in {3,4,5,6} is white (the 2nd white). That works.  

Case  g = 3 : white in box 2, green in box 3, reds in boxes 4,5,6 (3 reds), the other white must be in box 1. That works: W in 1,2; G in 3; R in 4,5,6. Check condition 2: green in 3, lowest red in 4 (3<4) ✓. Condition 3: white in 2, green in 3 ✓.  

So green can only be in 2 or 3.  

Step 7 – Matching options  
Options for green: A) box 1 — impossible because then no white below green (box 0 doesn’t exist).  
B) box 3 — possible (we saw).  
C) box 4 — impossible (not enough boxes above for 3 reds).  
D) box 5 — impossible.  
E) box 6 — impossible.  

So only B) box 3 is possible from the options.  

Step 8 – Double-check box 2 possibility  
Is box 2 an option? It’s not listed. Options are 1,3,4,5,6. So possible green positions from our reasoning: 2 or 3, but 2 not in options, so only 3.  

Thus answer: B.  

The correct option is: B

context: A street entertainer has six boxes stacked one on top of the other and numbered consecutively 1 through 6, from the lowest box up to the highest. 2. Given additional condition for this problem  
Green balls in boxes 5 and 6.  
So  G_{\text{low}} = 5  (lowest green ball is in box 5).  

From condition “green ball lower than any red ball”:  
 5 < R_{\text{low}}  ⇒ The lowest red ball must be in box 6 or impossible? Wait, boxes go 1 to 6, 6 is top.  
If  R_{\text{low}} > 5 , then  R_{\text{low}}  could only be 6.  
So all red balls are in box 6 only? That would mean only 1 red ball.  

But check:  G_{\text{low}} = 5 , so  R_{\text{low}}  must be > 5 ⇒  R_{\text{low}} = 6 .  
So all red balls are in box 6 (since box 6 is the only box above box 5).  

3. Implication for number of red vs white balls  
If all red balls are in box 6, then  R = 1  (only one red ball possible, since only one ball per box).  

Condition  R > W  ⇒  1 > W  ⇒  W = 0 .  

But that contradicts the last condition: “There is a white ball in a box immediately below a box containing a green ball.”  
Because  W = 0  means no white ball exists.  

4. Contradiction?  
We have a contradiction unless my interpretation is wrong. Let’s check:  
Lowest green ball is in box 5.  
Lowest red ball’s box number must be greater than 5 ⇒ only box 6 qualifies.  
So red balls only in box 6.  
Then  R = 1 .  
Then  W < 1  ⇒  W = 0 .  
But then “white ball below a green ball” impossible.  

So the only resolution: maybe “lower” means lower numbered box (closer to ground).  
Yes: “lower in the stack” means smaller box number (box 1 is lowest).  

So  G_{\text{low}} < R_{\text{low}}  means: lowest green box number < lowest red box number.  

Given greens in 5 and 6 ⇒  G_{\text{low}} = 5 .  
So  5 < R_{\text{low}}  ⇒  R_{\text{low}}  could be 6 only.  
So reds only in box 6.  

That leads to  R=1, W=0  ⇒ impossible due to white-below-green condition.  

So maybe greens in 5 and 6, but there could be another green lower than 5? No, given says “If there are green balls in boxes 5 and 6” — doesn’t say only there, but lowest green is at most 5. Could there be a green in box <5? Possibly.

B) Reds in 2 and 4

So no white-below-green possible if B is true. So B impossible.  

C) White in box1  
Then  W \ge 1 .

D) White in box2

context: A street entertainer has six boxes stacked one on top of the other and numbered consecutively 1 through 6, from the lowest box up to the highest. Each box contains a single ball, and each ball is one of three colors—green, red, or white. Onlookers are to guess the color of each ball in each box, given that the following conditions hold: There are more red balls than white balls. There is a box containing a green ball that is lower in the stack than any box that contains a red ball. There is a white ball in a box that is immediately below a box that contains a green ball.
question: The ball in which one of the following boxes must be the same color as at least one of the other balls?
options: A) box 2
B) box 3
C) box 4
D) box 5
E) box 6
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

1. Restating the conditions  
• 6 boxes: 1 (bottom) to 6 (top).  

• 3 colors: G, R, W.  

• (1) More red balls than white balls.  

• (2) There is a box with a green ball that is lower in the stack than any box with a red ball.  

• (3) There is a white ball in a box immediately below a box with a green ball.  

2. Interpreting (2)  
Let’s call the lowest red ball’s position  L_R .  
(2) says: There exists a green ball in a box below  L_R .  
So  L_R  must be at least 2, because the green ball must be below it (and above or equal to box 1).  

But more precisely:  
Let  L_R  = lowest box number containing R.  
(2) says: there exists some box with G such that its number <  L_R .  
So  L_R  > 1, because if  L_R = 1 , no box is lower than 1.  
Thus  L_R  ≥ 2, and there is a G in some box numbered less than  L_R .  

3. Interpreting (3)  
(3) says: There exists a white ball in a box immediately below a box with a green ball.  
So there is some  k  (2 ≤ k ≤ 6) such that box  k  has G, box  k-1  has W.  

4. Combining (2) and (3)  
From (3): There is a G in some box  k  and box  k-1  has W.  
From (2): There is a G in a box below  L_R .  

Could the G in (3) be the same as the G in (2)? Possibly yes, but not necessarily.  

Let’s check:  
Let’s call the G from (2)  G_1  (lowest G below  L_R ).  
Let’s call the G from (3)  G_2  (has W in box below).  

We know  G_1  <  L_R .  
We know  G_2  has W in box  G_2 - 1 .  

Also,  L_R  is the first R. All R’s are above  G_1 .  

5. Trying to place constraints on colors  
Let’s test possible  L_R  values:  

If  L_R = 2 : Then  G_1  must be in box 1. So box 1 = G.  
From (3): there is a W below a G. That could be: G in box 2, W in box 1? But box 1 is already G, so no.  
G in box 3, W in box 2: possible. So maybe  G_2  = 3, W in box 2.  

Check:  L_R = 2  means box 2 = R, but then G in box 3, W in box 2? That violates W below G (box 2 would be R, not W). So that doesn’t work.  

So G in box 3, W in box 2 is impossible if box 2 = R. So  L_R = 2  seems problematic:  
Because  L_R = 2  → box 2 = R, so box 2 cannot be W for the (3) condition.  
We need a W below a G. If  L_R = 2 , G_1 is box 1 = G. Then W must be below some G: The only G below  L_R  is box 1, but no box below box 1. So G_1 cannot be G_2 because no box below box 1. So G_2 must be a different G above  L_R . But if  L_R = 2 , then any G above  L_R  is in boxes 3–6. Then W in box below that G: e.g., G in box 3, W in box 2. But box 2 = R, contradiction. So  L_R = 2  impossible.  

So  L_R  ≥ 3.  

6. Try  L_R = 3   
Then G_1 < 3, so G_1 in box 1 or 2.  

From (3): G_2 with W in box below. G_2 could be above  L_R  or equal to  L_R ?  
If G_2 =  L_R  = 3, then W in box 2. That’s possible: box 2 = W, box 3 = G, box 1 = G or R? Wait, box 1 must be G_1 if G_1 in box 1. Let’s test:  

Case: G_1 in box 1, G_2 in box 3, W in box 2. Then  L_R = 3  means first R in box 3? But box 3 = G, so first R in box 4 or higher. Then more R than W.  

Possible arrangement:  
Box 1: G  
Box 2: W  
Box 3: G  
Box 4: R  
Box 5: R  
Box 6: R  
Reds = 3, Whites = 1, Greens = 2. Works:  
(2) G in box 1 <  L_R = 4  (first R in box 4). Wait,  L_R = 4  here, not 3. So if  L_R = 4 , then G_1 in box 1,2,or3. That’s fine.  

So maybe  L_R  = 4 possible. Let’s keep open.  

But I must check systematically:  

7. Let’s find possible  L_R  and constraints  

From (2): G_1 <  L_R .  
From (3): G_2 with W in G_2 - 1.  

Also G_2 - 1 < G_2 ≤ 6.  

If G_2 <  L_R , then W in G_2 - 1 <  L_R , so that W is below first R, so all below first R are not R, so that’s fine.  

If G_2 ≥  L_R , then W in G_2 - 1 ≥  L_R - 1 . If G_2 =  L_R , then W in  L_R - 1 , but  L_R - 1  <  L_R , so W is below first R, so that’s fine. If G_2 >  L_R , then W in G_2 - 1 ≥  L_R , so W could be above or equal to first R.  

No direct contradiction.  

8. What’s forced?  

We need: “The ball in which box must be the same color as at least one of the other balls?” Means: that box cannot be a unique color among all 6 boxes.  

So if only one ball of a certain color exists, that box cannot be that color.  

Given more R than W, and total 6 balls, possible color counts:  
R > W, R + W + G = 6. Minimal W = 1, then R ≥ 2. If W=1, R=2, G=3. If W=2, R=3, G=1. If W=1, R=4, G=1. If W=2, R=3, G=1. If W=1, R=3, G=2.  

So possible (G,R,W) distributions: (3,2,1), (2,3,1), (1,4,1), (1,3,2), (2,4,0) not allowed (W=0 not allowed since W exists by (3)), (3,3,0) not allowed.  

So W ≥ 1, G ≥ 1, R ≥ 2.  

Thus there is at least 2 R’s, at least 1 G, at least 1 W.  

9. Which box cannot have a unique color?  

If a color appears only once in all 6 boxes, that box cannot be that color.  

Possible solo colors?  
• G can be 1 (if R=4,W=1 or R=3,W=2).  

• W can be 1 (if R=3,G=2 or R=4,G=1 or R=2,G=3).  

• R cannot be 1 because R>W and W≥1 ⇒ R≥2.  

So possible unique-color balls: unique G or unique W.  

So any box that could be the unique G or unique W is not forced to share color.  

But the question: which box MUST be same color as another ball ⇒ that box cannot be the unique G or unique W in any valid arrangement. So we must check if there’s a box that in every valid arrangement is not the unique G and not the unique W.  

10. Apply (2) and (3) to find forced positions  

From (3): There is a white ball in a box immediately below a box with a green ball. Call that white ball position  p_W  and green above it  p_W+1 .  

From (2): There is a green ball below the lowest red.  

Let’s denote lowest red = LR.  

We can test small cases:  

Case 1: W=1, G=3, R=2.  
Then the unique W is the W from (3). That W is below a G. That W’s position is fixed? Not exactly, but it’s the only W. So that W’s box is the unique white. So that box can be the solo white. So that box is not forced to share color.  

So maybe the box that is the W in (3) could be unique. But is there a box that can never be the unique W?  

Similarly, unique G: if G=1, that G must be below LR (from (2)), and also there must be another G above to satisfy (3)? Wait, can the unique G satisfy both (2) and (3)?  

(3) requires a G with W below it. If G is unique, then that G is the same G as in (2)? Possibly. Example:  
Boxes: 1: W, 2: G, 3: R, 4: R, 5: R, 6: R.  
Check: G=1 (only box 2), W=1 (box 1).  
(2): G in box 2 < LR=3? Yes.  
(3): W in box 1 below G in box 2. Works.  
So unique G in box 2 possible. So box 2 could be unique G.  

So many boxes could be unique colors in some arrangement.  

11. Narrow down by position constraints  

We need a box that is never the only ball of its color in any valid arrangement.  

Consider box 3:  

If box 3 were the only W: then W=1, box 3=W. Then (3) says a W below a G ⇒ box 3 is below a G ⇒ box 4=G. Then (2) says a G below LR. If box 4=G, then LR>4 ⇒ LR=5 or 6. Then Reds in 5,6 only? But R>W=1 ⇒ R≥2, so possible: 5=R,6=R. Then G=… We already have G in box 4, maybe others? Need G count. Possible. So box 3 as unique W possible. So box 3 can be unique W.  

Similarly box 3 as unique G: Try G=1 in box 3. Then (3) requires a W below a G ⇒ W in box 2, G in box 3. (2) requires a G below LR ⇒ box 3 < LR ⇒ LR≥4. Works. So box 3 can be unique G.  

So box 3 can be solo color. So maybe not forced.  

12. Try extreme: box 1  

Box 1 as unique W: W=1 in box 1. Then (3): W below a G ⇒ G in box 2. Then (2): a G below LR ⇒ box 2 < LR ⇒ LR≥3. Works. So box 1 can be unique W.  

Box 1 as unique G: G=1 in box 1. Then (3): W below a G ⇒ no box below box 1 ⇒ impossible. So box 1 cannot be unique G!  

So in every valid arrangement, box 1 is not the unique G.  

Could box 1 be unique W? Yes, as above. So box 1 could be the only white. So box 1 is not forced to share color with another.  

13. Try box 6  

Box 6 as unique W: W=1 in box 6. Then (3): W below a G ⇒ G in box 7 impossible. So no. So box 6 cannot be unique W.  

Box 6 as unique G: G=1 in box 6. Then (2): a G below LR ⇒ box 6 < LR impossible. So box 6 cannot be unique G.  

So box 6 cannot be a unique color in any arrangement! Therefore box 6 must share its color with at least one other ball.  

That matches the question: “must be the same color as at least one of the other balls” = not unique colored.  

So answer: box 6.  

14. Check options  

Options: 2,3,4,5,6. Only box 6 is impossible to be unique color.  

The correct option is: E

question: Which one of the following must be true?
options: A) There is a green ball in a box that is lower than box 4.
B) There is a green ball in a box that is higher than box 4.
C) There is a red ball in a box that is lower than box 4.
D) There is a red ball in a box that is higher than box 4.
E) There is a white ball in a box that is lower than box 4.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break it down step by step.  

Step 1: Restating the conditions  
• 6 boxes: 1 (lowest) to 6 (highest).  

• Colors: G, R, W.  

• More red balls than white balls:  R > W .  

• There is a box containing a green ball that is lower in the stack than any box containing a red ball.  

  → Let’s call the lowest red ball’s position  L_R . Then there is some green ball in a box  < L_R .  
• There is a white ball in a box that is immediately below a box containing a green ball.  

  → Somewhere:  W  in box  k ,  G  in box  k+1 .  

Step 2: Implications of the red/green condition  
Let  L_R  = lowest red ball’s box number.  
Condition says: some green ball in a box  < L_R .  
So  L_R  cannot be box 1 (because then no box lower than it).  
So  L_R \ge 2 .  
Also, there exists at least one G below  L_R .  

Step 3: Implications of the white-below-green condition  
There is a white ball in box  k , green in box  k+1 .  
So there is at least one green ball that is not in the lowest box (since  k+1 \ge 2 ).  

Step 4: Possible arrangement constraints  
We know:  
•  R > W  → since total 6 balls,  R+W+G=6 ,  R>W .  

Possible (R,W) pairs: (3,2), (4,1), (5,0) but W=0 would violate white-below-green condition (since there must be at least one W). So W≥1.  
Also R≥3 (since R>W and W≥1).  

Step 5: Try minimal R=3, W=2, G=1  
G=1: But then the condition “there is a green ball lower than any red ball” means that G must be below all reds.  
Also “white immediately below a green” means W in k, G in k+1. But if G=1, then k+1=G’s position, so k=G’s position -1 = impossible if G=1 (k=0, no box 0). So G≥2.  

So G≥2, R≥3, W≥1, R>W.  

Step 6: Try G=2, R=3, W=1  
We need:  
• A G below all reds → so the lowest red box > some G’s box.  

• A white immediately below a green.  

Let’s test if we can avoid each option being “must be true”.  

Step 7: Testing option A: “There is a green ball in a box lower than box 4”  
Could all greens be in box 4 or higher?  
No: because there is a G below all reds. If all reds are in boxes 4,5,6, then G below them means G in box ≤3.  
Could reds be in boxes 2–6? Then lowest red is box 2, so G below that → G in box 1. So yes, G in box 1 (lower than 4).  
Could reds be in boxes 3–6? Then lowest red is box 3, so G below that → G in box 1 or 2 (both <4).  
Could reds be in boxes 1–6? No, because then lowest red is box 1, impossible (no box below 1 for G). So lowest red ≥2.  
Could lowest red be box 4? Then G below 4 → G in box 1,2,3 (all <4).  
So in all valid scenarios, there is a G < box 4.  

Step 8: Testing if we can avoid others being must-be-true  
B: Green higher than box 4 — not necessary; counterexample: G in 1 and 3, no G above 4 possible? But we need 2 greens (G≥2) and white-below-green: W in k, G in k+1. If G=2, one G low, one G maybe high. But maybe both G’s could be low. Let’s check:  
Example: Box1: G, Box2: W, Box3: G, Box4: R, Box5: R, Box6: R.  
Check: R>W? R=3, W=1, yes.  
G lower than any red? Lowest red=4, G in 1 and 3, yes.  
W below a G? W in 2, G in 3, yes.  
So here: no G above 4. So B is not necessary.  

C: Red lower than box 4 — not necessary: in above example, reds in 4,5,6, so no red <4. So C not necessary.  

D: Red higher than box 4 — not necessary: counterexample: reds in 2,3,4 (lowest red=2, G in 1 below it; W in 5 impossible? Let’s construct: Box1: G, Box2: R, Box3: R, Box4: R, Box5: W, Box6: G.  
Check: W below G? W in 5, G in 6, yes. G lower than any red? Lowest red=2, G in 1, yes. R>W? R=3, W=1, yes.  
Here: reds in 2,3,4 — no red >4. So D not necessary.  

E: White lower than box 4 — not necessary: in earlier example (Box1: G, Box2: W, Box3: G, Box4: R, Box5: R, Box6: R), W=2 (<4). But can W be ≥4? Try: W in 5, G in 6, and another G low: Box1: G, Box2: R, Box3: R, Box4: R, Box5: W, Box6: G.  
Check: W below G? Yes (5 below 6). G lower than any red? Lowest red=2, G in 1, yes. R=3, W=1, R>W.  
Here W=5 (>4), so E is false.  

Step 9: Conclusion  
Only A must be true: there is always a green ball lower than box 4.  

The correct option is: A

reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.

1. Understanding the constraints

• 6 boxes, numbered 1 (bottom) to 6 (top).

• Conditions:

  1. More red balls than white balls. So  R > W .

4. Try possibilities for condition 3

We know Box 1 is G, so  k  could be 0? No, k=0 not valid. So Box 1 being G means: if k=1, then k+1=2 must be G, but Box 2 is R (given). So not possible.

Let’s list all greens: Box 1 is G. Are there others? Possibly.  

Condition 3: There exists some  k  such that Box  k  = W, Box  k+1  = G.

So the green above white must be a green in boxes 2–6, but Box 2 = R, Box 3 = R, so greens could be in Box 4, 5, or 6.

• If Box 4 = G → Box 3 = W? But Box 3 = R (given). So no.  

• If Box 5 = G → Box 4 = W possible.  

• If Box 6 = G → Box 5 = W possible.

So condition 3 satisfied if Box 4 = W and Box 5 = G, or Box 5 = W and Box 6 = G.

5. Condition 1: More red than white

We already have at least 2 reds (Box 2, Box 3).  
Possible other reds? Let’s check options.

We know Box 1 = G.  

Let’s test options:

A) Red in Box 1 → Impossible because Box 1 = G.

B) White in Box 1 → Impossible because Box 1 = G.

C) Green in Box 4 → Possible? If Box 4 = G, then to satisfy condition 3: need W below G: only possibility is Box 3 = W, but Box 3 = R (given). So condition 3 not satisfied if Box 4 = G (unless another G above some W elsewhere). Wait, we could have Box 5 or Box 6 = G to satisfy condition 3. Yes, Box 4 = G doesn’t prevent Box 5 or Box 6 = G to satisfy condition 3. So Box 4 = G possible. But check R > W: if Box 4 = G, Box 2,3 = R, so 2 reds so far. Need R > W. Let’s test minimal W: If condition 3: say Box 5 = G, Box 4 = W? But Box 4 = G (assumed for C), so Box 4 = G not W. So W must be Box 4 if Box 5 = G? No, Box 4 = G. So the only possible W below G: Box 5 = G → Box 4 = W? But Box 4 = G → impossible. So Box 5 = G impossible here. Box 6 = G → Box 5 = W possible. So possible arrangement: Box 1 = G, Box 4 = G, Box 6 = G, Box 5 = W, Box 2,3 = R. Colors: G, R, R, G, W, G.  
R count = 2 (Box 2,3), W count = 1 (Box 5). R > W? 2 > 1, yes. Condition 3: Box 5 = W, Box 6 = G, satisfied. Condition 2: Box 1 = G < Box 2 = R, satisfied. All conditions met. So C is possible.

D) Red in Box 5 → Let’s test: Box 1 = G, Box 2,3,5 = R. That’s 3 reds. Condition 3: need W below G: possibilities: Box 5 = R, so not G above W? Box 6 = G possible: then Box 5 = W? But Box 5 = R, so no. Box 4 = G possible: then Box 3 = W? But Box 3 = R, so no. So only way: Box 6 = G → Box 5 = W? But Box 5 = R. So no W below G. So condition 3 fails. So D impossible.

E) White in Box 6 → Let’s test: Box 1 = G, Box 2,3 = R, Box 6 = W.  
R=2, W=1 so far. Condition 3: need W below G: only candidate: Box 6 = W, Box 7 nonexistent, so no. Other possibility: Box 5 = G → Box 4 = W. That works: Box 4 = W, Box 5 = G. Then colors: Box 1 = G, Box 2 = R, Box 3 = R, Box 4 = W, Box 5 = G, Box 6 = W.  
R=2, W=2 → violates R > W. So fails. Try Box 4 = G → Box 3 = W? But Box 3 = R. So fails. So no way to satisfy condition 3 without breaking R>W or given constraints. So E impossible.

6. Conclusion

Only C is possible.

The correct option is: C

context: A street entertainer has six boxes stacked one on top of the other and numbered consecutively 1 through 6, from the lowest box up to the highest.
