context: A television programming director is scheduling a three-hour block of programs beginning at 1 P.M. The programs that are to fill this time block include an hour-long program called Generations and four half-hour programs: Roamin', Sundown, Terry, and Waterloo. The programs will be shown one after the other, each program shown exactly once. The schedule must meet the following constraints: Generations starts on the hour rather than the half hour. Terry starts on the half hour rather than the hour. Roamin' is shown earlier than Sundown. If Waterloo is shown earlier than Terry, it is shown immediately before Terry.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the constraint that Generations starts on the hour rather than the half hour, would have the same effect in determining the order in which the programs are shown?
options: A) Generations is not shown immediately before Terry.
B) Generations is either the first program or the fifth.
C) Generations is neither the second program nor the fourth.
D) If Generations is shown third, then Roamin' is shown first.
E) If Generations is not shown first, then it is shown later than Terry.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Original constraints:
1. Three-hour block: 1:00 PM to 4:00 PM.  
   • 1 program: Generations (1 hour)  

   • 4 programs: Roamin', Sundown, Terry, Waterloo (each 0.5 hour)  

   • Total: 1 + 4 × 0.5 = 3 hours.  

   • 5 programs in total, but 1 is 1 hour, 4 are 0.5 hour → total slots: 6 half-hour slots.  

2. Generations starts on the hour rather than half hour → occupies two consecutive half-hour slots starting on an hour.  
   • Possible start times: 1:00, 2:00, 3:00 (since 4:00 is end, can’t start then).  

   • So G’s possible half-hour slots: (1,2) or (3,4) or (5,6) if we number slots 1 to 6 starting 1:00.  

3. Terry starts on the half hour rather than the hour → occupies two consecutive half-hour slots starting on a half hour.  
   • Possible start times: 1:30, 2:30, 3:30.  

   • So T’s possible half-hour slots: (2,3) or (4,5) or (6,7) but 6,7 impossible because slot 6 ends at 4:00, so 3:30 start = slots (6,7) not possible (only 6 slots). Wait — correction: slots: 1=1:00-1:30, 2=1:30-2:00, 3=2:00-2:30, 4=2:30-3:00, 5=3:00-3:30, 6=3:30-4:00.  

   • Half-hour start means Terry starts in slots 2, 4, or 6. But Terry is 0.5 hours, so occupies 1 slot, not 2 slots? No — each program is 0.5 hours except Generations (1 hour). So Terry occupies exactly 1 slot.  

   • Wait, I see the confusion: Generations is 1 hour = 2 half-hour slots. The other four are each 0.5 hour = 1 half-hour slot. That’s 2 + 1 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 6 half-hour slots.  

   So:  
   • Generations: 2 consecutive half-hour slots starting on an hour boundary → slots (1,2) or (3,4) or (5,6).  

   • Terry: starts on half hour: possible start slots: 2, 4, 6.  

4. Roamin' earlier than Sundown (each 0.5 hour).  

5. If Waterloo earlier than Terry, it is shown immediately before Terry.  

Effect of “Generations starts on the hour”:  
It means G cannot start in slots 2, 4, or 6.  
So G’s possible start slots: 1, 3, or 5.  

But G is 1 hour, so:  
• Start slot 1 → occupies 1,2  

• Start slot 3 → occupies 3,4  

• Start slot 5 → occupies 5,6  

So G’s possible occupied slot pairs: (1,2), (3,4), (5,6).  

Implication: G’s start time is either 1:00, 2:00, or 3:00.  

Now, Terry’s constraint: Terry starts on half hour: possible start slots: 2, 4, 6.  

So G and T cannot overlap in start times, but more importantly, G’s placement blocks certain slots for T.  

Let’s test possible G positions:  

• G in (1,2): then slot 2 is occupied, so Terry can’t start at 1:30 (slot 2). Terry’s possible: slot 4 or 6.  

• G in (3,4): then slot 4 occupied, Terry possible: slot 2 or 6.  

• G in (5,6): then slot 6 occupied, Terry possible: slot 2 or 4.  

So G’s constraint removes one of Terry’s possible starts depending on G’s position.  

We need a new constraint that has same effect as G’s hour-start constraint.  
Equivalent: G’s start slot is odd (1, 3, or 5).  

So G’s slot number (first half-hour slot it occupies) is odd.  

Check options:  

A) G not immediately before Terry.  
• “Immediately before” in half-hour programs? They’re in a sequence of 5 programs, not slots. But in time slots, “immediately before Terry” means the slot before Terry’s start slot.  

• This is not same as G starting on the hour. Could be many cases. So not equivalent.  

B) G is either first program or fifth.  
• First program = starts at 1:00 (slot 1) → ok.  

• Fifth program: in 5 programs, fifth starts after 4 others: total time before it = 4×0.5? No: G is 1 hour, so ordering by programs:  

  Let’s list programs in order: G, R, S, T, W (just example).  
  Actually, fifth program means last program: start time = after 4 others: total duration before it:  
  The 4 others = 4 half-hours = 2 hours. So fifth program starts at 3:00 (slot 5) → yes, that’s an hour start.  
  So B says: G starts at 1:00 or 3:00. But original also allows 2:00 start (slots 3,4). So B forbids G starting at 2:00, which original allows. So B is not equivalent.  

C) G is neither second program nor fourth.  
• Second program: starts after 1st program (0.5 hour later) → start time 1:30 (slot 2) → not allowed in original. So forbidding 2nd program forbids slot 2 start, good.  

• Fourth program: starts after 3 programs: total duration before = 3 half-hours = 1.5 hours → start time 2:30 (slot 4) → not allowed in original. Good.  

• So forbidding 2nd and 4th program means G’s start slot ≠ 2 and ≠ 4. Also start slot 6? Could G be 6th program? Impossible, only 5 programs. So programs numbered 1 to 5. G can be 1st, 3rd, or 5th program.  

Check:  
• 1st program: start slot 1 (ok)  

• 3rd program: starts after 2 programs = 1 hour → start time 2:00 (slot 3) (ok)  

• 5th program: starts after 4 programs = 2 hours → start time 3:00 (slot 5) (ok)  

So C says: G is 1st, 3rd, or 5th program. That’s exactly = G starts on the hour (slots 1, 3, or 5).  

So C is equivalent.  

D) If G third then R first. That’s not equivalent; it’s a conditional, not restricting G’s position to hour starts in all cases.  

E) If G not first, then it is later than Terry. That’s not equivalent to G starting on the hour.  

So C is correct.  

The correct option is: C

context: Five students—Manolo, Nadia, Owen, Peng, and Rana—are each to deliver exactly one speech. Speeches are on exactly one of two topics—friendship and liberty. Each student has only one major: two major in geology, two in history, and one in journalism. The following conditions must apply: Exactly two of the students speak on friendship. A geology major and a history major speak on friendship. Manolo speaks on friendship. Rana speaks on liberty. Neither Peng nor Rana is a geology major. Nadia is a geology major.
question: Which one of the following could be a list of the majors of Manolo, Nadia, Owen, Peng, and Rana, respectively?
options: A) geology, geology, journalism, journalism, history
B) geology, geology, history, history, history
C) history, geology, geology, journalism, history
D) history, geology, journalism, geology, history
E) history, history, geology, journalism, history
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

Step 1 – List fixed facts from the problem  
• Students: Manolo (M), Nadia (N), Owen (O), Peng (P), Rana (R)  

• Topics: Friendship (F) or Liberty (L)  

• Majors: Geology (G) = 2, History (H) = 2, Journalism (J) = 1  

• Exactly 2 speak on Friendship.  

• 1 G and 1 H speak on Friendship.  

• M speaks on F.  

• R speaks on L.  

• Neither P nor R is G.  

• N is G.  

Step 2 – Assign topics  
M = F.  
R = L.  
So the other 3 (N, O, P) must be distributed between F and L.  
But exactly 2 F total → only 1 more F among N, O, P.  
Exactly 1 G and 1 H speak on F. M is already F, so M’s major must be either G or H.  

Step 3 – Use “1 G and 1 H speak on F”  
Case 1: M is G → then the other F must be H (O or P or N).  
Case 2: M is H → then the other F must be G (but N is G, so N could be F).  

Step 4 – Use constraints on G and H counts  
G: N is G. P not G, R not G → G’s are N and one of M or O.  
H: 2 total.  

Step 5 – Try to match options  

Option A: M=G, N=G, O=J, P=J, R=H  
Check: G’s: M, N (ok, 2 G’s). H’s: R=H, need one more H → but P=J, O=J, so only 1 H → wrong. Discard A.  

Option B: M=G, N=G, O=H, P=H, R=H  
G’s: M, N (ok). H’s: O, P, R (3 H’s) → wrong, should be 2 H’s. Discard B.  

Option C: M=H, N=G, O=G, P=J, R=H  
G’s: N, O (ok). H’s: M, R (ok). J: P (ok).  
Now check topic constraints: M=F (H), so other F must be G (N or O).  
N=G could be F, O=G could be F. But R=L fixed. P unknown topic.  
Exactly 2 F: M and one G. Possible: N=G=F, O=G=L, P=J=L, R=H=L → works: F: M(H), N(G) → satisfies 1 G & 1 H on F.  
So C is possible.  

Option D: M=H, N=G, O=J, P=G, R=H  
But P not G (contradicts P=G in D) → violates “Neither P nor R is G”. Discard D.  

Option E: M=H, N=H, O=G, P=J, R=H  
But N is G (given) → contradicts N=H. Discard E.  

Only C remains consistent with all constraints.  

Step 6 – Verify C fully  
Majors: M=H, N=G, O=G, P=J, R=H.  
G’s: N, O (ok). H’s: M, R (ok). J: P (ok).  
Topics: M=F (H), need 1 G on F: choose N=G=F. Then O=G=L, P=J=L, R=H=L.  
Exactly 2 F: M, N.  
1 G (N) and 1 H (M) on F.  
P not G (ok), R not G (ok), N is G (ok).  

All conditions satisfied.  

Final answer:  
The correct option is: C

context: Five students—Manolo, Nadia, Owen, Peng, and Rana—are each to deliver exactly one speech. Speeches are on exactly one of two topics—friendship and liberty. Each student has only one major: two major in geology, two in history, and one in journalism. The following conditions must apply: Exactly two of the students speak on friendship. A geology major and a history major speak on friendship. Manolo speaks on friendship. Rana speaks on liberty. Neither Peng nor Rana is a geology major. Nadia is a geology major.
question: If Peng speaks on friendship, then which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Manolo is a history major.
B) Nadia speaks on friendship.
C) Owen speaks on friendship.
D) Owen is a journalism major.
E) Peng is a journalism major.
reasoning_cot:
Let's go step by step.  

Step 1: Known constraints from the context  

• 5 students: Manolo (M), Nadia (N), Owen (O), Peng (P), Rana (R)  

• Topics: Friendship (F) or Liberty (L)  

• Majors: Geology (G) – 2 students, History (H) – 2 students, Journalism (J) – 1 student  

Rules:  
1. Exactly 2 students speak on F.  
2. One G major and one H major speak on F.  
3. M speaks on F.  
4. R speaks on L.  
5. Neither P nor R is G major.  
6. N is a G major.  

Step 2: Major assignments possible  

From rules 5 & 6:  
• G majors: N is one G major. One more G major exists.  

• P and R are not G, so G majors are N and one of {M, O}.  

• H majors: 2 students.  

• J major: 1 student.  

Possible G majors: N + (M or O).  

Step 3: Friendship speakers  

From rule 1: Exactly 2 F speakers.  
From rule 2: F speakers = 1 G major + 1 H major.  
From rule 3: M is F speaker.  

So:  
F speakers: M (F) and one other person.  
But F speakers must be 1 G and 1 H.  

Case 1: M is G major → then other F speaker must be H major.  
Case 2: M is H major → then other F speaker must be G major.  

Step 4: Peng speaks on F (given in the question)  

Peng is F speaker. But exactly 2 F speakers total: M and P are the F speakers.  

So F speakers: M and P.  
From rule 2: F speakers = 1 G + 1 H.  

Thus {M, P} = {1 G, 1 H}.  

Step 5: Determine M and P’s majors  

Possibility 1: M is G, P is H.  
Possibility 2: M is H, P is G.  

But P cannot be G (rule 5). So Possibility 2 is impossible.  

Thus: M is G, P is H.

Only B satisfies all constraints.  

The correct option is: B

context: A toy retailer is opening a small satellite store with exactly three aisles, numbered from 1 (lowest) to 3 (highest). question: If aisle 1 contains Hobbies only, which one of the following could be true?

B) Music is located in aisle 2.

D) Reading is located in aisle 3.

reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

Given conditions:
1. Three aisles: 1 (lowest), 2, 3 (highest).  
2. Six sections: F (Fantasy), H (Hobbies), M (Music), P (Puzzles), R (Reading), S (Science).  
3. Each aisle has at least one section.  
4. Reading is in the same aisle as either Fantasy or Music.  
5. Fantasy is in a lower-numbered aisle than both Music and Puzzles:  
   • F < M  

   • F < P  

6. Science is in a lower-numbered aisle than Puzzles: S < P.  
7. Science is NOT in a lower-numbered aisle than Hobbies:  
   • Not S < H → means S ≥ H in aisle numbering (same aisle or S higher).  

Extra constraint for this question:  
Aisle 1 contains Hobbies only → H is alone in aisle 1.  

Step 1 – Place H in aisle 1.  
From condition 7: S ≥ H. Since H is in aisle 1, S cannot be in a lower aisle (none lower), so S is either in aisle 1 or higher. But aisle 1 has only Hobbies, so S cannot be in aisle 1.  
Thus S is in aisle 2 or 3.  

Step 2 – Use S < P.  
Since S is in aisle 2 or 3, P must be higher than S, unless S is in 3 (then no higher aisle), so S cannot be in 3.  
Thus S must be in aisle 2, and P in aisle 3.  

So far:  
Aisle 1: H  
Aisle 2: S  
Aisle 3: P  

Step 3 – Use F < M and F < P.  
F < P (P is in aisle 3) → F can be in aisle 1 or 2.  
F < M → M must be higher than F.  

Step 4 – Remaining sections:  
We’ve placed H, S, P. Remaining: F, M, R.  

Aisle 1: H only. So F cannot be in aisle 1 unless it’s with H? No, aisle 1 has H only, so F cannot be in aisle 1.  

Wait — check: If aisle 1 contains Hobbies only, then F cannot be in aisle 1.  

So F must be in aisle 2 or 3. But F < P and P is in aisle 3 → F must be in aisle 2.  

Thus F in aisle 2.  

Step 5 – F in aisle 2 → F < M → M must be in aisle 3 (since only aisle 3 is higher than aisle 2).  

So M in aisle 3.  

Step 6 – Remaining section R:  
R must be in same aisle as F or M.  
F is in aisle 2, M in aisle 3.  

So R can be in aisle 2 (with F) or aisle 3 (with M).  

Step 7 – Fill aisles:  
Aisle 1: H  
Aisle 2: S, F, and possibly R  
Aisle 3: P, M, and possibly R  

But each aisle must have at least one section. We already have:  
Aisle 2: S, F (and maybe R) → at least 2 sections.  
Aisle 3: P, M (and maybe R) → at least 2 sections.  

We have 6 sections total: H(1), S(2), F(2), P(3), M(3), R(?2 or 3).  

If R in aisle 2 → aisle 2: S, F, R (3 sections), aisle 3: P, M (2 sections) → valid.  
If R in aisle 3 → aisle 2: S, F (2 sections), aisle 3: P, M, R (3 sections) → valid.  

So R is movable between aisle 2 and 3.

A) Fantasy in aisle 3? No, F is fixed in aisle 2.  
B) Music in aisle 2? No, M is fixed in aisle 3.  
C) Puzzles in aisle 2? No, P is fixed in aisle 3.  
D) Reading in aisle 3? Possible if R is in aisle 3 (valid arrangement).  
E) Science in aisle 3? No, S is fixed in aisle 2.  

So only D could be true.  

The correct option is: D

E) Reading is located in aisle 1.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. Understanding the constraints  
• 3 aisles: 1 (lowest) to 3 (highest).  

• 6 sections: F, H, M, P, R, S.  

• Each aisle has at least 1 section.  

• Rules:  

1. R is in same aisle as F or M.  
2. F is in a lower-numbered aisle than both M and P.  
3. S is in a lower-numbered aisle than P.  
4. S is not in a lower-numbered aisle than H.  

2. Extra condition for this question  
Aisle 2 contains Science only → S is alone in aisle 2.  

So:  
Aisle 2: S only.  
Aisle 1: some sections.  
Aisle 3: some sections.  

3. Applying rules with S in aisle 2  

From rule 3: S is lower-numbered than P → P cannot be in aisle 1 or 2 → P must be in aisle 3.  

From rule 2: F is lower than M and P.  
P is in aisle 3, so F lower than P means F cannot be in aisle 3.  
F lower than M means M cannot be in aisle 1 (since F must be lower than M).  

So F must be lower than M and P.  
Possible placements:  
• F in aisle 1, M in aisle 3 (since M cannot be in aisle 1 because F < M, and M cannot be in aisle 2 because S is alone in aisle 2).  

So M must be in aisle 3.  

Thus:  
Aisle 3: M, P, and maybe others.  
Aisle 2: S only.  
Aisle 1: F, and maybe others.  

4. Rule 4: S not lower-numbered than H  
S is in aisle 2. “S not lower than H” means H cannot be in a higher aisle than S? Wait, check:  
“S cannot be located in a lower-numbered aisle than H” means:  
It is not true that S < H in aisle numbering.  
So possible: S = H (same aisle) or S > H (H lower aisle than S) or H > S (H higher than S)? Let’s check:  

“S cannot be located in a lower-numbered aisle than H” means:  
We cannot have S_aisle < H_aisle.  
So either H_aisle ≤ S_aisle.  

S_aisle = 2. So H_aisle ≤ 2.  
So H cannot be in aisle 3.  

Thus H is in aisle 1 or 2.  
But aisle 2 has only S, so H cannot be in aisle 2 (S is alone).  
So H must be in aisle 1.  

5. Remaining sections  
We have: F, H, M, P, R, S.  
So far:  
Aisle 1: F, H, and maybe R.  
Aisle 2: S only.  
Aisle 3: M, P, and maybe R?  

Rule 1: R is in same aisle as F or M.  
If R is with F → R in aisle 1.  
If R is with M → R in aisle 3.  

So R can be in aisle 1 or 3.  

6. Filling aisles  
Aisle 1: F, H, (R possibly)  
Aisle 2: S  
Aisle 3: M, P, (R possibly)  

Each aisle at least 1 section: already satisfied.  

We have 6 sections:  
Case 1: R in aisle 1 → A1: F, H, R (3 sections), A2: S (1), A3: M, P (2) → total 6.  
Case 2: R in aisle 3 → A1: F, H (2 sections), A2: S (1), A3: M, P, R (3) → total 6.  

Both valid.  

7. What must be true?  
From above:  
• F in aisle 1 (must be true) → Option A must be true.  

• H in aisle 1 (must be true) → Option B must be true.  

• M in aisle 3 (must be true) → Option C must be true.  

• P in aisle 3 (must be true) → Option D must be true.  

• R in aisle 1? Not necessarily; R could be in aisle 3. So E is not necessarily true.  

Thus the EXCEPT question: Which must be true? All except E.  

8. Conclusion  

The correct option is: E

context: Millville has created three new development zones: Z1, Z2, and Z3. Within these zones, subzones can be designated for housing, industrial, or retail use, with no subzone designated for more than one use. By city regulation, a total of no more than three subzones can be designated for each of the three uses. The following restrictions are in place: Retail subzones are not allowed in Z1. No more than two subzones for housing are allowed in any particular zone. No more than one retail subzone is allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing. Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing or three subzones are designated for retail use.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable way of designating subzones within the three zones?
options: A) Z1: no designated subzones Z2: one housing subzone, two retail subzones Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
B) Z1: one housing subzone, one industrial subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
C) Z1: one housing subzone, one retail subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, one retail subzone
D) Z1: one industrial subzone Z2: three housing subzones Z3: three retail subzones
E) Z1: one industrial subzone Z2: two housing subzones, one retail subzone Z3: one industrial subzone, two retail subzones
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each option against the rules.

Rules summary:
1. No more than 3 subzones total for each use across all zones.  
2. Retail subzones not allowed in Z1.  
3. No more than 2 housing subzones in any one zone.  
4. No more than 1 retail subzone in any zone that has housing.  
5. Industrial subzones not allowed in any zone that has housing or in which 3 subzones are designated for retail use. (The wording: “Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing or three subzones are designated for retail use.” Means: If a zone has housing, or if a zone has 3 retail subzones, then industrial subzones are not allowed in that zone.)

Option A:  
Z1: none — OK (retail not in Z1: OK)  
Z2: 1 housing, 2 retail — Check: 2 retail in a zone with housing → violates rule 4 (only 1 retail allowed if housing exists).  
→ Not allowed.

Option B:  
Z1: 1 housing, 1 industrial — Check: Industrial in a zone with housing → violates rule 5.  
→ Not allowed.

Option C:  
Z1: 1 housing, 1 retail — Check: Retail not allowed in Z1 (rule 2).  
→ Not allowed.

Option D:  
Z1: 1 industrial — OK (no housing, not 3 retail)  
Z2: 3 housing — Check: rule 3 says no more than 2 housing in any zone → violates.  
→ Not allowed.

Option E:  
Z1: 1 industrial — OK (no housing, not 3 retail)  
Z2: 2 housing, 1 retail — Check: housing ≤ 2? Yes. Retail ≤ 1 in a zone with housing? Yes (1 retail). Industrial not in this zone, so OK.  
Z3: 1 industrial, 2 retail — Check: Z3 has no housing, doesn’t have 3 retail subzones (has 2 retail), so industrial allowed.  
Totals: Housing = 2 (Z2 only) ≤ 3 OK; Retail = 1 (Z2) + 2 (Z3) = 3 ≤ 3 OK; Industrial = 1 (Z1) + 1 (Z3) = 2 ≤ 3 OK.  
No rule violations.  

→ Allowed.

The correct option is: E

context: Millville has created three new development zones: Z1, Z2, and Z3. question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true within a single zone?
options: A) Two subzones are designated, one housing and one retail.
B) Two subzones are designated, one industrial and one retail.
C) Three subzones are designated, all of them retail.
D) Four subzones are designated, none of them industrial.
E) Four subzones are designated, two retail and two industrial.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each option against the rules.

Rules summary:
1. No more than 3 subzones total for each use (housing, industrial, retail) across all zones.
2. Retail not allowed in Z1.
3. No more than 2 housing subzones in any zone.
4. No more than 1 retail subzone in any zone that has housing.
5. Industrial not allowed in any zone that has housing or that has 3 retail subzones.

Option A: Two subzones: 1 housing, 1 retail.  
• Check rule 4: only 1 retail in a zone with housing → OK.  

• Check rule 5: industrial not present, so no conflict.  

Possible.

Option B: Two subzones: 1 industrial, 1 retail.  
• No housing, not 3 retail → rule 5 doesn’t forbid industrial here.  

Possible.

Option C: Three subzones: all retail.  
• Rule 5: industrial not allowed in a zone with 3 retail subzones — but here there’s no industrial, so fine.  

Possible.

Option D: Four subzones: none industrial.  
• That means all 4 are housing or retail.  

• Rule 3: max 2 housing per zone. So at most 2 housing, at least 2 retail.  

• Rule 4: if housing present, max 1 retail per zone. So if housing present, can’t have 2 retail.  

• If no housing, then all 4 are retail? But 4 retail total in a zone is impossible because rule 1 says max 3 retail subzones total across all zones, not per zone? Wait — careful: rule 1 says “a total of no more than three subzones can be designated for each of the three uses” — that’s across all zones, not per zone. So in one zone, you could have 3 retail, but not 4 retail (since only 3 retail total in all zones, so 4 retail in one zone would exceed total).  

• But here: 4 subzones, none industrial → possible combos: (2 housing, 2 retail) or (1 housing, 3 retail) or (0 housing, 4 retail) or (2 housing, 2 retail) etc.  

• Check totals: 4 retail in one zone impossible because total retail subzones citywide ≤ 3. So 4 retail in one zone is impossible.  

• Check 2 housing, 2 retail: rule 4: housing present → max 1 retail per zone → so 2 retail not allowed. So impossible.  

• Check 1 housing, 3 retail: rule 4: housing present → max 1 retail per zone → so 3 retail not allowed.  

• Check 0 housing, 4 retail: violates total retail limit (citywide max 3 retail).  

So any 4-subzone, none industrial arrangement is impossible because:  
• If housing present → retail ≤ 1 → total subzones ≤ housing (max 2) + retail (1) = 3 subzones max. So 4 subzones impossible with housing.  

• If no housing → all 4 must be retail (since none industrial) → 4 retail in one zone impossible (citywide total retail ≤ 3).  

So D is impossible.

Option E: Four subzones: 2 retail, 2 industrial.  
• Rule 5: industrial not allowed if housing present or 3 retail present. Here no housing, not 3 retail → allowed.  

• Totals: 2 retail in one zone possible (citywide retail total ≤ 3).  

Possible.

Thus D cannot be true.

The correct option is: D

context: Millville has created three new development zones: Z1, Z2, and Z3. question: What is the maximum number of designated subzones allowed in Z3?
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

1. Understanding the constraints  
• 3 zones: Z1, Z2, Z3.  

• Each subzone is either Housing (H), Industrial (I), or Retail (R).  

• No subzone has more than one use.

• Specific restrictions:  

  1. No Retail in Z1 → Z1 can only have H or I.

  3. No more than 1 Retail subzone in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing → If H > 0 in a zone, then R ≤ 1 in that zone.  
  4. No Industrial in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing OR three subzones are designated for retail use →  
     ◦ If a zone has H > 0 → no I in that zone.  

     ◦ If total R = 3 city-wide → no I in any zone.  

2. Goal: Maximize subzones in Z3  
We want to maximize Z3’s subzones (H, I, R) subject to constraints.  

3. First, what’s possible in Z3?  
Z3 can have H, I, R (no restriction like Z1’s R ban).  

But:  
• If Z3 has H > 0 → no I in Z3 (rule 4).  

• If Z3 has H > 0 → R ≤ 1 in Z3 (rule 3).  

• Per zone H ≤ 2 (rule 2).  

4. Try maximum in Z3 without H  
If Z3 has no H, then:  
• Z3 can have I and R without restriction from rule 4 (unless city-wide R=3 forbids I everywhere).  

• Per zone, no explicit limit on I or R except city-wide limits and maybe others.  

But city-wide: Max 3 R total. Z1 has no R, so R can be in Z2, Z3 only.  
Also, if Z3 has no H, Z2 could have H (affects Z2’s I eligibility).  

We want to load Z3 with subzones: maybe all 3 R in Z3? That’s possible if Z2 has no R. But then:  
If total R = 3 → no I anywhere (rule 4). So Z3 could have 3 R + maybe H? But if Z3 has H, then R ≤ 1 (contradicts 3 R in Z3). So Z3 can’t have H if it has 3 R.  

So: Z3: 3 R + 0 H + I? But if R=3 total, I forbidden in all zones. So Z3: 3 R + 0 I = 3 subzones only.  

That’s small.  

5. Try Z3 with H=2, R=1  
If Z3: H=2, R=1 → no I in Z3 (rule 4).  
Z3 total = 3 subzones.  

That’s also small.  

6. Try Z3 with no H but with I and R  
Maximize: Z3: I=3 (city-wide max I), R=3 (city-wide max R) possible?  
But city-wide R=3 → no I anywhere (rule 4) → so impossible.  

So if Z3 has I, then total R ≤ 2 city-wide (to avoid R=3 total).  

Let’s distribute R: Z2 can have R=2, Z3 can have R=0? But we want Z3 max.  

Better: Z2: R=0, Z3: R=2 (total R=2), so I allowed in Z3.  

City-wide I max=3. Put all 3 I in Z3.  

So Z3: I=3, R=2, H=0. That’s 5 subzones.  

Check constraints:  
• Z3 has no H → no conflict with I.  

• Total R=2 (<3) → I allowed.  

• Z1: can have H or I freely (but not R).  

• City-wide H max 3: put H in Z1 and Z2 if needed to use city capacity, but not relevant to Z3’s count.  

Z3: 5 subzones possible: 3 I + 2 R.  

7. Can Z3 have 6?  
6 = 3 I + 3 R? No, because 3 R total forbids I.  
6 = 2 H + 2 I + 2 R? No, H>0 forbids I.  
6 = 3 I + 2 R + 1 H? No, H>0 forbids I.  

So 5 seems max.  

8. Check if 5 is achievable with other constraints  
We need to satisfy per-zone H ≤ 2, city-wide H ≤ 3, etc.  

Let’s test:  
Z1: H=2 (uses 2 of city H=3 total)  
Z2: H=1 (uses last H)  
Z3: H=0, I=3, R=2  

Check:  
• Z2: has H=1 → R ≤ 1 in Z2 (rule 3). Z2: R=0 (since all R in Z3).  

• Z1: has H=2 → no I in Z1 (rule 4). Z1: H=2 only.  

• Total R=2 (<3) → I allowed in Z3.  

• All constraints satisfied.  

Yes, 5 works.  

9. Can Z3 have more than 5?  
No, because:  
• H and I mutually exclusive in a zone.  

• R max per zone not fixed, but total R=3 city-wide kills I in all zones.  

• So to maximize a zone: either (H=2, R=1) = 3, or (I=3, R=2) = 5, or (R=3, H=0, I=0) = 3.  

So 5 is max.  

The correct option is: D

question: If one subzone in each of the zones is designated for industrial use, then which one of the following is allowed?
options: A) More subzones are designated for retail use in Z2 than in Z3.
B) A subzone in one of the zones is designated for housing.
C) Exactly two subzones are designated in Z1.
D) Exactly three subzones each are designated in Z2 and Z3.

reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1: Restate constraints

3. No more than 2 housing subzones in any zone.  
4. No more than 1 retail subzone in any zone that has housing.

Step 2: Given condition  
One subzone in each zone is designated for industrial use.  
So: Z1 has I, Z2 has I, Z3 has I.  

From constraint 5: Industrial not allowed in any zone that has housing or three subzones are designated for retail use.  
Since each zone has industrial, that means:  
• No zone can have housing.  

• It cannot be the case that three subzones are designated for retail use.  

So: Housing = 0 in all zones.  

Step 3: Remaining possibilities  
Uses: only Industrial (already 1 in each zone) and Retail possible.  
Constraint 1: Max 3 subzones for each use total.  
We already have 3 industrial subzones (Z1, Z2, Z3 each 1 I), so no more industrial allowed.  

So the only possible additional subzones are retail.  

Constraint 2: Retail not allowed in Z1.  
So retail can only be in Z2 and Z3.  

Constraint 4: irrelevant (no housing).  

Constraint 5’s “three subzones for retail” is forbidden — so retail subzones ≤ 2 total.  

Step 4: Retail count  
Max retail = 2 (since 3 retail is forbidden by constraint 5 because industrial exists in all zones).  
Retail possible in Z2 and Z3 only.  

So possible retail distribution: (Z1: 0 retail, Z2: r2, Z3: r3) with r2 + r3 ≤ 2.  

Step 5: Check options  

A) More retail in Z2 than in Z3.  
Possible? r2=2, r3=0 → total retail=2 (allowed). r2=1, r3=0 or 1 (but 1,1 gives total 2, but “more” means r2>r3, so r2=1, r3=0 works). So possible.  

B) Housing in one zone — impossible (would violate industrial-housing exclusion).  

C) Exactly 2 subzones in Z1 — impossible because Z1 can only have industrial (no retail allowed) and only 1 industrial is possible (since total industrial max 3, and we have 3 zones with 1 each). So Z1 has exactly 1 subzone.  

D) Exactly 3 subzones each in Z2 and Z3 — impossible because Z2 has 1 industrial already, so to have 3 subzones total, need 2 retail, and Z3 has 1 industrial, to have 3 subzones total, need 2 retail. That would be total retail = 4, but max retail allowed = 2.  

E) Exactly 4 subzones in Z3 — impossible because Z3 has 1 industrial, so 4 subzones means 3 retail in Z3 alone, but retail not allowed in a zone with industrial if total retail=3 (for all zones) — but also total retail max=2, so impossible.  

Step 6: Which is allowed?  
Only A is possible without violating constraints.  

The correct option is: A

context: Millville has created three new development zones: Z1, Z2, and Z3. Within these zones, subzones can be designated for housing, industrial, or retail use, with no subzone designated for more than one use. By city regulation, a total of no more than three subzones can be designated for each of the three uses. The following restrictions are in place: Retail subzones are not allowed in Z1. No more than two subzones for housing are allowed in any particular zone. No more than one retail subzone is allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing. Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing or three subzones are designated for retail use.
question: If three subzones in all are designated for retail use and a subzone in Z2 is designated for housing, then which one of the following is allowed?
options: A) Two subzones in Z1 are designated for housing.
B) More subzones are designated for industrial use in Z2 than in Z3.
C) More subzones are designated for retail use in Z2 than in Z3.
D) The same number of subzones are designated for retail use in Z2 and Z3.
E) A subzone in Z3 is designated for housing.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. Restating the rules  
• 3 zones: Z1, Z2, Z3.  

• Each subzone is Housing (H), Industrial (I), or Retail (R).  

• No subzone has more than one use.  

• Total across all zones: ≤3 subzones for each use (H, I, R).  

• Specific restrictions:  

  1. No Retail in Z1.  
  2. In any zone: ≤2 Housing subzones.  
  3. In any zone: If there’s at least 1 Housing subzone → ≤1 Retail subzone in that zone.  
  4. Industrial not allowed in a zone if:  
     ◦ that zone has at least 1 Housing subzone, OR  

     ◦ three subzones are designated for retail use in total (across all zones).  

2. Given conditions for this problem  
• Total Retail subzones = 3 (max possible).  

• Z2 has at least 1 Housing subzone.  

3. Immediate implications  

From rule 4: If total R = 3, then Industrial is not allowed in any zone that has Housing or (already triggered by total R=3) — wait, careful:  

Rule 4 says: "Industrial subzones are not allowed in any zone in which a subzone is designated for housing or three subzones are designated for retail use."  

The "or" means: if total R=3, then Industrial is not allowed in any zone at all (because the second condition is true for all zones).  

So: No Industrial anywhere because total R = 3.  

4. Check each zone’s possibilities  

• Z1: No Retail (rule 1), No Industrial (just deduced). So Z1 can only have Housing.  

• Z2: Has at least 1 H. Also no Industrial. So Z2 can have H or R.  

• Z3: No Industrial. So Z3 can have H or R.  

5. Distribution of 3 Retail subzones  

Since Z1 cannot have R, all 3 R must be in Z2 and Z3.  

Also: In any zone with H, R ≤ 1 (rule 3).  

Z2 has H → Z2 can have at most 1 R.  

So: Z2: R ≤ 1. That means Z3 must have at least 2 R (since total R=3).  

Possible R counts:  
• If Z2 has 1 R → Z3 has 2 R.  

• If Z2 has 0 R → Z3 has 3 R. But is 3 R allowed in Z3? Yes, no rule forbids 3 R in a zone except total limit (3 total, so 3 in one zone means 0 in others). But Z2 has H, so rule 4’s first condition doesn’t forbid I in Z3? Wait, I is forbidden anyway. But check rule 3: rule 3 only applies if the zone has H. Z3 having 3 R is fine if Z3 has no H. So possible.  

But also: Z2 has H, so Z2 can’t have I (already known), and Z2’s R ≤ 1.  

6. Check options  

A) Two subzones in Z1 designated for housing.  
• Z1: only H allowed (no I, no R). Max H per zone = 2 (rule 2). So 2 H in Z1 is allowed. But is it possible given total H ≤ 3? Yes, total H limit 3. If Z1=2H, Z2 has at least 1H → total H at least 3. That uses all H. Z3 would have 0 H. That’s fine. So A seems possible. But check conflicts: Z3 would have all 3 R in that case? No: total R=3, Z1 none, Z2 at most 1 R, so if Z2=1R, Z3=2R. That works. So A is possible. But the question asks “which is allowed?” meaning must be possible in some valid arrangement. So A is possible. But let’s check others.  

B) More I in Z2 than in Z3.  
• But I=0 everywhere (total R=3 forbids I in all zones). So impossible.  

C) More R in Z2 than in Z3.  
• Z2 ≤ 1 R, Z3 ≥ 2 R (since total R=3, Z1=0). So more R in Z2 than Z3 is impossible.  

D) Same number of R in Z2 and Z3.  
• Z2 ≤ 1, Z3 ≥ 2. Equal only if Z2=1 and Z3=1, but then total R=2, not 3. So impossible.  

E) A subzone in Z3 is designated for housing.  
• If Z3 has H, then Z3’s R ≤ 1 (rule 3). But total R=3, Z1=0, Z2 ≤ 1 (since Z2 has H). Then max total R = Z2’s R (≤1) + Z3’s R (≤1) = 2, but we need 3. Contradiction. So E impossible.  

8. So only A is possible.  

The correct option is: A

M must be in {1,2,3}, but 1=F, 2=H, 3=S ⇒ no room for M unless M=F or M=H or M=S, impossible (different manuscripts).  
Thus S=3 ⇒ no spot for M in {1,2,3} ⇒ impossible.

M in {1,2,3} but 2=G, 3=P ⇒ M=1 possible.  
F<H<S and H≠5, L≥5. Arrange: 1=M, 2=G, 3=P, then F, H, S, L order consistent?

So only S fails.

Only B satisfies all conditions.

options: A) Exactly three of the dishes are stored on the bottom shelf.

Let’s reason it out step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints  
• 6 dishes: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.  

• 3 shelves: B (bottom), M (middle), T (top).  

• Max 3 dishes per shelf.  

• Exactly 1 shelf is empty ⇒ 2 shelves hold all 6 dishes ⇒ each of those 2 shelves must have 3 dishes (since 6/2 = 3 and max 3 allowed).  

• So: 3 dishes on one shelf, 3 dishes on another shelf, 0 dishes on the third shelf.

Step 2 – Relative positions of dishes 2, 5, 6  
• Dish 2 is at least one shelf above dish 6 ⇒ D2’s shelf > D6’s shelf (in height: T > M > B).

D6 adjacent to D5 ⇒ D5 on M (since B has D6, M is adjacent to B).  
So: M has D2, D5; B has D6.  
But each full shelf must have 3 dishes. M has 2 so far, B has 1 so far. Need to assign D1, D3, D4.

context: Exactly six petri dishes—labeled dish 1 through dish 6—are to be stored in an otherwise empty refrigerator. There are three available shelves—the bottom shelf, the middle shelf, and the top shelf. The placement of the dishes must be consistent with the following conditions: No more than three dishes are stored on any shelf. Dish 2 is stored at least one shelf above dish 6. Dish 6 is stored either one shelf above or one shelf below dish 5. Dish 1 is not stored on the same shelf as dish 4.
question: If dish 5 is the only dish stored on the bottom shelf and if exactly two of the dishes are stored on the middle shelf, then which one of the following is a pair of dishes that must be among the dishes stored on the top shelf?
options: A) dish 1 and dish 2
B) dish 1 and dish 6
C) dish 2 and dish 3
D) dish 2 and dish 4
E) dish 3 and dish 4
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason step by step.  

Step 1 – Understand the constraints  
• 6 dishes: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.  

• 3 shelves: Bottom (B), Middle (M), Top (T).  

• No more than 3 dishes per shelf.  

• Dish 2 is at least one shelf above dish 6 → 2 > 6 (in shelf level).  

• Dish 6 is either one shelf above or one shelf below dish 5 → 6 and 5 are on adjacent shelves.  

• Dish 1 is not on the same shelf as dish 4.  

Step 2 – Apply the new condition  
Dish 5 is the only dish on the bottom shelf.  
Exactly two dishes are on the middle shelf.  

So:  
B: {5} only.  
M: 2 dishes.  
T: remaining 6 – 1 – 2 = 3 dishes.  

Step 3 – Place 6 relative to 5  
5 is alone on B.  
6 must be adjacent to 5 → so 6 must be on M (since B has only 5, and T is not adjacent to B if M is in between? Wait: shelves are B, M, T. Adjacent means B-M or M-T. B and T are not adjacent. So 6 must be on M because 5 is on B).  

So: M contains 6 and one other dish.  

Step 4 – Constraint: Dish 2 is at least one shelf above dish 6  
6 is on M → 2 must be above M → so 2 is on T.  

So T contains 2.  

Step 5 – Fill shelves  
B: {5}  
M: {6, x} (x is one of 1, 3, 4)  
T: {2, y, z} (remaining 3 dishes from {1,3,4} after x goes to M)  

Step 6 – Constraint: Dish 1 and Dish 4 not on same shelf  
If 1 and 4 are both on T, that’s fine (different from M). But they can’t be both on M or both on T? Wait, the rule says: not on the same shelf. So they can be on different shelves.  

We need a pair that must be on T. We know 2 is on T. So any pair that must include 2 and another dish that is forced to T.  

Let’s check possibilities:  

M has 6 and one other. The other could be 3, or 4, or 1.  

Case 1: M = {6, 1} → T = {2, 3, 4} → 4 is on T, 1 is on M.  
Case 2: M = {6, 3} → T = {2, 1, 4} → 1 and 4 both on T (allowed)  
Case 3: M = {6, 4} → T = {2, 1, 3} → 1 on T, 4 on M.  

In all cases, who is always on T besides 2?  

From cases:  
• 1 is on T in cases 2 and 3, but in case 1, 1 is on M. So 1 is not forced to T.  

• 3 is on T in cases 1 and 3, but in case 2, 3 is on M. So 3 not forced.  

• 4 is on T in cases 1 and 2, but in case 3, 4 is on M. So 4 not forced.  

So no single other dish is forced to T besides 2.  

But the question asks: which pair must be among the dishes stored on T? That means both in the pair must be on T in every case.  

Check pairs:  

A) 1 and 2: In case 1, 1 is on M → not on T → so pair (1,2) not both on T always. No.  

B) 1 and 6: 6 is always on M, so never on T. No.  

C) 2 and 3: In case 2, 3 is on M → not on T. No.  

D) 2 and 4: In case 3, 4 is on M → not on T. No.  

E) 3 and 4: In case 2, 3 on M; in case 3, 4 on M; in case 1, both 3 and 4 on T. So not always both on T. No.  

Hmm — that suggests none of the pairs are both forced to T. But the problem says “must be among the dishes stored on the top shelf” meaning both in the pair are on T in every scenario.  

Let’s check carefully: Maybe I made a mistake: Are there only 3 cases? Yes: M = {6,1}, {6,3}, {6,4}.  

We need a pair that appears on T in all 3 cases:  

Case 1: T = {2,3,4} → pairs on T: (2,3), (2,4), (3,4).  
Case 2: T = {2,1,4} → pairs: (2,1), (2,4), (1,4).  
Case 3: T = {2,1,3} → pairs: (2,1), (2,3), (1,3).  

Intersection of pairs present in all cases:  
• (2,4) is in case1 and case2, but not in case3 (4 not on T in case3).  

• (2,3) is in case1 and case3, but not case2.  

• (2,1) is in case2 and case3, but not case1.  

• (3,4) is only in case1.  

• (1,4) is only in case2.  

• (1,3) is only in case3.  

No pair is in all 3.  

But the problem says “must be among the dishes stored on the top shelf” — maybe they mean at least one of the two dishes in the pair is on T in all cases? No, “a pair … that must be among the dishes stored on the top shelf” means both members of the pair are on the top shelf in every possible arrangement.  

But none satisfy. Did I miss a constraint?  

Check: “exactly two of the dishes are stored on the middle shelf” — yes.  

But maybe the total per shelf constraint: T can have 3 max, we gave it 3.  

Wait — maybe I misinterpreted “must be among the dishes stored on the top shelf” — it could mean: the pair is a subset of the set of dishes on the top shelf in every scenario. That’s what I tested.  

But since none work, maybe I made a wrong deduction.  

Let’s check 2 and 4: Are they always on T? No, case3: 4 on M.  

2 and 3: case2: 3 on M.  

2 and 1: case1: 1 on M.  

3 and 4: case2: 3 on M; case3: 4 on M.  

So none.  

But the problem is from LSAT, maybe I missed that 1 and 4 can’t be on M together? No, they can be on different shelves.  

Maybe the correct reading: “which pair must be stored on the top shelf?” means: it is impossible to place them otherwise — so both forced to T.  

But 2 is forced to T. So any pair with 2 and another dish forced to T. Is any other dish forced to T? No.  

But maybe the pair is 2 and X where X is forced to T in the scenarios that remain after applying all constraints fully. Did I apply “Dish 1 is not stored on the same shelf as dish 4” fully?  

Let’s apply it:  

Case M={6,1}: then T={2,3,4} → 1(M) and 4(T) ok.  
Case M={6,4}: then T={2,1,3} → 4(M) and 1(T) ok.  
Case M={6,3}: then T={2,1,4} → 1(T) and 4(T) — oh! That’s not allowed? Wait, rule: Dish 1 is not stored on the same shelf as dish 4. In this case, they are both on T → violates the rule!  

So Case M={6,3} is impossible!  

So possible cases: only M={6,1} and M={6,4}.  

Now check T in each:  

Case M={6,1}: T={2,3,4}  
Case M={6,4}: T={2,1,3}  

Now, which pair is in T in both cases?  

Case1 T: {2,3,4}  
Case2 T: {2,1,3}  

Pairs on T in both:  
• (2,3) is in both.  

• (3,4) is only in case1.  

• (2,4) only in case1.  

• (1,3) only in case2.  

• (2,1) only in case2.  

Only (2,3) appears in both cases’ T sets.  

So the pair that must be on the top shelf together is (2,3).  

That corresponds to option C.  

Final check: In case1: dishes on T: 2,3,4 → (2,3) on T.  
In case2: dishes on T: 2,1,3 → (2,3) on T.  

Yes.  

The correct option is: C

context: Exactly six petri dishes—labeled dish 1 through dish 6—are to be stored in an otherwise empty refrigerator. There are three available shelves—the bottom shelf, the middle shelf, and the top shelf. The placement of the dishes must be consistent with the following conditions: No more than three dishes are stored on any shelf. Dish 2 is stored at least one shelf above dish 6. Dish 6 is stored either one shelf above or one shelf below dish 5. Dish 1 is not stored on the same shelf as dish 4.
question: If exactly one of the dishes is stored on the middle shelf, which one of the following could be the list of dishes stored on the top shelf?
options: A) dish 1, dish 2
B) dish 1, dish 5
C) dish 2, dish 3
D) dish 3, dish 4
E) dish 3, dish 5
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason step by step.  

Step 1 – Understand constraints  
• 6 dishes (1–6), 3 shelves (bottom, middle, top).  

• No more than 3 per shelf.  

• Dish 2 is at least one shelf above dish 6 → D2 > D6 (shelf level: top > middle > bottom).  

• D6 is either one shelf above or one shelf below D5 → D5 and D6 are on adjacent shelves.  

• D1 is not on the same shelf as D4.  

• Exactly 1 dish on the middle shelf.  

Step 2 – Implications of exactly 1 dish on middle shelf  
With 6 dishes total, 1 on middle shelf means:  
• Top shelf: some dishes (1–3 dishes possible, but must leave at least 1 for bottom shelf).  

• Bottom shelf: rest of dishes.  

So distribution: Top shelf = x dishes, Middle shelf = 1 dish, Bottom shelf = 5–x dishes.  
Since max 3 per shelf, x ≤ 3, and 5–x ≤ 3 → x ≥ 2.  
So x = 2 or 3.  

Step 3 – D2 and D6 constraint  
D2 is at least one shelf above D6.  
If D6 is on bottom shelf, D2 can be on middle or top.  
If D6 is on middle shelf, D2 must be on top shelf.  
If D6 is on top shelf, impossible (no shelf above top). So D6 cannot be on top shelf.  

Step 4 – D5 and D6 adjacent shelves  
Possible arrangements:  
• D6 on bottom → D5 on middle (since D6 not on top, so D5 adjacent: bottom–middle).  

• D6 on middle → D5 on top or bottom.  

Step 5 – Try each option  

Option A: Top shelf = D1, D2  
Middle shelf = 1 dish (not D1, D2).  
Bottom shelf = other 4 dishes.  

D6 not on top (from Step 3).  
D6 on bottom or middle.  

Case 1: D6 on bottom → D5 on middle (adjacency).  
Middle shelf = D5 only.  
Top shelf = D1, D2.  
Bottom shelf = D3, D4, D6, and one more? Wait, dishes: D1, D2 top; D5 middle; bottom: D3, D4, D6, and D? We have D1, D2, D3, D4, D5, D6. Yes, bottom: D3, D4, D6. That’s 3 dishes, but we need 4? Let’s count: Top: D1, D2 (2 dishes), Middle: D5 (1 dish), total 3 so far, so bottom: D3, D4, D6 (3 dishes) → total 6. That’s fine.  
Check D1 and D4 not same shelf: D1 top, D4 bottom → OK.  
D2 above D6: D2 top, D6 bottom → OK.  
D5 middle, D6 bottom → adjacent → OK.  
So possible.  

Case 2: D6 on middle → D5 on top or bottom.  
If D6 on middle, D2 must be on top (D2 above D6) → yes, D2 is on top (given in option A).  
Middle = D6 only.  
Top = D1, D2.  
Bottom = D3, D4, D5.  
D5 and D6 adjacent? D5 bottom, D6 middle → yes adjacent.  
D1 ≠ D4 shelf: D1 top, D4 bottom → OK.  
Possible.  

So Option A works in both cases.  

Step 6 – Check others briefly to ensure only A works  

Option B: Top = D1, D5  
Middle = 1 dish.  
D6 not on top.  

If D6 bottom → D5 must be middle (adjacent), but D5 is on top → impossible.  
If D6 middle → D5 top or bottom; D5 is top, so OK adjacency. Then D6 middle, D2 must be top (D2 above D6), but top is D1, D5 only → D2 not on top → impossible.  
So B fails.  

Option C: Top = D2, D3  
Middle = 1 dish.  
D6 not on top.  

If D6 bottom → D5 middle. Then D2 top above D6 OK.  
But middle = D5 only.  
Top = D2, D3.  
Bottom = D1, D4, D6.  
D1 and D4 both bottom → same shelf → violates D1≠D4. Fail.  

If D6 middle → D5 top or bottom.  
D6 middle → D2 must be top (yes, D2 is top).  
Middle = D6 only.  
Top = D2, D3.  
Bottom = D1, D4, D5.  
D1 and D4 both bottom → fail.  
So C fails.  

Option D: Top = D3, D4  
D1 and D4 not same shelf → D1 not top (OK, D4 top, so D1 not top).  
D6 not on top.  

If D6 bottom → D5 middle.  
Middle = D5 only.  
Top = D3, D4.  
Bottom = D1, D2, D6.  
D2 above D6: D2 bottom, D6 bottom → same shelf → fail.  

If D6 middle → D5 top or bottom.  
D6 middle → D2 must be top. But top is D3, D4 only → D2 not top → fail.  
So D fails.  

Option E: Top = D3, D5  
D6 not on top.  

If D6 bottom → D5 must be middle (adjacent), but D5 top → impossible.  
If D6 middle → D5 top or bottom; D5 top OK.  
D6 middle → D2 must be top. But top is D3, D5 only → D2 not top → fail.  
So E fails.  

Only A works.  

The correct option is: A

context: A company operates vending machines in four schools: Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford, and Isley. The company delivers juices in one of its two trucks and snacks in the other truck. Each week, exactly one delivery of juices and exactly one delivery of snacks is made to each school, subject to the following conditions: Snacks must be delivered to Ferndale at some time before they are delivered to Hafford. Gladstone cannot be the fourth school to which juices are delivered. Gladstone must be the third school to which snacks are delivered. The first school to which juices are delivered must be the fourth one to which snacks are delivered.
question: Which one of the following could be the schedule of deliveries to the schools, from the first to the fourth?
options: A) Juices: Hafford, Ferndale, Gladstone, Isley Snacks: Ferndale, Isley, Gladstone, Hafford
B) Juices: Hafford, Isley, Ferndale, Gladstone Snacks: Isley, Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford
C) Juices: Isley, Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford Snacks: Hafford, Ferndale, Gladstone, Isley
D) Juices: Isley, Gladstone, Ferndale, Hafford Snacks: Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford, Isley
E) Juices: Isley, Hafford, Gladstone, Ferndale Snacks: Ferndale, Isley, Gladstone, Hafford
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each condition against the options.  

Conditions:
1. Snacks: Ferndale before Hafford. (F_snacks < H_snacks in order)
2. Juices: Gladstone not fourth.
3. Snacks: Gladstone is third.
4. First school for juices = fourth school for snacks.

Option A  
Juices: H, F, G, I  
Snacks: F, I, G, H  

Check:  
1. Snacks: F(1) before H(4) ✅  
2. Juices: G is 3rd (not 4th) ✅  
3. Snacks: G is 3rd ✅  
4. First juices = H; fourth snacks = H ✅  

All conditions satisfied.  

Option B  
Juices: H, I, F, G  
Snacks: I, F, G, H  

Check:  
1. Snacks: F(2) before H(4) ✅  
2. Juices: G is 4th ❌ (violates condition 2)  

Fail.  

Option C  
Juices: I, F, G, H  
Snacks: H, F, G, I  

Check:  
1. Snacks: F(2) before H(1)? No, H is 1st, F is 2nd → H before F ❌  

Fail.  

Option D  
Juices: I, G, F, H  
Snacks: F, G, H, I  

Check:  
1. Snacks: F(1) before H(3) ✅  
2. Juices: G is 2nd ✅  
3. Snacks: G is 2nd ❌ (must be 3rd)  

Fail.  

Option E  
Juices: I, H, G, F  
Snacks: F, I, G, H  

Check:  
1. Snacks: F(1) before H(4) ✅  
2. Juices: G is 3rd ✅  
3. Snacks: G is 3rd ✅  
4. First juices = I; fourth snacks = H ❌ (I ≠ H)  

Fail.  

Only A satisfies all conditions.  

The correct option is: A

context: A company operates vending machines in four schools: Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford, and Isley. The company delivers juices in one of its two trucks and snacks in the other truck. Each week, exactly one delivery of juices and exactly one delivery of snacks is made to each school, subject to the following conditions: Snacks must be delivered to Ferndale at some time before they are delivered to Hafford. Gladstone cannot be the fourth school to which juices are delivered. Gladstone must be the third school to which snacks are delivered. The first school to which juices are delivered must be the fourth one to which snacks are delivered.
question: If Hafford is the fourth school to which juices are delivered, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) Ferndale is the second school to which juices are delivered.
B) Gladstone is the third school to which juices are delivered.
C) Ferndale is the second school to which snacks are delivered.
D) Hafford is the second school to which snacks are delivered.
E) Isley is the first school to which snacks are delivered.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. Restating the constraints  
• Schools: F, G, H, I.  

• Two separate sequences:  

  • Juice delivery order (J1, J2, J3, J4)  

  • Snack delivery order (S1, S2, S3, S4)  

• Constraints:  

  1. Snacks: F before H in snack order. (F < H in snacks)  
  2. Juice: G ≠ J4.  
  3. Snacks: G = S3.  
  4. J1 = S4.  

2. New given condition  
H = J4.  

From constraint 4: J1 = S4.  
So S4 = J1, and H = J4.  

3. Snack order implications  
From constraint 3: G = S3.  
From constraint 1: F before H in snacks.  

So in snacks: F’s position < H’s position.  

Also, S4 = J1.  

4. Juice order with H = J4  
Juice order: J1, J2, J3, H.  
G ≠ J4 (given), so G is in {J1, J2, J3}.  

But J1 = S4. Could G = J1? Possibly, but check snacks: G = S3.  
If G = J1 = S4, then S3 = S4, impossible. So G ≠ J1.  

So G is in {J2, J3}.  

5. Snack order reasoning  
Snack order: S1, S2, S3=G, S4=J1.  

We know F < H in snacks.  

H’s snack position: H ≠ S4 (because S4 = J1, and H = J4, so H ≠ J1, so H ≠ S4).  
H’s snack position ≠ S3 (S3=G). So H is S1 or S2.  

But F < H in snacks, so if H is S1, impossible (no position before S1).  
Thus H must be S2.  

So snacks: H = S2.  

Then F < H means F = S1.  

6. Snack order so far  
S1 = F, S2 = H, S3 = G, S4 = J1.  

The remaining school for S4 is I (since F, H, G are S1, S2, S3).  

So S4 = I = J1.  

Thus J1 = I.  

7. Juice order so far  
J1 = I, J4 = H.  
G is J2 or J3.  

Remaining school F is the other of {J2, J3} not taken by G.  

So Juice order possibilities:  
Case 1: I, G, F, H  
Case 2: I, F, G, H  

Both satisfy: G ≠ J4, H = J4, J1 = I = S4.  

8. Check the options  
A) F = J2? Not necessarily; in Case 2, F = J2 yes; in Case 1, F = J3. So A not always true.  

B) G = J3? In Case 1, G = J2; in Case 2, G = J3. So B not always true.  

C) F = S2? No, F = S1. So false.  

D) H = S2? Yes, we deduced H = S2. So D is always true.  

E) I = S1? No, I = S4. So false.  

9. Conclusion  
Only D must be true.  

The correct option is: D

reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. Known constraints (always true):

• Two separate sequences:  

  • Juice delivery order (J1, J2, J3, J4)  

  • Snack delivery order (S1, S2, S3, S4)  

• Snacks: F before H in snack order.  

• Juices: G ≠ J4.  

• Snacks: G = S3.  

• First school to get juices = fourth school to get snacks:  

  \[
  J1 = S4
  \]

2. Extra condition for this question:  
I = J3 (Isley is third for juices).

3. Deductions:

From G = S3 (snacks) and J1 = S4:  
• G is not J1 (since J1 = S4, but G = S3, so G ≠ S4 ⇒ G ≠ J1).  

Also, G ≠ J4 (given). So G is either J2 or J3.  
But J3 = I (given in this question), so G ≠ J3.  
Thus G = J2.  

So juice order so far:  
J1 = ?, J2 = G, J3 = I, J4 = ?.  
Remaining schools for J1 and J4: {F, H}.  

4. Snack order constraints:

Snack order: S3 = G. S4 = J1.  

J1 is either F or H.  

Case 1: J1 = F ⇒ S4 = F.  
Snack order: S4 = F, S3 = G.  
Snack constraint: F before H ⇒ F = S4 means H must be after S4 in snacks — impossible because S4 is last.  
So J1 ≠ F.  

So J1 = H ⇒ S4 = H.  

Thus:  
Juice order: J1 = H, J2 = G, J3 = I, J4 = F.  

Snack order: S3 = G, S4 = H.  
Also F before H in snacks: F must be S1, S2, or S3. But S3 = G, S4 = H, so F is S1 or S2.  

Remaining school I is the other of S1/S2 not taken by F, and the remaining slot S? is determined.  

5. Possible snack orders:

We have S3 = G, S4 = H. F before H ⇒ F in {S1, S2}. I takes the remaining of S1/S2, and the leftover snack slot S? is the other.  

So possible snack orders:  
(a) S1 = F, S2 = I, S3 = G, S4 = H.  
(b) S1 = I, S2 = F, S3 = G, S4 = H.  

Both satisfy F before H (F is S1 or S2, H is S4).  

6. Check options:

Juice order: H, G, I, F.  

A) Juices: G before H? No — H is J1, G is J2, so H before G. So A is false.  

B) Juices: I before H? No — H is J1, I is J3, so H before I. So B is false.  

C) Snacks: F before I?  
• In (a) S1=F, S2=I ⇒ F before I ⇒ True.  

• In (b) S1=I, S2=F ⇒ I before F ⇒ False.  

Since (a) is possible, C could be true.  

D) Snacks: G before I? G = S3, I is S1 or S2. If I is S1 or S2, then I before G (since S1, S2 before S3). So G before I is impossible. D is false.  

E) Snacks: H before G? H = S4, G = S3 ⇒ S3 before S4 ⇒ G before H, so H before G is impossible. E is false.  

Only C is possible in some scenario.  

The correct option is: C

H I G F

context: A company operates vending machines in four schools: Ferndale, Gladstone, Hafford, and Isley. The company delivers juices in one of its two trucks and snacks in the other truck. Each week, exactly one delivery of juices and exactly one delivery of snacks is made to each school, subject to the following conditions: Snacks must be delivered to Ferndale at some time before they are delivered to Hafford. Gladstone cannot be the fourth school to which juices are delivered. Gladstone must be the third school to which snacks are delivered. The first school to which juices are delivered must be the fourth one to which snacks are delivered.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the condition that Gladstone cannot be the fourth school to which juices are delivered, would have the same effect in determining the delivery schedule?
options: A) Ferndale must be either the second school or the fourth school to which juices are delivered.
B) Gladstone must be either the second school or the third school to which juices are delivered.
C) Hafford must be either the first school or the fourth school to which juices are delivered.
D) The first school to which juices are delivered must be either Ferndale or Isley.
E) The fourth school to which juices are delivered must be either Hafford or Isley.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Original conditions:
1. Snacks: Ferndale (F) before Hafford (H) in snack delivery order.  
2. Juices: Gladstone (G) ≠ 4th in juice order.  
3. Snacks: Gladstone (G) = 3rd in snack order.  
4. Juices: 1st in juice order = Snacks: 4th in snack order.  

Step 1 – Interpret condition 4.  
Let’s denote:  
Juice order:  J_1, J_2, J_3, J_4   
Snack order:  S_1, S_2, S_3, S_4   

Condition 4:  J_1 = S_4  (same school).  

Step 2 – Snack order constraints.  
From (3):  S_3 = G .  
From (1): F before H in snack order.  

Possible snack orders consistent with  S_3 = G :  
Positions left for F and H: F before H, so H can’t be S₁ if F is later, etc. Let’s list possibilities later.  

Step 3 – Juice order constraint to be replaced:  J_4 \neq G .  
So G is not last in juice order.  

We want: which new condition, if substituted for “G ≠ J₄”, yields the same effect?  

That means: the new condition must force G ≠ J₄, and not conflict with other possible orders allowed by original.  

Step 4 – Test possible snack orders to see link between J₁ and G’s juice position.  

From (4):  J_1 = S_4 .  
So S₄ is the same school as J₁.  

Where can G be in juice order?  

We know G is S₃ in snack order.  
So in snack sequence: (…, G, J₁) because S₄ = J₁.  

So in snacks: G is immediately before J₁ in snack order, unless S₄ is G? But S₄ can’t be G because S₃ is G. So S₄ ≠ G. So J₁ ≠ G.  

Thus J₁ is not G.  

Step 5 – Consider possible snack orders with F before H and S₃ = G.  

Snack order: 4 slots: S₁, S₂, S₃=G, S₄=J₁.  

So J₁ is determined by S₄.  

Also F before H: F and H occupy S₁, S₂, S₄ in some order? Wait, S₃ is G, so F and H are in {S₁, S₂, S₄} with F before H.  

Case 1: F = S₁, H = S₂ (then S₄ is the remaining school, not G,F,H → must be I)  
Case 2: F = S₁, H = S₄ (then S₂ is the remaining school, not G,F,H → I)  
Case 3: F = S₂, H = S₄ (then S₁ is the remaining school, not G,F,H → I)  

So possible (S₁, S₂, S₃=G, S₄):  
1. (F, H, G, I) → J₁ = I  
2. (F, I, G, H) → J₁ = H  
3. (I, F, G, H) → J₁ = H  

So J₁ is either I or H.  

Step 6 – Original juice constraint G ≠ J₄.  
We need to see if that’s automatically implied if we choose a certain new condition.  

Currently: J₁ is H or I.  

If J₁ = H, then in juice order H is 1st. G is not 4th originally. Could G be 4th without the rule? Possibly, unless other constraints forbid.  

We must check: without “G ≠ J₄”, could G be J₄?  

Snack order: S₃=G, S₄=J₁. So J₁ ≠ G (we already saw).  

If G = J₄ in juice order, is that possible? Yes: Juice order example: (H, F, I, G) satisfies J₁=H=S₄, snack order (F,I,G,H) has F before H, S₃=G, S₄=H=J₁. This satisfies all except original G≠J₄. So original rule explicitly forbids G=J₄.  

So the effect of the original rule is just to say G’s juice position ≠ 4.  

Step 7 – Which option is equivalent to G ≠ J₄?  

A) F = J₂ or J₄ — unrelated to G’s position.  
B) G = J₂ or J₃ — this means G is 2nd or 3rd in juice order, so automatically G ≠ J₄ and G ≠ J₁. But is G ≠ J₁ already forced?  

Check: Could G be J₁? No, because J₁ = S₄ and S₄ ≠ G (since S₃=G). So G ≠ J₁ is fixed. So possible juice positions for G: 2,3,4 without original rule. Original rule removes 4. Option B removes 4 and also removes 1 (already removed), so it leaves {2,3}. That is stricter than original (original allows G in 2,3, or? Wait, 1 not allowed, 4 not allowed, so original allows 2,3 only? Let’s check:  

From Step 5: J₁ is H or I. So G ≠ J₁. So G in {J₂, J₃, J₄} without original restriction. Original restriction says G ≠ J₄, so G in {J₂, J₃}.  

So actually original rule + fixed J₁≠G already force G to be J₂ or J₃!  

So the original condition “G ≠ J₄” is redundant if we know J₁ ≠ G? Wait, but is J₁ ≠ G already given? Yes, from S₄ ≠ G and J₁ = S₄. So without “G ≠ J₄”, G could be J₄. Let’s check example:  

Snack: (F, I, G, H) → J₁ = H. Juice order: (H, F, I, G) → valid for all conditions except original G≠J₄. So original rule is not redundant. So G’s positions possible without original rule: {2,3,4}. With original: {2,3}.  

So original rule = “G is 2nd or 3rd in juice order”. That’s exactly option B.  

Step 8 – Check others:  
C) H = J₁ or J₄ — unrelated.  
D) J₁ = F or I — but J₁ is H or I from earlier, so this would remove H as J₁, changing more than original.  
E) J₄ = H or I — not equivalent, could force J₄ ≠ F, G, not same as just blocking G.  

Only B matches the original effect.  

The correct option is: B

context: Each of five paralegals—Frank, Gina, Hiro, Kevin, and Laurie—is being assigned to exactly one of three cases—the Raimes, Sicoli, or Thompson case. At least one paralegal will be assigned to each case. The following conditions must apply: Either Frank is assigned to Raimes and Kevin is assigned to Thompson, or Frank is not assigned to Raimes and Kevin is not assigned to Thompson. Either Frank is the sole paralegal assigned to his case or Gina is the sole paralegal assigned to her case, but not both. Hiro is assigned to Sicoli.
question: Which one of the following could be the assignment of paralegals to cases?
options: A) Raimes: Frank Sicoli: Gina, Hiro, Kevin Thompson: Laurie
B) Raimes: Kevin Sicoli: Gina Thompson: Frank, Hiro, Laurie
C) Raimes: Gina, Kevin Sicoli: Frank, Hiro Thompson: Laurie
D) Raimes: Kevin, Laurie Sicoli: Gina, Hiro Thompson: Frank
E) Raimes: Frank, Kevin, Laurie Sicoli: Hiro Thompson: Gina
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

Step 1 – Interpret the conditions  
1. Either Frank is assigned to Raimes and Kevin is assigned to Thompson, or Frank is not assigned to Raimes and Kevin is not assigned to Thompson.  
   • This means: Frank’s case = Raimes ⇔ Kevin’s case = Thompson.  

   • Equivalently: They are either both true or both false.  

2. Either Frank is the sole paralegal assigned to his case or Gina is the sole paralegal assigned to her case, but not both.  
   • Exactly one of these is true:  

     (a) Frank is alone on his case.  
     (b) Gina is alone on her case.  
   • Not both true, not both false.  

3. Hiro is assigned to Sicoli.  

Step 2 – Check each option  

Option A: Raimes: Frank; Sicoli: Gina, Hiro, Kevin; Thompson: Laurie.  
• Condition 1: Frank is assigned to Raimes → Kevin must be assigned to Thompson. But Kevin is in Sicoli, not Thompson. ❌ Fails condition 1.  

Option B: Raimes: Kevin; Sicoli: Gina; Thompson: Frank, Hiro, Laurie.  
• Condition 1: Frank not in Raimes → Kevin not in Thompson. Kevin is in Raimes, so not in Thompson → OK.  

• Condition 3: Hiro in Sicoli? No, Hiro is in Thompson. ❌ Fails condition 3.  

Option C: Raimes: Gina, Kevin; Sicoli: Frank, Hiro; Thompson: Laurie.  
• Condition 3: Hiro in Sicoli? Yes.  

• Condition 1: Frank not in Raimes → Kevin not in Thompson. Kevin is in Raimes, so not in Thompson → OK.  

• Condition 2: Frank’s case = Sicoli, has Hiro too → not alone. Gina’s case = Raimes, has Kevin too → not alone. So both “Frank alone” and “Gina alone” are false. ❌ Fails condition 2 (must have exactly one true).  

Option D: Raimes: Kevin, Laurie; Sicoli: Gina, Hiro; Thompson: Frank.  
• Condition 3: Hiro in Sicoli? Yes.  

• Condition 1: Frank not in Raimes → Kevin not in Thompson. Kevin is in Raimes, so not in Thompson → OK.  

• Condition 2: Frank’s case = Thompson, has only Frank → Frank is alone. Gina’s case = Sicoli, has Hiro too → Gina not alone. So “Frank alone” is true, “Gina alone” false → exactly one true. ✅ All conditions satisfied.  

Option E: Raimes: Frank, Kevin, Laurie; Sicoli: Hiro; Thompson: Gina.  
• Condition 3: Hiro in Sicoli? Yes.  

• Condition 1: Frank in Raimes → Kevin must be in Thompson. But Kevin is in Raimes, not Thompson. ❌ Fails condition 1.  

Step 3 – Conclusion  
Only option D satisfies all conditions.  

The correct option is: D

context: Each of five paralegals—Frank, Gina, Hiro, Kevin, and Laurie—is being assigned to exactly one of three cases—the Raimes, Sicoli, or Thompson case. At least one paralegal will be assigned to each case. The following conditions must apply: Either Frank is assigned to Raimes and Kevin is assigned to Thompson, or Frank is not assigned to Raimes and Kevin is not assigned to Thompson. Either Frank is the sole paralegal assigned to his case or Gina is the sole paralegal assigned to her case, but not both. Hiro is assigned to Sicoli.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be the complete assignment of paralegals to the Sicoli case?
options: A) Frank, Hiro, Kevin
B) Frank, Hiro, Laurie
C) Gina, Hiro, Kevin
D) Gina, Hiro, Laurie
E) Hiro, Kevin, Laurie
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints

1. Either Frank is assigned to Raimes and Kevin is assigned to Thompson, or Frank is not assigned to Raimes and Kevin is not assigned to Thompson.  
   This means:  
   • Case 1: (Frank → Raimes) and (Kevin → Thompson)  

   • Case 2: (Frank → not Raimes) and (Kevin → not Thompson)  

   So Frank and Kevin are “linked” in assignment to Raimes/Thompson: they are either both assigned to those specific cases, or both not assigned to those specific cases.

2. Either Frank is the sole paralegal assigned to his case, or Gina is the sole paralegal assigned to her case, but not both.  
   So exactly one of the following is true:  
   • Frank is alone on his case  

   • Gina is alone on her case  

   Not both, not neither.

3. Hiro is assigned to Sicoli.  
   So Sicoli has at least Hiro.

Step 2 – Translating the question

We are asked: Which CANNOT be the complete assignment of paralegals to the Sicoli case?  
So the options list possible sets of paralegals assigned to Sicoli. We must check if that Sicoli assignment is possible given the constraints.

Step 3 – Testing each option

Option A: Sicoli = {Frank, Hiro, Kevin}

• Then Raimes and Thompson split the remaining two paralegals: Gina and Laurie.  

• From constraint 1: Frank is not in Raimes (he’s in Sicoli), so Kevin must not be in Thompson. But Kevin is in Sicoli, so Kevin is not in Thompson — OK.  

• Check constraint 2: Frank is in Sicoli with others → not sole. So Gina must be sole on her case.  

   Gina’s case: either Raimes or Thompson. If Gina is sole, the other of Raimes/Thompson gets Laurie alone? But there are 2 cases (Raimes and Thompson) and 2 people left (Gina, Laurie). If Gina is alone in her case, Laurie must be alone in the other case. That means both Raimes and Thompson have 1 person each. That’s possible:  
   Raimes: Gina (sole)  
   Thompson: Laurie (sole)  
   Sicoli: F, H, K (3 people)  
   This satisfies:  
   • Hiro in Sicoli ✓  

   • Frank not in Raimes, Kevin not in Thompson ✓  

   • Gina sole ✓ (Frank not sole)  

   So A is possible.

Option B: Sicoli = {Frank, Hiro, Laurie}

• Remaining: Gina and Kevin go to Raimes and Thompson.  

• Constraint 1: Frank not in Raimes (he’s in Sicoli) → Kevin not in Thompson. So Kevin must be in Raimes.  

   So: Kevin → Raimes, Gina → Thompson.  
• Check constraint 2: Frank not sole (Sicoli has 3) → Gina must be sole.  

   But Gina is in Thompson with no one else? Wait: Gina in Thompson alone? Yes: Raimes: Kevin, Thompson: Gina.  
   That works:  
   Raimes: Kevin (1 person)  
   Thompson: Gina (1 person)  
   Sicoli: F, H, L (3 people)  
   Check: Kevin not in Thompson ✓, Frank not in Raimes ✓. Gina sole ✓.  
   So B is possible.

Option C: Sicoli = {Gina, Hiro, Kevin}

• Remaining: Frank and Laurie to Raimes and Thompson.  

• Constraint 1: Frank not in Raimes? Let’s check both possibilities:  

   If Frank in Raimes → Kevin in Thompson. But Kevin is in Sicoli, so Kevin not in Thompson → contradiction. So Frank not in Raimes.  
   Then Kevin not in Thompson (OK, Kevin in Sicoli).  
   So Frank → Thompson, Laurie → Raimes.  
• Constraint 2: Frank not sole? Frank in Thompson with no one else? Wait: Thompson: Frank (alone), Raimes: Laurie (alone).  

   Then Frank is sole on his case. Then Gina cannot be sole (but she’s in Sicoli with others, so not sole). That’s fine: exactly one of them is sole — here Frank is sole, Gina not sole. ✓  
   So C is possible.

Option D: Sicoli = {Gina, Hiro, Laurie}

• Remaining: Frank and Kevin to Raimes and Thompson.  

• Constraint 1: If Frank in Raimes → Kevin in Thompson. That’s possible: Raimes: Frank, Thompson: Kevin.  

   Check constraint 2: Frank in Raimes alone? No, Raimes has only Frank? Wait, Raimes: Frank (1 person), Thompson: Kevin (1 person). Yes, both cases have 1 person.  
   Then Frank is sole on his case. Gina is in Sicoli with others → not sole. So exactly one (Frank) is sole. ✓  
   Alternatively, if Frank not in Raimes: Then Frank in Thompson, Kevin in Raimes. Then Kevin not in Thompson automatically. But then Frank sole? Thompson: Frank alone, Raimes: Kevin alone. Again Frank sole, Gina not sole. ✓  
   So D is possible.

Option E: Sicoli = {Hiro, Kevin, Laurie}

• Remaining: Frank and Gina to Raimes and Thompson.  

• Constraint 1: Frank not in Raimes? Check: If Frank in Raimes → Kevin in Thompson. But Kevin is in Sicoli, so Kevin not in Thompson → contradiction. So Frank not in Raimes.  

   So Frank in Thompson, Gina in Raimes.  
• Constraint 2: Frank sole? Thompson: Frank alone, Raimes: Gina alone. Then both Frank and Gina are sole. That violates “not both” in constraint 2.  

   So impossible.  

Thus E is impossible.

Step 4 – Conclusion

The correct option is: E

The correct option is: E

At least one paralegal will be assigned to each case. The following conditions must apply: Either Frank is assigned to Raimes and Kevin is assigned to Thompson, or Frank is not assigned to Raimes and Kevin is not assigned to Thompson. Either Frank is the sole paralegal assigned to his case or Gina is the sole paralegal assigned to her case, but not both. Hiro is assigned to Sicoli.
question: If exactly two of the paralegals are assigned to the Thompson case, then which one of the following could be the complete assignment of paralegals to the Raimes case?
options: A) Gina
B) Kevin
C) Laurie
D) Gina, Kevin
E) Kevin, Laurie
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason it out step by step.  

Step 1 – Interpret the constraints  

We have 5 paralegals: F, G, H, K, L.  
Cases: R, S, T.  
Each paralegal assigned to exactly one case.  
At least one per case.  

(1) Either (F to R and K to T) OR (F not to R and K not to T).  
So F and K are “linked” in assignment to R and T: either both are assigned to R and T respectively, or neither is in that specific pairing.  

(2) Either F is the sole paralegal on his case OR G is the sole paralegal on her case, but not both.  
So exactly one of them is alone on their case; the other is not alone.  

(3) H is assigned to S.  

Step 2 – Extra condition for this question  

Exactly two paralegals are assigned to T.  

So T has 2 people; the other 3 paralegals are split between R and S.  
Since H is in S, S has at least H.  

Step 3 – Try possibilities for T’s team  

T has 2 paralegals. Possible pairs for T:  

We know H is in S, so H is not in T. So T’s 2 are chosen from {F, G, K, L}.  

Step 4 – Apply constraint (1)  

Case A: F in R and K in T.  
Case B: F not in R and K not in T.  

Let’s test Case A first: F in R, K in T.  

Then T has K and one other from {G, L} (since H is in S, F is in R, so F not available for T).  
So T = {K, G} or {K, L}.  

Step 5 – Fill in the rest for Case A  

Subcase A1: T = {K, G}.  
Then remaining: F in R, H in S, L left to assign.  
L could go to R or S.  

If L to R: R = {F, L}, S = {H} only.  
Check (2): F is sole? No, R has 2 people. G is sole? G is in T with K, so G not sole. So neither F nor G is sole → violates (2). So impossible.  

If L to S: R = {F}, S = {H, L}.  
Check (2): F is sole (yes), G is sole? G in T with K, so not sole. So exactly one of F, G is sole → OK.  

So assignment: R = {F}, S = {H, L}, T = {K, G}. Works.  

Subcase A2: T = {K, L}.  
Then remaining: F in R, H in S, G left.  

If G to R: R = {F, G}, S = {H}.  
Check (2): F sole? No. G sole? G in R with F, so not sole. Neither sole → violates (2).  

If G to S: R = {F}, S = {H, G}.  
Check (2): F sole (yes), G sole? No. OK.  

So assignment: R = {F}, S = {H, G}, T = {K, L}. Works.  

So in Case A, R = {F} only.  

Step 6 – Case B: F not in R and K not in T  

Since K not in T, and T has 2 people, T’s members come from {F, G, L} (since H in S, K not in T).  

So T = {F, G} or {F, L} or {G, L}.  

Also F not in R, so F is in S or T. But if F in T, that’s fine.  

Subcase B1: T = {F, G}.  
Then K not in T (OK), F not in R (OK, F in T).  
Remaining: H in S, K and L to assign to R or S.  

R can’t be empty. K not in T, F not in R.  

Possibility: R = {K}, S = {H, L}? Then check (2): F sole? F in T with G, so not sole. G sole? G in T with F, so not sole → violates (2).  

So maybe R = {K, L}, S = {H}.  
Then (2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates.  

So maybe R = {L}, S = {H, K}.  
Then (2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates.  

So T = {F, G} fails because then neither F nor G is sole (they are together in T).  

Subcase B2: T = {F, L}.  
Then F not in R (OK), K not in T (OK).  
Remaining: H in S, G and K to assign to R or S.  

Possibility: R = {G}, S = {H, K}.  
(2): F sole? F in T with L → not sole. G sole? G alone in R → yes. So exactly one of F, G is sole → OK.  

Possibility: R = {K}, S = {H, G}.  
(2): F sole? No. G sole? G in S with H → no. Neither sole → violates.  

Possibility: R = {G, K}, S = {H}.  
(2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates.  

So only R = {G} works here.  

Subcase B3: T = {G, L}.  
Then F not in R, K not in T (OK).  
Remaining: H in S, F and K to assign to R or S.  

But F not in R, so F in S. Then R can have K only? Or R empty? No, R must have at least one.  

So R = {K}, S = {H, F}.  
(2): F sole? No (S has H and F). G sole? G in T with L → no. Violates.  

R = {K, ?} — no one else left besides K for R, since F in S, G and L in T, H in S. So R = {K} only.  

So R = {K}, S = {H, F}, T = {G, L}.  
(2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates.  

So B3 fails.  

Step 7 – Collect possible R assignments from working subcases  

From Case A: R = {F} in all working subcases.  

From Case B:  
B2: R = {G} works.  

So possible R teams given “exactly 2 in T” are: {F} and {G}.  

The question: “which could be the complete assignment of paralegals to the Raimes case?”  

Options:  
A) Gina → yes, from B2.  
B) Kevin → no, not possible (we saw Kevin alone in R fails because it violates (2) in cases we checked). Let’s check: If R = {K}, then from (1): K in R means F in R? No: (1) says: either (F in R and K in T) or (F not in R and K not in T). If K in R, then K not in T, so we are in second disjunct: F not in R and K not in T. But here K not in T is true, but K in R means F not in R. Then F in S or T. Try F in S: then T has 2 from {G, L}. Then (2): F sole? F in S with H? Possibly S = {H, F} if no one else, but then R = {K}, T = {G, L}. Then (2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates. So R = {K} impossible. So B is out.  

C) Laurie → R = {L} possible? Try: R = {L}, then from (1): L in R means nothing directly, but check (1): F in R? No, so we are in “F not in R and K not in T”. So K not in T. Then T has 2 from {F, G} (since H in S, L in R, K not in T). So T = {F, G}. Then S = {H, K}. (2): F sole? No (T has F, G). G sole? No. Violates. So C out.  

D) Gina, Kevin → R = {G, K}. Then (1): F in R? No, so second disjunct: F not in R and K not in T. But K in R, so K not in T is fine. Then T has 2 from {F, L} (since H in S, G in R, K in R). So T = {F, L}. Then S = {H}. (2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates. So D out.  

E) Kevin, Laurie → R = {K, L}. Then (1): F in R? No, so F not in R and K not in T. But K in R, so K not in T is fine. Then T has 2 from {F, G}. So T = {F, G}. Then S = {H}. (2): F sole? No. G sole? No. Violates. So E out.  

So only A works.  

Step 8 – Conclusion  

The only possible R assignment from the options is Gina alone.  

The correct option is: A
