question: If one of the cases has Gina and Laurie as the only paralegals assigned to it, then each of the following must be false EXCEPT:
options: A) Frank is assigned to the Raimes case.
B) Frank is assigned to the Sicoli case.
C) Gina is assigned to the Raimes case.
D) Kevin is assigned to the Raimes case.
E) Laurie is assigned to the Thompson case.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through this step by step.  

Step 1 – Interpret the constraints  

We have 5 paralegals: F, G, H, K, L.  
3 cases: R, S, T.  
Each case has at least 1 paralegal.  
H is assigned to S.  

Constraint 1:  
Either (F assigned to R and K assigned to T) OR (F not assigned to R and K not assigned to T).  

So F’s assignment to R and K’s assignment to T are logically equivalent:  
F:R ↔ K:T.  

Constraint 2:  
Either F is sole on his case OR G is sole on her case, but not both.  

So exactly one of these is true:  
• F is alone on his case.  

• G is alone on her case.  

Step 2 – Extra condition for this question  

One case has G and L as the only paralegals assigned to it.  
So G and L are together on some case, and no one else is on that case.  

That case cannot be S, because H is in S already, so S has at least H. So G&L case is either R or T.  

Step 3 – Try possibilities for G&L case  

Case A: G&L in R  
Then R = {G, L}.  
H is in S.  
Remaining paralegals: F, K must be assigned to cases, not R (since R full with G&L).  
Possible case assignments left: S has H already; T is empty so far.  

We must place F and K into S or T.  
But S can have more than H; T must have at least 1.  

Constraint 1: F:R ↔ K:T.  
But F is not in R (since R has G&L), so F:R is false ⇒ K:T is false ⇒ K not in T.  
So K must be in S.  
Then F must be in S or T. But T now has nobody (K not in T), so F must be in T to fill T.  
So: R = {G, L}, S = {H, K}, T = {F}.  

Check:  
F’s case is T, he is alone in T ⇒ F is sole on his case ⇒ that makes “F is sole” true.  
Then G is sole? G’s case is R, but R has G&L ⇒ G is not sole ⇒ OK, exactly one of F sole / G sole is true (F sole is true, G sole false) ⇒ Constraint 2 satisfied.  
Constraint 1: F:R? No. K:T? No ⇒ OK.  
H in S? Yes.  

So assignment works: R=GL, S=HK, T=F.  

Case B: G&L in T  
Then T = {G, L}.  
H in S.  
Remaining: F, K to be placed in R or S.  

Constraint 1: F:R ↔ K:T.  
But K:T? K is not in T (T has G&L), so K:T false ⇒ F:R false ⇒ F not in R.  
So F must be in S.  
Then K must be in R or S. But R currently empty, so K must be in R (since R needs at least 1).  

So: R = {K}, S = {H, F}, T = {G, L}.  

Check:  
F’s case is S, S has H and F ⇒ F not sole.  
G’s case is T, T has G&L ⇒ G not sole.  
So both “F sole” and “G sole” are false ⇒ violates Constraint 2 (exactly one must be true).  

So Case B is impossible.  

Thus only possible scenario: R = {G, L}, S = {H, K}, T = {F}.  

Step 4 – Check the options for “must be false EXCEPT”  

We want the statement that is not necessarily false (i.e., could be true or must be true).  

From our valid assignment:  
A) F assigned to R? No ⇒ false.  
B) F assigned to S? No (F in T) ⇒ false.  
C) G assigned to R? Yes ⇒ true! So this must be the answer.  
D) K assigned to R? No (K in S) ⇒ false.  
E) L assigned to T? No (L in R) ⇒ false.  

So only C is true in the valid scenario, so it’s not false.  

Step 5 – Confirm no other valid assignment  

We found only one valid assignment given G&L together. So the facts are fixed.  

The correct option is: C

options: A) Gina
B) Laurie
C) Gina, Kevin
D) Gina, Laurie
E) Kevin, Laurie
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

Step 1: Interpret the constraints  
• 5 paralegals: F, G, H, K, L.  

• 3 cases: R, S, T.  

• Each case has at least 1 paralegal.  

• H is assigned to Sicoli. (So Hiro is fixed in S.)  

Constraint 1:  
Either (F assigned to R and K assigned to T) OR (F not assigned to R and K not assigned to T).  

This is an XOR (exclusive or) of two scenarios:  
(1) F in R and K in T.  
(2) F not in R and K not in T.  

Constraint 2:  
Either F is the sole paralegal on his case OR G is the sole paralegal on her case, but not both.  

So exactly one of these is true:  
• F is alone in his case.  

• G is alone in her case.  

Step 2: Try each option for Thompson case  

We check which assignment to T is impossible given constraints.  

Option A: T = {G}  

Then:  
• H is in S.  

• Remaining: F, K, L for R and S. S already has H, maybe more. R has at least 1.  

Check constraint 1: F in R and K in T? No, K not in T. So first scenario false.  
So must have: F not in R and K not in T. K not in T is true (since T = G only). So need F not in R. So F in S.  

So: F in S, H in S, G in T, K and L for R and S? Wait, S already has F, H. Could have K or L there too.  

Let’s assign: F in S, H in S, G in T, K in R, L in S (for example).  

Check constraint 2: F alone? No, S has H, L. G alone? Yes, T has only G. So exactly one of (F alone, G alone) is true? Yes, G alone is true, F alone false. Works.  

So A possible.  

Option B: T = {L}  

Constraint 1: F in R and K in T? No, K not in T. So first scenario false. So must have F not in R and K not in T. K not in T is true. So F not in R → F in S.  

So: F in S, H in S, L in T, K in R, G in R or S?  

Try: F, H, G in S; L in T; K in R.  

Constraint 2: F alone? No, S has 3. G alone? No. Violation: neither F alone nor G alone. So fails.  

Try rearranging to satisfy constraint 2: We need exactly one of F alone or G alone true.  

If F alone: F’s case has only F. But F in S, so S = {F, H}? That’s 2 people, not alone. So F alone impossible if H in S fixed (unless H is only other in S? Wait, alone means exactly 1 in that case). So F alone means S = {F} only, but H must be in S — impossible. So F alone is impossible (since H is in S, F in S means S has at least F and H). So F cannot be alone.  

Therefore, for any valid assignment, G alone must be true.  

So G’s case has only G.  

Back to Option B: T = {L}. G alone means G’s case is a singleton containing G.  

Cases: R, S, T. G not in T (since T = L only). So G in R or S.  

If G in R alone: R = {G}. Then K? K not in T (since T = L only), so K in S. F? F not in R (since R = G only), so F in S. So S = {F, H, K}. T = {L}. R = {G}.  

Check constraint 1: F not in R (true), K not in T (true). Works.  

Constraint 2: G alone true, F alone false. Works.  

So B possible.  

Option C: T = {G, K}  

Constraint 1: Check scenarios:  
Scenario 1: F in R and K in T? K in T is true. So need F in R. So possible: F in R, K in T.  

Scenario 2: F not in R and K not in T — but K in T, so scenario 2 false. So must use scenario 1: F in R and K in T.  

So F in R, K in T.  

Now: T = {G, K}. So G in T, K in T.  

H in S.  

Remaining: L must go somewhere.  

Case R: at least F, maybe L. S: at least H, maybe L.  

Constraint 2: exactly one of F alone, G alone.  

G alone? G’s case is T, which has 2 people (G, K), so G not alone. So G alone false.  

Thus F alone must be true. So R = {F} only.  

So L not in R, so L in S.  

So: R = {F}, S = {H, L}, T = {G, K}.  

Check: each case at least 1: yes.  

Constraint 1: F in R (yes), K in T (yes). Works.  

Constraint 2: F alone true, G alone false. Works.  

So C possible.  

Option D: T = {G, L}  

Constraint 1: Two scenarios:  

If scenario 1: F in R and K in T? But K not in T (T = G, L), so false. So must use scenario 2: F not in R and K not in T. K not in T is true. So F not in R → F in S.  

So F in S, H in S, T = {G, L}, K not in T → K in R.  

So: R = {K}, S = {F, H}, T = {G, L} is forced (since L in T, G in T, all assigned).  

Check constraint 2: F alone? S has F, H → no. G alone? T has 2 → no. So neither true → violates constraint 2.  

Impossible.  

So D is impossible.  

Option E: T = {K, L}  

Constraint 1:  

Scenario 1: F in R and K in T? K in T true, so need F in R. So F in R.  

Scenario 2: F not in R and K not in T — but K in T, so scenario 2 false. So scenario 1 holds: F in R, K in T.  

So: F in R, K in T, H in S, T = {K, L}, so L in T.  

Remaining: G not assigned yet. G in R or S.  

Constraint 2: exactly one of F alone, G alone.  

If F alone: R = {F} only, so G in S. Then: R = {F}, S = {H, G}, T = {K, L}. Works: F alone true, G alone false.  

If G alone: Then G’s case singleton. G in R or S? If G in R alone: R = {F, G}? That’s 2, not alone. So G alone means G’s case = {G}. So G not in R with F, so G in S alone? But H in S fixed, so S has at least H and G → not alone. So G alone impossible (since the only case G could be alone is if we put G in R without F, but F in R required, so R would have F and G → not alone; or G in T alone? But T has K, L, so no). So G alone impossible here. So only possibility: F alone true.  

We already found one: R = {F}, S = {H, G}, T = {K, L}. Works.  

So E possible.  

Only D fails.  

The correct option is: D

question: If Kevin is the sole paralegal assigned to one of the cases then which one of the following lists all of the paralegals any one of
options: A) Frank, Kevin, Laurie
B) Frank, Kevin
C) Frank
D) Gina
E) Kevin
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1 – Understanding the setup  
We have 5 paralegals: F, G, H, K, L.  
3 cases: R, S, T.  
At least 1 per case.  
H is assigned to S (fixed).  

Step 2 – First condition  
Either (F assigned to R and K assigned to T) OR (F not assigned to R and K not assigned to T).  

That means: F and K are paired in terms of R and T assignments:  
• Possibility 1: F in R, K in T.

context: A record producer is planning the contents of a CD consisting of a sequence of exactly five instrumental pieces—Reciprocity, Salammbo, Trapezoid, Vancouver, and Wisteria. To create and sustain certain moods, the sequence of pieces will satisfy the following constraints: Salammbo must be earlier than Vancouver. Trapezoid must either be earlier than both Reciprocity and Salammbo or later than both Reciprocity and Salammbo. Wisteria must either be earlier than both Reciprocity and Trapezoid or later than both Reciprocity and Trapezoid.
question: The five pieces could appear in which one of the following sequences on the CD, in order from first to last?
options: A) Reciprocity, Trapezoid, Wisteria, Salammbo, Vancouver
B) Salammbo, Reciprocity, Trapezoid, Vancouver, Wisteria
C) Trapezoid, Wisteria, Salammbo, Vancouver, Reciprocity
D) Vancouver, Wisteria, Salammbo, Reciprocity, Trapezoid
E) Wisteria, Salammbo, Vancouver, Trapezoid, Reciprocity
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each constraint step by step.  

Constraint 1: Salammbo earlier than Vancouver.  
S < V (S before V in the sequence).  

Constraint 2: Trapezoid either earlier than both Reciprocity and Salammbo, or later than both Reciprocity and Salammbo.  
T < R and T < S  OR  T > R and T > S.  

Constraint 3: Wisteria either earlier than both Reciprocity and Trapezoid, or later than both Reciprocity and Trapezoid.  
W < R and W < T  OR  W > R and W > T.  

Option A: R, T, W, S, V  
• S < V? S is 4th, V is 5th → yes.  

• T relative to R and S: T is 2nd, R is 1st → T > R? No, T is after R? Wait: positions: 1:R, 2:T, 3:W, 4:S, 5:V.  

T is after R? No, T is before R? No, T is after R? Actually 2nd is after 1st? Yes, 2 is after 1, so T > R.  
S is 4th, T is 2nd → T > S? No, T is before S. So T > R but T < S → fails constraint 2 (must be earlier than both or later than both).  
❌ A fails.  

Option B: S, R, T, V, W  
• S < V? S 1st, V 4th → yes.  

• T relative to R and S: R is 2nd, T is 3rd → T > R? Yes. S is 1st, T is 3rd → T > S? Yes. So T is later than both → valid for constraint 2.  

• W relative to R and T: R is 2nd, T is 3rd, W is 5th → W > R and W > T → valid for constraint 3.  

✅ B satisfies all.  

Option C: T, W, S, V, R  
• S < V? S 3rd, V 4th → yes.  

• T relative to R and S: T is 1st, R is 5th → T < R? Yes. S is 3rd → T < S? Yes. So T earlier than both → valid.  

• W relative to R and T: T is 1st, W is 2nd → W > T? Yes. R is 5th → W < R? Yes. But W > T and W < R means W is between T and R, not earlier than both or later than both → fails constraint 3.  

❌ C fails.  

Option D: V, W, S, R, T  
• S < V? S is 3rd, V is 1st → S after V? No, S before V? No, S is after V? Actually 3rd is after 1st? Yes, so S > V → fails constraint 1.  

❌ D fails.  

Option E: W, S, V, T, R  
• S < V? S 2nd, V 3rd → yes.  

• T relative to R and S: T is 4th, R is 5th → T < R? No, T > R? Wait: 4th before 5th? Yes, so T < R? No, T is before R? Yes, T is 4th, R is 5th → T < R.  

S is 2nd, T is 4th → T > S? Yes. So T < R but T > S → not both earlier or both later → fails constraint 2.  
❌ E fails.  

Only B satisfies all.  

The correct option is: B

If T=3, R after T → R=5 impossible (V=5) → so T cannot be 3.  
So T in {1, 2}.  

R after T: R can be 3 or 5, but 5 is V, so R=3 only possibility.

T is 1 or 2. If T=1, W earlier than 1 impossible. So T cannot be 1 if W earlier than both.

Case 2: W later than both R(3) and T(1 or 2):  
Later than R(3) means W=4 or 5, but 4=S, 5=V, so impossible.  

So only possibility: W earlier than both R and T.  

But earlier than T means W < T. T is 1 or 2. If T=1, W earlier than 1 impossible. So T cannot be 1.  

Thus T=2, W=1.  

Final order: W=1, T=2, R=3, S=4, V=5.

1. S(4) < V(5) ✓  
2. T(2) earlier than R(3) and S(4) ✓  
3. W(1) earlier than R(3) and T(2) ✓

A) R earlier than W? No, W=1, R=3 → W earlier than R.  
B) S earlier than T? S=4, T=2 → No.  
C) T earlier than R? Yes, T=2, R=3.

E) W earlier than T? Yes, W=1, T=2.

reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

Pieces: R, S, T, V, W.  
Positions: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.  

Given: R = 1 (fixed for this question).  

Constraint 1: S earlier than V.  
So S < V in position number.  

Constraint 2: T is either earlier than both R and S, or later than both R and S.  
Since R = 1, T cannot be earlier than R (no position before 1).  
So T must be later than both R and S.  
Thus: S < T and R < T (R=1 already ensures R < T unless T=1, impossible).  
So S must be before T.  

Constraint 3: W is either earlier than both R and T, or later than both R and T.  
Since R = 1, W cannot be earlier than R.  
So W must be later than both R and T.  
Thus: T < W.  

Order constraints summary:  
R = 1.  
S < V.  
S < T.  
T < W.  
So: R=1, S < T < W, and S < V.  
Also all positions distinct.  

Possible positions:  
R = 1.  
S can be 2, 3, or 4? Let’s check: S < T < W means T and W are after S, and T < W means at least 2 positions after S.  

So S can be at most position 3 (because if S=4, T=5, W would need position >5, impossible).  
So S ∈ {2, 3}.  

Case check S=2:  
Then T > 2, W > T.  
Possible T=3, W=4 or 5; or T=4, W=5.  
V > S=2, so V=3,4,5 but must fit around T,W constraints.  

Case check S=3:  
Then T > 3, so T=4, W=5.  
V > S=3, so V=4 or 5, but T=4, W=5 → V=5 possible if T=4, W=5? No, that would put V=5 after W=5 impossible (W=5 fixed). Wait, V=5 possible if W=5? No, two pieces can’t be same position. So if S=3, T=4, W=5, then V must be >3 and ≠4, ≠5 → impossible. So S=3 impossible.  

Thus S must be 2.  

So: R=1, S=2.  
T > 2, W > T.  
V > 2.  

Possible (T,W) pairs: (3,4), (3,5), (4,5).  
V > 2 and V ≠ T, W, R, S.  

Check options:  

A) T=2? Impossible because S=2 already. So A false.  

B) V=3? Possible if T=4, W=5, V=3. Let’s check constraints:  
Order: R=1, S=2, V=3, T=4, W=5.  
S(2) < V(3) ✓.  
S(2) < T(4) ✓, T(4) < W(5) ✓.  
All good. So B is possible.  

C) W=3? Impossible because T<W, T>2, so smallest T=3, W>3. So W cannot be 3.  

D) S=4? Impossible because we deduced S=2.  

E) T=5? Then W would need to be >5 impossible. So E false.  

Only B works.  

The correct option is: B

context: At a business symposium there will be exactly five speakers: Long, Molina, Xiao, Yoshida, and Zimmerman. Each speaker will give exactly one speech, in either the Gold Room or the Rose Room. D) Gold Room: Yoshida's, Long's, Molina's Rose Room: Zimmerman's, Xiao's
E) Gold Room: Zimmerman's, Molina's Rose Room: Xiao's, Yoshida's, Long's

3. If Long's speech is in the Gold Room, then Xiao's and Zimmerman's speeches must both be in the Rose Room.

  • Yoshida's speech is not earlier than Zimmerman's (Yoshida is after Zimmerman) ✓

Rose: Xiao, Zimmerman  

• Molina earlier than Long ✓ (same room)  

• Rose Room: Xiao at 1 PM, Zimmerman at 2 PM → Xiao is earlier than Zimmerman → violates constraint 2. ✗

Rose: Zimmerman, Yoshida

  • Xiao's time slot number ≥ Zimmerman's time slot number (1 PM = slot 1, 2 PM = slot 2, 3 PM = slot 3)  

  • Yoshida's time slot number ≥ Zimmerman's time slot number  

Here: Xiao at 1 PM in Gold, Zimmerman at 1 PM in Rose → same time slot → Xiao's is not earlier than Zimmerman's (it's simultaneous) — is that allowed? "Not earlier" means "not before" → includes simultaneous or after. So simultaneous is okay. ✓  
Yoshida: in Rose Room at 2 PM, Zimmerman at 1 PM in Rose → Yoshida after Zimmerman ✓  

• Long's speech in Gold Room → Xiao must be in Rose Room ✗ (Xiao is in Gold Room)  

Eliminate C.

Rose: Zimmerman, Xiao  

• Molina earlier than Long? No, Molina is after Long in Gold Room ✗

Eliminate E.  

Only A satisfies all constraints.

So Z is not after X or Y; equivalently, Z is the same time as or earlier than both X and Y. But since only one speech per time slot per room, “earlier” means strictly earlier in time across the whole symposium, not just room.)  
6. If L in G, then X in R and Z in R.

Effect of constraint 5 (original):  
Z must be at 1 PM or 2 PM, but not 3 PM? Let’s check: Could Z be at 3 PM? If Z at 3 PM, then X and Y cannot be earlier than Z, so they’d have to be at 3 PM or later, but 3 PM is last slot, so they’d have to be at 3 PM too — impossible because only one speech at 3 PM. So Z cannot be at 3 PM.  
Thus Z is at 1 PM or 2 PM.  

Also, X and Y can be at 2 PM or 3 PM if Z at 1 PM; or at 3 PM if Z at 2 PM; or same time as Z if in different rooms? Wait, times are global: 1 PM (two speeches, one in each room), 2 PM (two speeches), 3 PM (one speech in one room). So “earlier” means earlier in the sequence of times: 1 PM < 2 PM < 3 PM.  

So constraint: Z’s time ≤ X’s time and Z’s time ≤ Y’s time.  
So Z must be strictly earlier than at least one of X or Y unless X and Y both at 3 PM? Let’s check: If Z at 2 PM, then X and Y must be at 2 PM or 3 PM. But only one speech per room per time, so if Z at 2 PM, then X and Y at 2 PM is impossible (two rooms, but three people: Z, X, Y can’t all be at 2 PM unless one is in same room/time — impossible). So if Z at 2 PM, then X and Y must both be at 3 PM — but only one 3 PM slot, so impossible.  

Thus Z cannot be at 2 PM either!  
So Z must be at 1 PM.  

Yes:  
• Z at 1 PM: Then X and Y can be at 1, 2, or 3 PM but not earlier than 1 PM (fine). But if at 1 PM, they’d have to be in different rooms from Z (since only one per room per time). So possible.  

• Z at 2 PM: Then X and Y at 2 PM or 3 PM. But at 2 PM: only two rooms, so at most two speeches at 2 PM. If Z at 2 PM, then X and Y can’t both be at 2 PM (only one slot left at 2 PM). So at least one of X or Y at 3 PM. But 3 PM is only one slot, so both can’t be at 3 PM. So one at 2 PM (other room) and one at 3 PM? That works: Z at 2 PM in G, X at 2 PM in R, Y at 3 PM in G or R? Wait 3 PM is only in one room. So Y at 3 PM, X at 2 PM works. But then is X earlier than Z? No, X at 2 PM same time as Z, so allowed. Similarly Y at 3 PM is after Z. So possible.  

So Z at 2 PM is possible if X at 2 PM (other room) and Y at 3 PM, or vice versa.  

But check: If Z at 2 PM, then X at 2 PM (same time) allowed, Y at 3 PM allowed. Or X at 3 PM, Y at 2 PM allowed. So yes possible.  

So my earlier reasoning that Z can’t be at 2 PM was wrong — because they can be at same time in different rooms.  

So the only restriction from “neither X nor Y earlier than Z” is: Z is not after X or Y in time. So Z must be the earliest or tied earliest among {Z, X, Y} in terms of times (1, 2, 3).  

So Z’s time ≤ X’s time and Z’s time ≤ Y’s time.  

Thus Z cannot be at 3 PM (since then X and Y would have to be at 3 PM too, impossible).  
Z can be at 2 PM only if X and Y are at 2 PM or 3 PM, and at least one at 2 PM to share the 2 PM slot with Z (since if both at 3 PM impossible). So if Z at 2 PM, then one of X or Y at 2 PM in other room, the other at 3 PM.  
Z at 1 PM: no restriction on X, Y except not earlier than 1 PM (so any).  

So original constraint ⇒ Z at 1 PM or 2 PM, and at least one of X or Y must be at same time as Z if Z at 2 PM.  

Now, which option is equivalent?

Option A: “Long’s speech must be at 3 PM.”  
• Not necessarily true in original. So not equivalent.

Option B: “Molina’s speech cannot be earlier than Zimmerman’s.”  
• That means M ≥ Z in time. In original, M and L same room, M before L. Z at 1 or 2 PM. Could M be after Z? Possibly, but not forced. This changes M’s time relative to Z, not obviously equivalent to original constraint.

Option C: “Either X’s speech or Y’s speech must be after Z’s.”  
• That means: at least one of X or Y has time > Z’s time.  

• Original: Z ≤ X and Z ≤ Y. So it’s possible that both X and Y = Z time (different rooms). Then C would be false (neither after Z). So C is not equivalent to original; original allows X=Y=Z time, C forbids that. So C is stronger.

Option D: “Either X’s speech or Y’s speech or both must be at 2 PM.”  
• This is unrelated to Z’s time. Not equivalent.

Option E: “Zimmerman’s speech must be at 1 PM.”  
• Does original require Z at 1 PM? No, Z could be at 2 PM. But check if Z at 2 PM possible under original:  

If Z at 2 PM, then X and Y at 2 PM or 3 PM. But at 2 PM: only two rooms, so one more slot at 2 PM besides Z’s. So one of X or Y at 2 PM, other at 3 PM. That works. So Z at 2 PM possible. So E is stronger than original (forces Z=1PM always). So not equivalent.

Wait — maybe I made a mistake: If Z at 2 PM, then to satisfy Z ≤ X and Z ≤ Y:  
• If X at 3 PM, Y at 3 PM impossible (only one 3 PM).  

So if Z at 2 PM, then one of X or Y at 2 PM (other room), other at 3 PM. That’s fine.  

So original allows Z at 2 PM.  

But does the original constraint have same effect as E? Let’s test: If we force Z at 1 PM (option E), does that mimic the original constraint’s restrictions?  

Original: Z at 1 or 2 PM. If we force Z at 1 PM, then X, Y free (just not earlier than 1 PM). That’s less restrictive than original? No — original also forbids Z at 3 PM, and forces at least one of X or Y to be at same time as Z if Z at 2 PM.  

But maybe in the presence of other constraints, Z at 2 PM is impossible anyway? Let’s check other constraints:  

M before L, same room. If L in G, then X in R, Z in R.  

Try Z at 2 PM:  
Case 1: Z in R at 2 PM. Then if L in G, Z in R (ok). But then X in R (from constraint 6 if L in G). But then X and Z both in R at 2 PM? Impossible. So if Z at 2 PM in R, then L cannot be in G (otherwise X in R at 2 PM conflict with Z). So L in R? But M before L in same room, so M, L in R. Then L in R means constraint 6 not triggered. So possible.  

So not automatically impossible. So Z at 2 PM possible. So E is not equivalent.  

But maybe the answer is B: “M cannot be earlier than Z.”  
If M not earlier than Z, then M = Z or M after Z.  
But M before L, same room. Could that force Z at 1 PM? Not necessarily.  

But maybe with all constraints, B is equivalent. Let’s test:  

Original: Z at 1 or 2 PM. If we change to B: M not earlier than Z.  
We know M before L. If Z at 2 PM, then M at 2 PM or 3 PM. But M at 2 PM (same time as Z) and M before L ⇒ L at 3 PM. Possible. But does that mess up things? Not obviously.  

But does B imply that X and Y not earlier than Z? Not directly. So B seems unrelated.  

Given the options, the only one that ensures Z is not at 3 PM and forces Z to be before or same time as both X and Y is none of them exactly. But standard LSAT logic: sometimes the correct substitution is one that forces Z to be first in time among the five? But here, if Z at 1 PM, then automatically neither X nor Y earlier than Z.  

But original allows Z at 2 PM if one of X or Y at 2 PM. So equivalent condition must allow that. Option C says: at least one of X or Y after Z. That means Z cannot be after both X and Y, so Z at 3 PM impossible. Also, if Z at 2 PM, then one of X or Y at 3 PM (after Z), the other at 2 PM (same time) allowed. That matches original.  

Yes! Because original: Z ≤ X and Z ≤ Y. So not both X and Y before Z ⇒ It is equivalent to: At least one of X or Y is after or same time as Z? Actually original: Z time ≤ X time and Z time ≤ Y time ⇒ Z is first or tied with both. That means: It is not the case that (X < Z or Y < Z). So X ≥ Z and Y ≥ Z.  

Option C: Either X > Z or Y > Z. Is that equivalent? No — original allows X=Z and Y=Z, but C requires at least one of X or Y > Z. So C is stronger.  

But maybe in the context of the whole problem, X=Z and Y=Z is impossible due to room constraints? With only 2 rooms per time, X=Z and Y=Z means three people at same time — impossible. So indeed, X=Z and Y=Z impossible. So in reality, original means: Z ≤ X, Z ≤ Y, and not all three at same time. So at least one of X or Y > Z. So C is equivalent!  

Yes! That’s the key. Because you can’t have three speeches at same time, so Z, X, Y cannot all be equal. So if Z ≤ X and Z ≤ Y, then at least one of X or Y must be > Z. So C is exactly equivalent.  

So answer is C.

The correct option is: C

context: During the seventeenth century, three families—the Trents, the Williamses, and the Yandells—owned the five buildings that constituted the center of their village—the forge, the granary, the inn, the mill, and the stable. Each family owned at least one of the buildings and each building was owned by exactly one of the families. The historical evidence establishes the following about the ownership of the buildings: The Williamses owned more of the buildings than the Yandells owned. Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge. Either the Trents owned the stable or the Yandells owned the inn, or both.
question: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of each family to the building or buildings it owned?
options: A) Trents: the granary, the stable Williamses: the inn, the mill Yandells: the forge
B) Trents: the granary, the mill Williamses: the inn, the stable Yandells: the forge
C) Trents: the forge, the mill Williamses: the granary, the stable Yandells: the inn
D) Trents: the forge, the granary Williamses: the mill Yandells: the inn, the stable
E) Trents: the stable Williamses: the inn, the mill Yandells: the forge, the granary
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

1. Restate the facts  
• 3 families: Trents (T), Williamses (W), Yandells (Y)  

• 5 buildings: forge (F), granary (G), inn (I), mill (M), stable (S)  

• Each family owns at least 1 building.  

• Each building owned by exactly 1 family.  

Constraints:  
1. W owned more buildings than Y owned.  
2. Neither I nor M belonged to the owner of F.  
3. Either T owned S, or Y owned I, or both.  

2. Check each option  

Option A: T: G, S; W: I, M; Y: F  

• Constraint 1: W owns 2, Y owns 1 → 2 > 1 ✅  

• Constraint 2: Owner of F is Y. I owned by W, M owned by W → I and M not owned by owner of F (Y) ✅  

• Constraint 3: T owns S ✅ (so “either T owns S or Y owns I” is true)  

✅ All constraints satisfied.  

3. Quickly check others to ensure A is correct  

Option B: T: G, M; W: I, S; Y: F  

• Constraint 1: W owns 2, Y owns 1 → 2 > 1 ✅  

• Constraint 2: Owner of F is Y. I owned by W, M owned by T → I and M not owned by Y ✅  

• Constraint 3: T owns S? No. Y owns I? No. So “either T owns S or Y owns I” is false ❌  

❌ Fails.  

Option C: T: F, M; W: G, S; Y: I  

• Constraint 1: W owns 2, Y owns 1 → 2 > 1 ✅  

• Constraint 2: Owner of F is T. M owned by T → M belongs to owner of F ❌ (violates: neither I nor M belonged to owner of F)  

❌ Fails.  

Option D: T: F, G; W: M; Y: I, S  

• Constraint 1: W owns 1, Y owns 2 → 1 > 2? No ❌  

❌ Fails.  

Option E: T: S; W: I, M; Y: F, G  

• Constraint 1: W owns 2, Y owns 2 → 2 > 2? No ❌  

❌ Fails.  

Only A satisfies all constraints.  

The correct option is: A

context: During the seventeenth century, three families—the Trents, the Williamses, and the Yandells—owned the five buildings that constituted the center of their village—the forge, the granary, the inn, the mill, and the stable. The historical evidence establishes the following about the ownership of the buildings: The Williamses owned more of the buildings than the Yandells owned. Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge. Either the Trents owned the stable or the Yandells owned the inn, or both.
question: Which one of the following is a pair of buildings that CANNOT both have been owned by the Trents?
options: A) the forge, the granary
B) the granary, the mill
C) the granary, the stable
D) the inn, the mill
E) the inn, the stable
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints

We have 5 buildings:  
F (forge), G (granary), I (inn), M (mill), S (stable)  
Families: T (Trents), W (Williamses), Y (Yandells)  

1. Williams > Yandells in number of buildings owned.  
   • Total 5 buildings, so possible distribution of counts:  

     W could have 3, Y 1, T 1; or W 2, Y 1, T 2; or W 2, Y 0, T 3; or W 3, Y 0, T 2; or W 3, Y 1, T 1; etc. But W > Y.

2. Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge.  
   • So F’s owner ≠ I’s owner, and F’s owner ≠ M’s owner.  

   • So F, I, M are all owned by different families? Not necessarily: I and M could be owned by the same family, but that family is not F’s owner. So F’s owner owns at most one of {I, M}? Actually, it says neither I nor M belongs to F’s owner → so F’s owner owns neither I nor M. So F’s owner owns only F possibly, or F plus G or S, but not I or M.

3. Either T owns S or Y owns I, or both.  
   • So at least one of (T has S) or (Y has I) is true.

Step 2 – Question: Which pair CANNOT both be owned by T?

We test each option by assuming T owns both buildings in the pair and see if constraints can be satisfied.

Option A: F and G both owned by T  
• If T owns F, then from constraint 2: T cannot own I or M.  

• So I and M must be owned by W and/or Y.  

• Constraint 3: Either T owns S or Y owns I (or both).  

  • If T owns S, then T owns F, G, S → 3 buildings.  

    ◦ Then W > Y: possible if W=2, Y=0, but Y=0 impossible because each family owns at least 1 building. So Y must have at least 1 building.  

    ◦ Remaining buildings after T has F, G, S: I and M remain for W and Y.  

    ◦ Y must have at least 1, so Y owns I or M. W gets the other.  

    ◦ Then W count = 1, Y count = 1 → violates W > Y.  

    ◦ So T cannot have 3 buildings if that forces W not > Y. Let’s check:  

      Total 5: T=3, W=1, Y=1 → W=Y, not allowed.  
      So impossible.  
  • If T does not own S, then from constraint 3: Y must own I.  

    ◦ T owns F, G (2 buildings).  

    ◦ S is not owned by T, so S owned by W or Y.  

    ◦ I owned by Y, M owned by ?  

    ◦ F’s owner (T) doesn’t own I or M, okay.  

    ◦ Let’s assign: T: F, G; Y: I, maybe more; W: maybe M, S.  

    ◦ We need W > Y:  

      Try: T: F, G (2); Y: I (1); W: M, S (2) → W=2, Y=1 → W>Y okay.  
      But then Y owns I, so constraint 3 satisfied (since T doesn’t own S).  
      This works:  
      F(T), G(T), I(Y), M(W), S(W) → W=2, Y=1, T=2.  
      Check: F’s owner T doesn’t own I(Y) or M(W) — okay.  
      W=2 > Y=1 — okay.  
      Either T owns S? No. Y owns I? Yes — okay.  
    ◦ So possible.  

So A is possible (F and G both by T).

Option B: G and M both owned by T  
• T owns G, M.  

• Constraint 2: F’s owner ≠ owner of I, ≠ owner of M.  

  • If T owns M, then F’s owner ≠ T. So F is not owned by T.  

• So F owned by W or Y.  

• Constraint 3: T owns S or Y owns I (or both).  

Try assignment:  
T: G, M (2 buildings).  
Let’s test:  
Case 1: T owns S → T: G, M, S (3 buildings).  
Remaining: F, I for W and Y.  
Y must have at least 1, W > Y.  
If Y=1, W=1 → W=Y not allowed.  
If Y=0 impossible. So T=3 impossible.  

Case 2: T does not own S → then Y owns I.  
T: G, M (2).  
Y owns I (1 building so far).  
Remaining: F, S for W and Y to own, plus Y already has I.  
We need W > Y.  
Possible: Y: I, F (2 buildings) → W owns S and maybe? Wait total 5: T: G, M (2); Y: I, F (2); W: S (1) → W=1, Y=2 → W not > Y, fails.  
Try: Y: I (1); W: F, S (2) → W=2, Y=1 → okay.  
Check: F’s owner W ≠ owner of I (Y) — okay; F’s owner W ≠ owner of M (T) — okay.  
So works:  
T: G, M; W: F, S; Y: I.  
W=2, Y=1, T=2.  
Constraint 3: T owns S? No; Y owns I? Yes — okay.  

So B is possible.

Option C: G and S both owned by T  
T: G, S (2 buildings).  
Constraint 3: T owns S — yes, so satisfied.  

We can assign:  
T: G, S; W: F, I; Y: M.  
Check: F’s owner W ≠ owner of I (W) — oh, that’s same, so F’s owner W owns I — violates “Neither I nor M belonged to owner of F”? Yes: F’s owner W owns I — not allowed. So reassign.  

We need F’s owner ≠ owner of I, ≠ owner of M.  
So F’s owner cannot own I or M.  

Try: T: G, S; W: F, M; Y: I.  
Check: F’s owner W owns M — not allowed.  

Try: T: G, S; W: I, M; Y: F.  
Check: F’s owner Y owns F only? Y owns F, but does Y own I or M? No, Y owns only F here. Then W owns I, M; T owns G, S.  
W=2, Y=1, T=2 → W>Y okay.  
Constraint 3: T owns S — yes.  
F’s owner Y ≠ owner of I (W) — okay; ≠ owner of M (W) — okay.  
Works.  

So C possible.

Option D: I and M both owned by T  
T owns I, M.  
Constraint 2: F’s owner ≠ owner of I (T) → so F’s owner ≠ T.  
F’s owner ≠ owner of M (T) — same conclusion: F not owned by T.  

So F owned by W or Y.  

Constraint 3: T owns S or Y owns I (or both).  
But T owns I here, so Y does not own I. So must have T owns S.  

Thus T owns I, M, S (3 buildings).  
Remaining: F, G for W and Y.  
Y at least 1, W > Y.  
If T=3, W and Y share 2 buildings.  
Possible splits: W=2, Y=0 impossible; W=1, Y=1 → W=Y not allowed; W=0, Y=2 impossible.  
So no way to have W>Y.  

Thus impossible.  

So D is the pair that cannot both be owned by T.

Step 3 – Check E quickly to confirm D is the answer  
E: I and S both owned by T.  
T: I, S.  
Constraint 2: F’s owner ≠ owner of I (T) → F not owned by T.  
F’s owner ≠ owner of M (T?) T doesn’t own M here necessarily. So M could be owned by T? Wait, if T owns M too, then F’s owner ≠ T automatically. But we’re testing only I and S owned by T, not M.  

Let’s test: T: I, S; assign M to W, F to W, G to Y.  
Then: T=2, W=2, Y=1 → W>Y okay.  
Constraint 3: T owns S — yes.  
F’s owner W ≠ owner of I (T) okay; ≠ owner of M (W) — oh, F’s owner W owns M — violates constraint 2. So rearrange:  

T: I, S; F to Y, M to W, G to W.  
Then: T=2, W=2 (M, G), Y=1 (F).  
Check: F’s owner Y ≠ I’s owner (T) okay; ≠ M’s owner (W) okay.  
W=2, Y=1 okay.  
Constraint 3: T owns S — yes.  
Works.  

So E possible.

Only D is impossible.

The correct option is: D

context: During the seventeenth century, three families—the Trents, the Williamses, and the Yandells—owned the five buildings that constituted the center of their village—the forge, the granary, the inn, the mill, and the stable. Each family owned at least one of the buildings and each building was owned by exactly one of the families. The historical evidence establishes the following about the ownership of the buildings: The Williamses owned more of the buildings than the Yandells owned. Neither the inn nor the mill belonged to the owner of the forge. Either the Trents owned the stable or the Yandells owned the inn, or both.
question: If the Yandells owned the mill, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) The Trents owned the forge.
B) The Trents owned the inn.
C) The Williamses owned the forge.
D) The Williamses owned the granary.
E) The Williamses owned the inn.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints  
We have 5 buildings: F (forge), G (granary), I (inn), M (mill), S (stable).  
Three families: T (Trents), W (Williamses), Y (Yandells).  
Each family owns at least 1 building; each building owned by exactly 1 family.  

Facts:  
1. W owned more buildings than Y owned.  
2. Neither I nor M belonged to the owner of F. (So F’s owner is different from I’s owner and from M’s owner.)  
3. Either T owned S, or Y owned I, or both.  

Step 2 – New condition: Y owns M  
From fact 2: F’s owner ≠ M’s owner. Since M is owned by Y, F’s owner ≠ Y. So F is owned by T or W.  

Step 3 – Possible building counts  
Total buildings: 5. W > Y in number owned.  
Since each family owns at least 1, possible (W, Y, T) counts:  
• Could be (3,1,1) or (2,1,2) or (3,2,0) not possible because T must own at least 1.  

• (3,1,1): W=3, Y=1, T=1.  

• (2,1,2): W=2, Y=1, T=2.  

• (2,2,1) is impossible because W > Y is strict.  

• (3,2,0) impossible because T owns at least 1.  

So possible distributions: (3,1,1) or (2,1,2).  

Step 4 – Y owns M, so Y’s buildings  
If Y=1, then Y owns only M.  
If Y=2, then Y owns M plus one other.  

Step 5 – Fact 3: Either T owns S, or Y owns I, or both.  
If Y=1 (only M), then Y does not own I. So T must own S.  

If Y=2, then maybe Y owns I, satisfying fact 3 automatically; or if Y doesn’t own I, then T owns S.  

Step 6 – Fact 2: F’s owner ≠ I’s owner, and F’s owner ≠ M’s owner (Y).  
So F’s owner is not Y.  

Step 7 – Try to see what must be true  

Case 1: Y=1 (Y owns only M).  
Then T owns S (from fact 3).  
W > Y means W owns at least 2.  
Possible assignments:  
Y: M.  
T: S, and maybe others.  
W: owns the rest.  

F’s owner ≠ Y (so F owned by T or W).  
F’s owner ≠ I’s owner.  

If F owned by T, then I’s owner ≠ T, so I owned by W.  
If F owned by W, then I’s owner ≠ W, so I owned by T.  

We must check both possibilities for consistency with counts.  

Counts: If Y=1, T owns at least S (1 building), W owns at least 2. Total 5:  
Possibility A: T=1 (only S), W=3 (F, G, I), Y=1 (M).  
Check: F owned by W, I owned by W → violates F’s owner ≠ I’s owner. So impossible.  

Possibility B: T=2 (S and G), W=2 (F, I), Y=1 (M).  
Check: F owned by W, I owned by W → violates F’s owner ≠ I’s owner. So impossible.  

Possibility C: T=2 (S and I), W=2 (F, G), Y=1 (M).  
Check: F owned by W, I owned by T → okay (F’s owner W ≠ I’s owner T).  
Also M owned by Y, F’s owner W ≠ Y, okay.  
This works: T: S, I; W: F, G; Y: M.  

Possibility D: T=3 (S, I, G), W=1 (F), Y=1 (M).  
Check: F owned by W, I owned by T → okay.  
But W=1, Y=1 violates W>Y. So impossible.  

So only possibility with Y=1 is: T owns S and I; W owns F and G; Y owns M.  

Thus if Y=1, T owns I.  

Case 2: Y=2 (Y owns M plus one other).  
Then W>2 (since W>Y and Y=2, so W≥3). Then T=0? No, T≥1.  
Total 5: W≥3, Y=2, T≥1 means W=3, Y=2, T=0 impossible (T≥1).  
So W=3, Y=2, T=0 impossible.  
W=2 impossible because W>Y means W≥3 if Y=2.  
So only W=3, Y=2, T=0 impossible because T≥1.  
Thus Y cannot be 2 because with 5 total, W>Y, Y=2 → W≥3, T≥1 → W+Y+T ≥ 3+2+1=6>5 impossible.  
So Y=2 and W≥3 and T≥1 → total ≥6, contradiction.  

Thus Y=2 is impossible.  

Step 8 – So only Y=1 case works  
From earlier, only valid assignment:  
Y: M  
T: S, I  
W: F, G  

So T owns I.  

Step 9 – Match to options  
Option B says “The Trents owned the inn.” That is true.  

A) T owned forge? No, W owns forge.  
C) W owned forge? True in our assignment, but must it be true? Could T own forge?  
Let’s check: If T owned forge, then I’s owner ≠ T, so I owned by W. But then T owns S (since Y doesn’t own I if Y=1), so T owns F and S, W owns I and G, Y owns M. Then counts: T=2, W=2, Y=1. W>Y okay. Check F’s owner T ≠ I’s owner W, okay. M’s owner Y ≠ F’s owner T, okay. This also works: T: F, S; W: I, G; Y: M.  

So T could own forge. So C is not necessarily true.  

But in both possibilities, T owns I?

1. Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common.  
2. Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common.  
3. Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons.  
4. If a bouquet has lilies, it must have roses but cannot have snapdragons.  
5. If a bouquet has tulips, it must have peonies.

B1: lilies, roses → has lilies ⇒ must have roses (✔) and no snapdragons (✔).  
B3: peonies, snapdragons, tulips → has tulips ⇒ must have peonies (✔).

B2 & B3: B2 has peonies, roses, tulips; B3 has peonies, snapdragons, tulips → common = peonies, tulips (2 kinds) (✔).  
B3 has snapdragons (✔).  
No rule violations.  

Option B  
B1: peonies, roses.  
B3: peonies, snapdragons, tulips → has tulips ⇒ must have peonies (✔).  
B1 & B3: both have peonies → violates rule 1 (✘).  

Option C

B2: roses, snapdragons, tulips → has tulips ⇒ must have peonies (✘) — B2 has no peonies. Violates rule 5.

Option E  
B3: lilies, roses → has lilies ⇒ cannot have snapdragons (✘) — but rule 3 says B3 must have snapdragons. Violates rules 3 and 4.  

Only A passes all checks.  

The correct option is: A

Step 2 – Bouquet 3’s composition  
Bouquet 3 has snapdragons (given).

So bouquet 3’s possible flowers: from {peonies, snapdragons, tulips} (since lilies, roses are out).  

Also, if bouquet 3 has tulips → must have peonies (rule 5).  

Step 3 – Bouquet 2 and Bouquet 3 share exactly 2 kinds  
Bouquet 3’s flower set is a subset of {peonies, snapdragons, tulips}.

• If bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, peonies, tulips} → all 3 flowers.  

• If bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, peonies} → 2 flowers.  

• If bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, tulips} → impossible because tulips require peonies.  

• If bouquet 3 = {snapdragons} only → impossible because bouquet 2 and bouquet 3 must share exactly 2 kinds, but bouquet 3 has only 1 kind.  

So bouquet 3 must have at least 2 flowers, one of which is snapdragons.  

Step 4 – Eliminate impossible bouquet 3 compositions  
Possible bouquet 3 sets:  
1. {snapdragons, peonies} → size 2.  
2. {snapdragons, peonies, tulips} → size 3.  

Bouquet 3 cannot have lilies or roses, so those are the only possibilities.  

Step 5 – Bouquet 2’s common flowers with bouquet 3  
Case 1: Bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, peonies}  
• Bouquet 2 must share exactly these 2 kinds with bouquet 3.  

• So bouquet 2 must contain both snapdragons and peonies, and no other flower from bouquet 3’s set (but bouquet 3 has only these 2 anyway). Bouquet 2 could have other flowers not in bouquet 3 (lilies, roses, tulips) but those don’t affect the count of common kinds.  

Case 2: Bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, peonies, tulips}  
• Bouquet 2 must share exactly 2 kinds with bouquet 3.  

• So bouquet 2 contains exactly 2 of {snapdragons, peonies, tulips}, not all 3.  

Step 6 – What must be true?  
Look at options:  

A) Lilies are in bouquet 2. — Not necessarily; bouquet 2 could be without lilies.  

B) Peonies are in bouquet 3. — Check:  
• In Case 1: yes, bouquet 3 has peonies.

So peonies are in bouquet 3 in all scenarios.  

C) Roses are in bouquet 2. — Not necessarily.  

D) Tulips are in bouquet 2. — Not necessarily.  

E) Tulips are in bouquet 3. — Not necessarily; Case 1 bouquet 3 has no tulips.  

Step 7 – Conclusion  
Only B is necessarily true.  

The correct option is: B

4. Bouquet 2 & Bouquet 3: exactly 2 kinds in common  

Bouquet 3’s available flower types: {snapdragons, roses} only? Could it have more? No, because:  
• lilies forbidden (snapdragons conflict)  

• tulips forbidden (shared with bouquet 1)  

• peonies forbidden (shared with bouquet 1)  

So bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, roses} exactly? Possibly just snapdragons? But if just snapdragons, then bouquet 2 and bouquet 3 share at most 1 flower type (snapdragons), not 2. So bouquet 3 must have at least 2 flower types to share exactly 2 with bouquet 2.  

Thus bouquet 3 = {snapdragons, roses} (both required).  

5. Bouquet 2’s constraints  

Bouquet 2 and bouquet 3 share exactly 2 kinds: those 2 kinds must be snapdragons and roses (since bouquet 3 has only those 2).  
So bouquet 2 must contain snapdragons and roses.  

Bouquet 2 may contain other flowers, but not relevant to common count with bouquet 3.

Option B) peonies, snapdragons — missing roses → shares only snapdragons with bouquet 3 (1 kind) → wrong.  

Option C) peonies, snapdragons, tulips — missing roses → shares only snapdragons with bouquet 3 → wrong.  

Option D) peonies, roses, tulips — missing snapdragons → shares only roses with bouquet 3 → wrong.  

Option E) peonies, roses, snapdragons, tulips — has snapdragons and roses → shares exactly 2 with bouquet 3.  
Check tulips → peonies: yes, peonies present.  
No lilies, so no conflict.  
Valid.

So bouquet 1 can have lilies? If lilies → roses and no snapdragons. But roses conflict: bouquet 1 can’t have roses (common with bouquet 3). So bouquet 1 cannot have lilies. So bouquet 1 = {tulips, peonies} possibly plus nothing else (since others are snapdragons, roses, lilies all forbidden). So bouquet 1 = {tulips, peonies} exactly.  

Bouquet 2 = {peonies, roses, snapdragons, tulips} works: tulips → peonies yes, shares exactly snapdragons and roses with bouquet 3.

reasoning_cot:

So B3’s composition must allow for exactly 2 kinds of flowers in common with B2.

3. Test each option for B2 to see if B3 can exist satisfying all constraints.

Option A: B2 = {lilies, roses}

• So impossible.  

Thus A is impossible immediately.

Option B: B2 = {peonies, tulips}  
• Tulips → must have peonies (yes).  

• B3 has snapdragons.  

• B3 and B2: common flowers possible: peonies, tulips.

• So B3 could be {peonies, tulips, snapdragons, roses? maybe not needed}.  

• Then B3 and B2 share peonies and tulips → exactly 2 kinds. Works.  

• B1 possible? B1 no flowers in common with B3, so B1 cannot have peonies, tulips, snapdragons; can have lilies, roses (lilies → roses, no snapdragons, fine).  

• Seems possible. So B is possible.

Option C: B2 = {peonies, roses, snapdragons}  
• B3 has snapdragons.  

• B3 and B2: common flowers could be peonies, roses, snapdragons.  

• Need exactly 2 in common → B3 must omit exactly one of peonies/roses from B2’s set.  

• Example: B3 = {snapdragons, roses, lilies? no lilies (lilies → no snapdragons) → so lilies impossible in B3.  

• B3 = {snapdragons, roses, tulips? tulips → peonies, so that adds peonies automatically → then common with B2 = {peonies, roses, snapdragons} = 3 kinds, not allowed. So if B3 has tulips, it must have peonies, and if it also has roses and snapdragons, that’s all 3 of B2’s types → 3 in common, not allowed. So B3 cannot have all of B2’s types.  

• Try B3 = {snapdragons, roses, peonies} → common with B2 = all 3 kinds → not allowed.  

• Try B3 = {snapdragons, roses} plus maybe tulips? No, tulips force peonies → then 3 in common.  

• Try B3 = {snapdragons, peonies} plus maybe tulips? tulips force peonies (already have), roses not forced. So B3 = {snapdragons, peonies, tulips}. Common with B2 = {peonies, snapdragons} (roses not in B3) → exactly 2 kinds. Works. B1 possible: B1 = {lilies, roses} (no flowers in common with B3).  

• So C is possible.

Option D: B2 = {peonies, roses, tulips}

• Need exactly 2 in common.

• So B3 = {snapdragons, tulips, peonies, (maybe something else but not roses)}.  

• Common with B2 = {peonies, tulips} → exactly 2. Works.

Option E: B2 = {peonies, roses, snapdragons, tulips}

So B1 cannot have roses. So B1 = {lilies} impossible (lilies → roses). So B1 cannot have lilies (since lilies force roses, and roses conflict with B3). So B1’s possible flowers: from {peonies, tulips, lilies(no), roses(no), snapdragons(no)} → only peonies, tulips remain? But tulips → peonies. So B1 = {peonies, tulips} possible? But B3 = {snapdragons, roses} so no conflict. Yes, that works.  

• So E is possible.

Only A is impossible.

The correct option is: A

context: A florist is filling a customer's order for three bouquets—bouquet 1, bouquet 2, and bouquet 3. Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common. Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons. If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons. If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
options: A) Lilies and roses are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 1.
B) Peonies and tulips are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 1.

reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

1. Restating the rules:

• Bouquet 1 and Bouquet 3: no flowers in common.  

• Bouquet 2 and Bouquet 3: exactly 2 kinds in common.  

• Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons.  

• Lilies → Roses, and Lilies → no Snapdragons.  

• Tulips → Peonies.  

2. Immediate consequence for Bouquet 3:  
B3 has snapdragons.  
If B3 had lilies, it would need roses and could not have snapdragons — contradiction.  
So B3 cannot have lilies.  

3. B1 and B3 have no flowers in common.  
So B1 cannot contain snapdragons (since B3 has snapdragons).  
Also, B1 cannot contain any flower that appears in B3.  

4. B2 and B3 have exactly 2 kinds in common.  
So B3’s flowers are a set; B2’s flowers are a set; the intersection size = 2.  

5. Check each option to see if it’s possible or impossible.

Option A: B1 = {Lilies, Roses}.  
• Lilies → Roses (ok) and Lilies → no Snapdragons (ok, B1 has no Snapdragons anyway).  

• B1 ∩ B3 = ∅. So B3 cannot have Lilies or Roses.  

• B3 must have Snapdragons.  

• B2 ∩ B3 size = 2.  

Possible B3? Could be {Snapdragons, Peonies, Tulips} (Tulips → Peonies, ok).  
Then B3 ∩ B2 must be size 2. B2 could be {Snapdragons, Peonies, …} to match.  
No rule broken for B1.  
Check B1: Lilies, Roses — allowed.  
Seems possible.  

Option B: B1 = {Peonies, Tulips}.  
• Tulips → Peonies, ok.  

• B1 ∩ B3 = ∅ ⇒ B3 cannot have Peonies or Tulips.  

• B3 must have Snapdragons.  

• B3 cannot have Peonies or Tulips, and cannot have Lilies (from earlier rule).  

So B3’s possible flowers: from {Roses, Snapdragons, …} — but Peonies and Tulips out, Lilies out.  
So B3 ⊆ {Roses, Snapdragons}? But that’s only 2 flowers. Could B3 have only 1 or 2 kinds? The problem says “composed of one or more” so yes, B3 could be {Snapdragons, Roses} only.  

But B2 ∩ B3 size = 2.  
If B3 = {Snapdragons, Roses}, then B2 must contain both Snapdragons and Roses to have intersection size 2. That’s possible.  

But check Tulips → Peonies in B1: fine.  
B1 = {Peonies, Tulips} — no Snapdragons, so B1 ∩ B3 = ∅?  
B3 = {Snapdragons, Roses} — disjoint from B1? Yes, B1 has Peonies, Tulips; B3 has Snapdragons, Roses — disjoint.  
Possible.  

So B possible.  

Option C: B2 = {Lilies, Peonies, Roses}.  
• Lilies → Roses (ok) and Lilies → no Snapdragons (ok, B2 has no Snapdragons).  

• B2 ∩ B3 size = 2.  

• B3 must have Snapdragons.  

• B3 cannot have Lilies (rule: Lilies → no Snapdragons).  

So B3’s intersection with B2: B2’s flowers: L, P, R.  
B3 cannot have L, so intersection can only be from {P, R}. That’s at most size 2.  
We need exactly size 2 ⇒ B3 must contain both P and R.  
So B3 contains {P, R, Snapdragons, maybe more?} but must be disjoint from B1 except B1 not relevant yet.  

But B3 has Snapdragons and P and R.  
B1 ∩ B3 = ∅ ⇒ B1 cannot have P, R, or Snapdragons.  
So B1 ⊆ {Lilies, Tulips}? But Lilies → Roses, so if B1 has Lilies, it must have Roses, but Roses in B3 ⇒ B1 cannot have Roses (since B1 ∩ B3 = ∅).  
So B1 cannot have Lilies (because Lilies → Roses, and Roses in B3).  
So B1 ⊆ {Tulips}? But Tulips → Peonies, and Peonies in B3 ⇒ B1 cannot have Peonies (disjoint from B3), so B1 cannot have Tulips either (since Tulips force Peonies, which B1 can’t have).  

So B1 would have no flowers allowed? B1 must have at least one kind. Contradiction.  

Thus Option C is impossible.  

Option D: B2 = {Peonies, Roses, Snapdragons}.  
• B3 has Snapdragons.  

• B2 ∩ B3 size = 2.  

Possible: B3 could be {Snapdragons, Peonies, Tulips} (Tulips → Peonies ok).  
Intersection with B2 = {Peonies, Snapdragons} size 2.  
B1 disjoint from B3: B3 has P, S, T ⇒ B1 cannot have P, S, T ⇒ B1 ⊆ {Lilies, Roses}.  
But Lilies → Roses and Lilies → no Snapdragons (ok).  
So B1 could be {Lilies, Roses}. Works.  
So D possible.  

Option E: B3 = {Peonies, Snapdragons, Tulips}.  
• Tulips → Peonies, ok.  

• B1 disjoint from B3 ⇒ B1 cannot have P, S, T ⇒ B1 ⊆ {Lilies, Roses}.  

• Lilies → Roses, so B1 could be {Lilies, Roses}.  

• B2 ∩ B3 size = 2. B3 = {P, S, T}. B2 could share exactly 2, e.g., {P, S, …}.  

Possible.  

So the only clear impossibility is C.

The correct option is: C

context: A corporation's Human Resources department must determine annual bonuses for seven employees—Kimura, Lopez, Meng, and Peterson, who work in the Finance department; and Vaughan, Xavier, and Zane, who work in the Graphics department. Each employee will receive either a $1,000 bonus, a $3,000 bonus, or a $5,000 bonus, in accordance with the following: No one in the Graphics department receives a $1,000 bonus. Any employee who was rated Highly Effective receives a larger bonus than anyone in his or her department who was not rated Highly Effective. Only Lopez, Meng, and Xavier were rated Highly Effective.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable distribution of bonuses to the seven employees?
options: A) [Finance] Kimura: $1,000; Lopez: $5,000; Meng: $5,000; Peterson: $1,000 [Graphics] Vaughan: $3,000; Xavier: $3,000; Zane: $3,000
B) [Finance] Kimura: $1,000; Lopez: $5,000; Meng: $5,000; Peterson: $3,000 [Graphics] Vaughan: $3,000; Xavier: $5,000; Zane: $1,000
C) [Finance] Kimura: $1,000; Lopez: $5,000; Meng: $5,000; Peterson: $3,000 [Graphics] Vaughan: $3,000; Xavier: $5,000; Zane: $3,000
D) [Finance] Kimura: $3,000; Lopez: $5,000; Meng: $3,000; Peterson: $1,000 [Graphics] Vaughan: $3,000; Xavier: $5,000; Zane: $3,000
E) [Finance] Kimura: $3,000; Lopez: $5,000; Meng: $5,000; Peterson: $1,000 [Graphics] Vaughan: $1,000; Xavier: $5,000; Zane: $3,000
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check the constraints:  

1. No one in the Graphics department receives a $1,000 bonus.  
   → Graphics (Vaughan, Xavier, Zane) cannot have $1,000.  

2. Any employee rated Highly Effective receives a larger bonus than anyone in his/her department who was not rated Highly Effective.  
   → Highly Effective: Lopez, Meng, Xavier.  
   • In Finance: Lopez and Meng must have a bonus larger than Kimura and Peterson.  

   • In Graphics: Xavier must have a bonus larger than Vaughan and Zane.  

3. Only Lopez, Meng, Xavier are Highly Effective.  

Option A:  
Finance: Kimura 1K, Lopez 5K, Meng 5K, Peterson 1K.  
→ Highly Effective (Lopez, Meng) = 5K each. Others in Finance (Kimura, Peterson) = 1K each.  
Constraint: 5K > 1K ✓.  

Graphics: Vaughan 3K, Xavier 3K, Zane $3K.  
→ Highly Effective (Xavier) = 3K. Others in Graphics (Vaughan, Zane) = 3K each.  
Constraint: Xavier’s bonus > others in Graphics? No, equal → violates rule. ❌  

Option B:  
Graphics: Zane 1K → violates “No 1K in Graphics” ❌ immediately.  

Option C:  
Finance: Kimura 1K, Lopez 5K, Meng 5K, Peterson 3K.  
→ Highly Effective (Lopez, Meng) = 5K. Others in Finance (Kimura 1K, Peterson 3K) → 5K > 1K and 5K > $3K ✓.  

Graphics: Vaughan 3K, Xavier 5K, Zane $3K.  
→ Highly Effective (Xavier) = 5K. Others in Graphics (Vaughan 3K, Zane 3K) → 5K > $3K ✓.  

No $1K in Graphics ✓.  

All constraints satisfied.  

Option D:  
Finance: Kimura 3K, Lopez 5K, Meng 3K, Peterson 1K.  
→ Highly Effective (Lopez 5K, Meng 3K). Others in Finance (Kimura 3K, Peterson 1K).  
Meng (3K) not greater than Kimura (3K) → violates rule ❌.  

Option E:  
Graphics: Vaughan 1K → violates “No 1K in Graphics” ❌.  

Only C satisfies all constraints.  

The correct option is: C

context: A corporation's Human Resources department must determine annual bonuses for seven employees—Kimura, Lopez, Meng, and Peterson, who work in the Finance department; and Vaughan, Xavier, and Zane, who work in the Graphics department. Each employee will receive either a $1,000 bonus, a $3,000 bonus, or a $5,000 bonus, in accordance with the following: No one in the Graphics department receives a $1,000 bonus. Any employee who was rated Highly Effective receives a larger bonus than anyone in his or her department who was not rated Highly Effective. Only Lopez, Meng, and Xavier were rated Highly Effective.
question: If Lopez does not receive the same bonus as Meng, which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Kimura receives a $3,000 bonus.
B) Lopez receives a $3,000 bonus.
C) Peterson receives a $3,000 bonus.
D) Kimura receives the same bonus as Vaughan.
E) Peterson receives a larger bonus than Kimura.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. Restating the constraints  
• 7 employees:  

  • Finance: Kimura (K), Lopez (L), Meng (M), Peterson (P)  

  • Graphics: Vaughan (V), Xavier (X), Zane (Z)  

• Bonus amounts: 1k, 3k, $5k  

• No one in Graphics gets 1k → V, X, Z ∈ {3k, $5k}  

• Highly Effective (HE) employees: L, M, X  

• HE employees get a larger bonus than anyone in their department who is not HE.  

2. Implications of HE rule  
• In Finance: L and M are HE, K and P are not HE.  

  • L’s bonus > K’s bonus and L’s bonus > P’s bonus  

  • M’s bonus > K’s bonus and M’s bonus > P’s bonus  

  • So K and P must have smaller bonuses than L and M.  

• In Graphics: X is HE, V and Z are not HE.  

  • X’s bonus > V’s bonus and X’s bonus > Z’s bonus  

  • Since V and Z are in {3k, 5k}, the only way X’s bonus is greater than both is:  

    ◦ V and Z must be 3k, X must be 5k.  

  • So Graphics is fixed: X = 5k, V = 3k, Z = $3k.  

3. Finance department possibilities  
Finance: L, M, K, P.  
Possible bonuses: 1k, 3k, $5k.  
K and P cannot be $5k (because L and M are HE and must be greater than K and P).  
So K and P ∈ {1k, 3k}.  
L and M ∈ {3k, 5k} (since they must be > K and P, and $5k is possible).  

4. Extra condition: Lopez does not receive the same bonus as Meng  
So L and M have different bonuses from {3k, 5k}.  
So one is 3k, the other is 5k.  

5. Determining K and P  
K and P must be less than both L and M’s bonuses? Wait — careful:  
Rule: “Any employee who was rated HE receives a larger bonus than anyone in his or her department who was not rated HE.”  
So L’s bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus.  
M’s bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus.  

So K’s bonus < L’s bonus and K’s bonus < M’s bonus.  
P’s bonus < L’s bonus and P’s bonus < M’s bonus.  

Since L and M are 3k and 5k in some order, the smaller of L and M is $3k.  
So K and P must be less than $3k (since they must be less than both L and M individually).  
Only possible bonus less than 3k is 1k.  

So K = 1k, P = 1k.  

6. Check options  
A) Kimura receives a 3,000 bonus. → False, K = 1k.  
B) Lopez receives a 3,000 bonus. → Possible if L = 3k, M = $5k.  
C) Peterson receives a 3,000 bonus. → False, P = 1k.  
D) Kimura receives the same bonus as Vaughan. → K = 1k, V = 3k → False.  
E) Peterson receives a larger bonus than Kimura. → Both = $1k → False.  

Only B is possible.  

The correct option is: B

context: A corporation's Human Resources department must determine annual bonuses for seven employees—Kimura, Lopez, Meng, and Peterson, who work in the Finance department; and Vaughan, Xavier, and Zane, who work in the Graphics department.
