D) The employee who receives a $1,000 bonus is Peterson.
E) The employee who receives a $1,000 bonus is Kimura.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Step 1 – Understanding constraints

• Employees:  

  Finance: Kimura (K), Lopez (L), Meng (M), Peterson (P)  
  Graphics: Vaughan (V), Xavier (X), Zane (Z)  

• Bonuses: 1,000, 3,000, or $5,000.

• Rules:  

  1. No one in Graphics gets $1,000.  
  2. Highly Effective (HE) employees get a larger bonus than anyone in their department who is not HE.  
  3. HE employees: Lopez, Meng, Xavier (only these three).

Step 2 – Implications of HE rule

• In Finance: L and M are HE. K and P are not HE.  

  • So L’s bonus > K’s bonus and L’s bonus > P’s bonus.  

  • M’s bonus > K’s bonus and M’s bonus > P’s bonus.  

  • So K and P are the lowest in Finance (but not necessarily equal).  

• In Graphics: X is HE. V and Z are not HE.  

  • X’s bonus > V’s bonus and X’s bonus > Z’s bonus.  

  • Also, V and Z cannot get 1,000 (rule 1), so V and Z get at least 3,000.  

  • But X must be larger than V and Z, so X must get 5,000 (since V and Z get at least 3,000, the only way X is larger is if X gets 5,000 and V, Z get 3,000 each).  

So Graphics is fixed:  
X = 5,000, V = 3,000, Z = $3,000.

Step 3 – Only one employee gets $1,000 bonus

Total employees: 7.  
Only one gets $1,000.  
So 6 get 3,000 or 5,000.

We already assigned:  
Graphics: X (5k), V (3k), Z ($3k) → 3 employees done.

Finance: K, L, M, P remain.  
Only one of these four gets 1,000. The other three get 3k or $5k.

Step 4 – Constraints in Finance

L and M are HE, K and P are not HE.  
L’s bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus.  
M’s bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus.

So K and P are lower than both L and M.  
If K or P gets $1,000, that’s fine (they’d be lower than L and M).  
But only one gets $1,.

If K gets 1,000, then P must get at least 3,000 (since only one $1k total).  
If P gets 1,000, then K must get at least 3,000.

Also, L and M must be > K and > P, so L and M must be at least 3,000, but if K or P is 3,000, L and M must be $5,000.

Step 5 – Test possibilities

Case 1: K gets 1,000 (only 1k in whole company).  
Then P gets at least $3,000.  
L and M must be > P (if P is 3k, L and M must be 5k).  
If P is 5k, impossible because L and M must be > P, but 5k is max. So P cannot be $5k.  
So P = 3k, L = 5k, M = $5k.  
This works: K (1k), P (3k), L (5k), M (5k).  
Checks: L and M > K and > P. Only one $1k (K).

Case 2: P gets $1,000.  
Then K gets at least $3k.  
L and M must be > K (if K is 3k, L and M must be 5k).  
If K is 5k, impossible because L and M must be > K. So K = 3k.  
So P (1k), K (3k), L (5k), M (5k).  
Checks: L and M > K and > P. Only one $1k (P).

Case 3: Could the $1k go to L or M?  
No, because L and M are HE, so they must be > K and P. If K or P gets 3k or 5k, L and M must be higher, so L and M can’t be 1k. So 1k must be K or P.

So $1k is either K or P.

Step 6 – What must be true?

From above, the $1k is K or P.  
So D says "$1k is P" — not necessarily true (could be K).  
E says "$1k is K" — not necessarily true (could be P).  
So neither D nor E must be true.

B says "Peterson gets 3k" — not necessarily true: if P gets 1k, then P gets 1k, not 3k. So B is false.

C says "Meng gets $3k" — impossible? Let’s check:  
M is HE, must be > K and P. If K or P gets 3k, M must be 5k. If K or P gets 1k, the other gets 3k, so M must be 5k. So M is always 5k.  
Yes! Because:  
• If K=1k, P=3k → M > P → M=$5k.  

• If P=1k, K=3k → M > K → M=$5k.  

So in both cases, M gets $5k.

So A says "Meng gets $5k" — that is always true.  
C says "Meng gets $3k" — false.

Step 7 – Conclusion

A must be true.

The correct option is: A

context: A corporation's Human Resources department must determine annual bonuses for seven employees—Kimura, Lopez, Meng, and Peterson, who work in the Finance department; and Vaughan, Xavier, and Zane, who work in the Graphics department. Each employee will receive either a $1,000 bonus, a $3,000 bonus, or a $5,000 bonus, in accordance with the following: No one in the Graphics department receives a $1,000 bonus. Any employee who was rated Highly Effective receives a larger bonus than anyone in his or her department who was not rated Highly Effective. Only Lopez, Meng, and Xavier were rated Highly Effective.
question: Which one of the following must be true?
options: A) At least one of the employees receives a $1,000 bonus.
B) At least three of the employees receives a $3,000 bonuses.
C) At most three of the employees receives a $3,000 bonuses.
D) At least two of the employees receives a $5,000 bonuses.
E) At most three of the employees receives a $5,000 bonuses.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Step 1 – Understand the constraints  
• Employees:  

  • Finance: Kimura (K), Lopez (L), Meng (M), Peterson (P)  

  • Graphics: Vaughan (V), Xavier (X), Zane (Z)  

• Bonus amounts: 1,000, 3,000, $5,000  

• No one in Graphics gets 1,000 → V, X, Z ∈ {3k, $5k}  

• Highly Effective (HE) employees: L, M, X  

• HE employees get a larger bonus than anyone in their department who is not HE.  

Step 2 – Apply HE rule to each department  

Finance department (K, L, M, P):  
• HE: L, M  

• Non-HE: K, P  

• L and M must each get a larger bonus than K and P.  

• So K and P cannot have the highest bonus in Finance.  

• Therefore, L and M must each have a bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus.  

• This means K and P must be lower than L and M.  

• Possible bonus order in Finance: K and P get at most 3k (since if L or M get 5k, K and P could be 1k or 3k but must be less than L and M’s bonus).  

• But careful: L and M could both be 5k, then K and P could be 3k or $1k. But they must be less than L and M’s bonus.  

Actually, more precisely:  
• For each non-HE in Finance: bonus < bonus of L and bonus < bonus of M.  

• So K’s bonus < L’s bonus and K’s bonus < M’s bonus.  

• Similarly P’s bonus < L’s bonus and P’s bonus < M’s bonus.  

Thus:  
• If L = 5k, K and P ≤ 3k.  

• If L = 3k, K and P = 1k.  

• But L and M are both HE, so they could have same bonus as each other (rule says larger than non-HE, not larger than other HE).  

So minimal possible for K and P is 1k if L and M are at least 3k.  

Graphics department (V, X, Z):  
• HE: X  

• Non-HE: V, Z  

• X’s bonus > V’s bonus and > Z’s bonus.  

• V and Z are in {3k, 5k} (no $1k in Graphics).  

• If X’s bonus > V’s and > Z’s, and V, Z ≥ 3k, then X must be 5k, and V and Z must be $3k.  

• Because if V or Z were 5k, X would need > 5k (impossible).  

• So: X = 5k, V = 3k, Z = $3k.  

Step 3 – Determine Graphics bonuses fixed  
From above:  
V = 3k, Z = 3k, X = $5k.  

Step 4 – Finance department implications  
We know L and M are HE, K and P are not HE.  
L’s bonus > K’s and > P’s.  
M’s bonus > K’s and > P’s.  

Possible bonus amounts for L, M: 3k or 5k (since 1k would violate > K’s and > P’s unless K and P are even lower, but 1k is minimum, so impossible for L or M to be 1k because then K and P would need less than 1k). So L, M ∈ {3k, 5k}.  

K and P ∈ {1k, 3k} but must be less than L’s bonus and M’s bonus.  

Case analysis:  
• If L = 3k, then K and P < 3k → K and P = $1k.  

• If M = 3k, then K and P = 1k.  

• If L = 5k and M = 5k, then K and P can be 1k or 3k.  

So K and P could both be 3k only if L and M are both 5k.  

Step 5 – Check options  

A) At least one gets $1k bonus.  
• Could K and P both be 3k? Yes if L and M = 5k. Then Finance: K=3k, P=3k, L=5k, M=5k. Graphics: V=3k, Z=3k, X=$5k.  

• Check HE rule: K’s bonus (3k) < L’s (5k) and < M’s (5k) — OK. P’s bonus (3k) < L’s and M’s — OK.  

• No one gets $1k in this scenario. So A is not necessarily true.  

B) At least three get $3k.  
• In the above scenario: K, P, V, Z all get 3k → 4 people get 3k.  

• Could there be a case with fewer than three $3k?  

• Try: L=3k → forces K=1k, P=1k. Finance: K=1k, P=1k, L=3k, M=?  

• M must be > K and P (true if M=3k or 5k), but also M HE, so M’s bonus > K’s and P’s.  

• If M=3k, then Finance: K=1k, P=1k, L=3k, M=3k. Graphics: V=3k, Z=3k, X=5k.  

• Count $3k: L, M, V, Z → 4 people. Still at least 3.  

• Try to minimize 3k: L=5k, M=5k, K=1k, P=1k. Finance: K=1k, P=1k, L=5k, M=5k. Graphics: V=3k, Z=3k, X=5k.  

• $3k: V, Z → 2 people. That’s fewer than 3. So B is not necessarily true.  

C) At most three get $3k.  
• In the last example above: 2 people get $3k → satisfies “at most 3”.  

• But in earlier scenario: 4 people get $3k → violates “at most 3”. So C is not necessarily true.  

D) At least two get $5k.  
• Graphics: X=5k. Finance: need at least one more 5k?  

• Could be: L=3k, M=3k, K=1k, P=1k, V=3k, Z=3k, X=5k → only 1 person with 5k (X). So D is false.  

E) At most three get $5k.  
• Maximum 5k possible: X=5k, L=5k, M=5k → that’s 3 people. K, P, V, Z cannot be $5k:  

  • V, Z cannot be $5k (since X must be > V and Z in Graphics).  

  • K, P cannot be $5k (since L and M must be > K and P in Finance).  

• So maximum 5k = 3 (X, L, M). So at most three get 5k is always true.  

Step 6 – Conclusion  
The only one that must be true is E.  

The correct option is: E

context: A corporation's Human Resources department must determine annual bonuses for seven employees—Kimura, Lopez, Meng, and Peterson, who work in the Finance department; and Vaughan, Xavier, and Zane, who work in the Graphics department. Each employee will receive either a $1,000 bonus, a $3,000 bonus, or a $5,000 bonus, in accordance with the following: No one in the Graphics department receives a $1,000 bonus. Any employee who was rated Highly Effective receives a larger bonus than anyone in his or her department who was not rated Highly Effective. Only Lopez, Meng, and Xavier were rated Highly Effective.
question: If exactly two of the employees receive $5,000 bonuses, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) Lopez receives a $3,000 bonus.
B) Meng receives a $3,000 bonus.
C) Meng is one of the employees who receives a $5,000 bonus.
D) Peterson receives a $1,000 bonus.
E) Peterson receives a $3,000 bonus.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason this out step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints  
• Employees:  

  • Finance: Kimura (K), Lopez (L), Meng (M), Peterson (P)  

  • Graphics: Vaughan (V), Xavier (X), Zane (Z)  

• Bonus amounts: 1,000, 3,000, or $5,000.  

• No one in Graphics gets 1,000 → V, X, Z get 3k or $5k only.  

• Highly Effective (HE) employees: L, M, X.  

• HE employees get a larger bonus than anyone in their department who is not HE.  

• Exactly two employees get $5,000.  

Step 2 – Implications of HE rule  
• In Finance: L and M are HE. K and P are not HE.  

  • L’s bonus > bonus of K and P (within Finance)  

  • M’s bonus > bonus of K and P (within Finance)  

  • So K and P cannot have the highest bonus in Finance; L or M must have the highest in Finance.  

  • Actually, stronger: L’s bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus; M’s bonus > K’s bonus and > P’s bonus.  

  • So K and P must be lower than both L and M individually.  

• In Graphics: X is HE; V and Z are not HE.  

  • X’s bonus > V’s bonus and > Z’s bonus.  

  • So V and Z cannot have the highest bonus in Graphics; X must have the highest in Graphics.  

Step 3 – Exactly two $5k bonuses  
Two people get $5k. Who can they be?  

• X could be $5k (since X is HE and highest in Graphics).  

• If X is 5k, then V and Z are at most 3k.  

• L and M could be 5k, but if both L and M are 5k, that’s two 5k already, so X would be 3k.  

• Could X be 3k? Then V and Z must be less than X’s bonus, but V and Z can’t be 1k (Graphics rule), so they must be less than 3k — impossible because their only options are 3k or 5k. So X cannot be 3k unless V and Z are less than $3k, which is impossible.  

  • Wait, check: If X = 3k, then V and Z must be < 3k, but they can’t be $1k, so impossible.  

  • Therefore X must be $5k.  

So one $5k bonus is X.  

Step 4 – Second $5k bonus  
We have exactly two 5k total. One is X. The other must be in Finance (since Graphics only X can be 5k, otherwise V or Z would be 5k, but then X would have to be > them, impossible unless X is 5k and they are 3k — but that would be three 5k’s: X, V or Z, and someone else? Let’s check carefully.)  

Actually, if V or Z is 5k, then X must be > them → impossible. So indeed, only X can be 5k in Graphics.  

So second $5k must be in Finance.  

Finance: K, P cannot be 5k because if K is 5k, then L and M must be > K (since L and M are HE and K is not HE), impossible because 5k is max. So K and P cannot be 5k.  

Thus second $5k must be either L or M.  

Step 5 – Who in Finance gets $5k?  
Either L or M gets 5k, but not both (since exactly two 5k total: X and one of L/M).  

The other of L/M must be $3k, because:  
• L and M both > K and P.  

• K and P must be lower than both L and M.  

• If L = 5k, M = 3k, then K and P must be < 3k (since < M’s 3k and < L’s 5k), so K and P = 1k.  

• If M = 5k, L = 3k, then K and P = $1k.  

So in either case, the HE person in Finance who is not 5k gets 3k, and K and P get $1k.  

Step 6 – Which must be true?  
Options:  
A) Lopez receives 3,000 → Not necessarily true; could be L gets 5k, M gets $3k.  
B) Meng receives 3,000 → Not necessarily true; could be M gets 5k, L gets $3k.  
C) Meng is one of the employees who receives 5,000 → Not necessarily; could be L gets 5k.  
D) Peterson receives $1,000 → Yes, must be true (from Step 5).  
E) Peterson receives 3,000 → False; P gets 1k.  

So D must be true.  

The correct option is: D

context: A corporation's Human Resources department must determine annual bonuses for seven employees—Kimura, Lopez, Meng, and Peterson, who work in the Finance department; and Vaughan, Xavier, and Zane, who work in the Graphics department. Each employee will receive either a $1,000 bonus, a $3,000 bonus, or a $5,000 bonus, in accordance with the following: No one in the Graphics department receives a $1,000 bonus. Any employee who was rated Highly Effective receives a larger bonus than anyone in his or her department who was not rated Highly Effective. Only Lopez, Meng, and Xavier were rated Highly Effective.
question: Any of the following could be true of the seven employees EXCEPT:
options: A) The same number receive $1,000 bonuses as receive $3,000 bonuses.
B) More receive $1,000 bonuses than receive $3,000 bonuses.
C) The same number receive $1,000 bonuses as receive $5,000 bonuses.
D) More receive $1,000 bonuses than receive $5,000 bonuses.
E) More receive $3,000 bonuses than receive $5,000 bonuses.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Step 1 – Understanding constraints  
• 7 employees:  

  • Finance: Kimura (K), Lopez (L), Meng (M), Peterson (P) — 4 people.  

  • Graphics: Vaughan (V), Xavier (X), Zane (Z) — 3 people.  

• Bonuses: 1,000, 3,000, $5,000.  

• No one in Graphics gets $1,000.  

• Highly Effective (HE) employees: Lopez, Meng, Xavier.  

• In each department, HE employees get a larger bonus than non-HE employees in that department.  

Step 2 – Implications for Graphics department  
Graphics: V, X, Z.  
HE: Xavier.  
So Xavier’s bonus > V’s bonus and > Z’s bonus.  
Also, V and Z cannot get 1,000 (no Graphics gets 1,000 anyway).  
Possible bonus amounts for Graphics: 3k or 5k.  

Since Xavier > V and Z, Xavier must get 5k, and V and Z must get 3k.  
So Graphics is fixed:  
• Xavier: $5k  

• Vaughan: $3k  

• Zane: $3k  

Step 3 – Finance department  
Finance: K, L, M, P.  
HE: Lopez, Meng.  
Non-HE: Kimura, Peterson.  
Rule: L and M each get larger bonus than K and P in Finance.  

Possible bonuses: 1k, 3k, $5k.  

Since L and M > K and P, K and P cannot be the highest in Finance.  
So K and P cannot get 5k unless L or M get more, but 5k is max, so if K or P get 5k, L and M can’t be higher — impossible. So K and P cannot get 5k.  

Thus K and P can only get 1k or 3k.  

L and M can get 3k or 5k, but must be > K and P.  

Step 4 – Possible distributions of counts  
We know:  
• Graphics: 2 people at 3k, 1 at 5k.  

• Finance: K, P ∈ {1k, 3k} but must be less than L and M’s bonus.  

Case analysis:  
If L gets 3k, then K and P must be 1k each.  
If L gets 5k, K and P can be 1k or 3k but must be less than L (so they can be 3k or 1k if M is 5k, but careful: M also > K, P).  

Similarly for M.  

Let’s test extremes for total counts:  

Let’s find possible total counts of people with 1k, 3k, $5k.  

Step 5 – Total counts possible  
Total 5k: Xavier (1 fixed). Possibly L and/or M also 5k.  

Min $5k count = 1 (only Xavier).  
Max $5k count = 3 (Xavier, L, M).  

Total $3k: Vaughan, Zane fixed (2). Possibly K, P, L, M.  

Total 1k: Only possible in Finance (K, P, maybe L or M? No, L and M can’t be 1k because they must be > K, P; if K or P are 1k, L, M at least 3k, but if K, P both 1k, L, M can be 3k or $5k).  

Step 6 – Try each option  

A) Same number get 1k as 3k  
Let’s see: Total 7 people. Let 1k = 3k = x, $5k = 7 - 2x, x positive integer.  
Possible: x=2 → 1k=2, 3k=2, $5k=3.  
Can we have 5k=3? That’s Xavier, L, M all 5k. Then K, P must be < L, M, so K, P can be 1k or 3k. But 3k count total must be 2, but Graphics already 2 at 3k, so K, P must be 1k each. Then 1k=2, 3k=2 (V, Z), 5k=3. Works: K=1k, P=1k, L=5k, M=5k, V=3k, Z=3k, X=$5k. Valid. So A possible.  

B) More 1k than 3k  
1k > 3k.  
3k at least 2 (V, Z fixed). So 1k ≥ 3. But only 4 in Finance, 1k only possible for K, P (since L, M can’t be min). So max 1k = 2 (K and P). So impossible to have $1k ≥ 3. So B is impossible.  

Check: Could 3k be less than 2? No, V, Z fixed 3k. So 3k=2 fixed. So 1k>2 means 1k≥3, but only K, P can be 1k. So B is impossible.  

C) Same number 1k as 5k  
Possible? 1k = 5k = y. Total 7, so $3k = 7 - 2y.  
y=2: 1k=2, 5k=2, $3k=3.  
Graphics: 5k=1 (X), 3k=2 (V, Z). So Finance must supply 5k=1 more (L or M), and 3k=1 more, $1k=2.  
So Finance: K=1k, P=1k, L=5k, M=3k? Check: M=3k > K,P=1k ok. L=$5k > K,P ok. Works. So C possible.  

D) More 1k than 5k  
1k > 5k.  
Min 5k=1 (X). If 5k=1, 1k≥2. Max 1k=2 (K,P). So 1k=2, 5k=1 possible? Yes: X=5k, L=3k, M=3k, K=1k, P=1k, V=3k, Z=3k. Wait, then 3k=5 people? That’s fine. Check rules: L=3k>K,P=1k ok, M=3k>K,P ok. Graphics: X=5k>V,Z=$3k ok. Works. So D possible.  

E) More 3k than 5k  
3k > 5k.  
Min 5k=1, so 3k≥2. We already have 3k=2 fixed (V,Z). So 3k>2 means 3k≥3, so at least 1 more in Finance at 3k. Possible: e.g., X=5k, L=3k, M=5k, K=1k, P=3k. Then 3k: V, Z, L, P =4, $5k: X, M=2. 4>2. Works. So E possible.  

Only B is impossible.  

The correct option is: B

context: A landscaper will plant exactly seven trees today—a hickory, a larch, a maple, an oak, a plum, a sycamore, and a walnut. Each tree must be planted on exactly one of three lots—1, 2, or 3—in conformity with the following requirements: The trees planted on one lot are the hickory, the oak, and exactly one other tree. The maple is not planted on the same lot as the walnut. Either the larch or the walnut, but not both, is planted on lot 1. Either the maple or the oak, but not both, is planted on lot 2. More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1.
question: Which one of the following could be the list of the trees that the landscaper plants on each of the lots today?
options: A) lot 1: the larch, the maple lot 2: the hickory, the oak lot 3: the plum, the sycamore, the walnut
B) lot 1: the larch, the maple lot 2: the hickory, the oak, the walnut lot 3: the plum, the sycamore
C) lot 1: the maple lot 2: the hickory, the larch, the oak lot 3: the plum, the sycamore, the walnut
D) lot 1: the sycamore, the walnut lot 2: the larch, the maple lot 3: the hickory, the oak, the plum
E) lot 1: the walnut lot 2: the plum, the sycamore lot 3: the hickory, the maple, the oak
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.

Step 1: Interpret constraints

1. "The trees planted on one lot are the hickory, the oak, and exactly one other tree."  
   → One lot has exactly 3 trees: hickory, oak, and one other. The other two lots have the remaining 4 trees distributed (not both with 3 trees, since total is 7).

2. "The maple is not planted on the same lot as the walnut."  
   → M and W are on different lots.

3. "Either the larch or the walnut, but not both, is planted on lot 1."  
   → Lot 1 contains exactly one of L or W.

4. "Either the maple or the oak, but not both, is planted on lot 2."  
   → Lot 2 contains exactly one of M or O.

5. "More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1."  
   → Lot 3 trees > Lot 1 trees.

Step 2: Identify the 3-tree lot (H, O, +1)

Possible 3-tree lot candidates: could be lot 1, 2, or 3.  
But check constraints:  
• If lot 1 has H, O, +1, then L or W (but not both) in lot 1 → that third tree must be L or W.  

• If lot 2 has H, O, +1, then M or O (but not both) in lot 2 → but O is in lot 2, so M cannot be in lot 2.  

• If lot 3 has H, O, +1, no immediate conflict, but must check distribution.

Step 3: Test each option

Option A:  
Lot 1: L, M (2 trees)  
Lot 2: H, O (2 trees)  
Lot 3: P, S, W (3 trees)  

Check:  
• Which lot has H, O, +1? None. Each lot has 2, 2, 3 but H and O are together in lot 2 with only 2 trees. Violates rule 1. → Eliminate A.

Option B:  
Lot 1: L, M (2 trees)  
Lot 2: H, O, W (3 trees)  
Lot 3: P, S (2 trees)  

Check:  
• H, O, +1: lot 2 has H, O, W → satisfies.  

• M and W: M in lot 1, W in lot 2 → OK.  

• L or W in lot 1: L in lot 1, W not in lot 1 → OK.  

• M or O in lot 2: O in lot 2, M not in lot 2 → OK.  

• More trees on lot 3 than lot 1: lot 3 has 2, lot 1 has 2 → violates. → Eliminate B.

Option C:  
Lot 1: M (1 tree)  
Lot 2: H, L, O (3 trees)  
Lot 3: P, S, W (3 trees)  

Check:  
• H, O, +1: lot 2 has H, O, L → satisfies.  

• M and W: M in lot 1, W in lot 3 → OK.  

• L or W in lot 1: L not in lot 1, W not in lot 1 → violates (must have exactly one of L or W in lot 1). → Eliminate C.

Option D:  
Lot 1: S, W (2 trees)  
Lot 2: L, M (2 trees)  
Lot 3: H, O, P (3 trees)  

Check:  
• H, O, +1: lot 3 has H, O, P → satisfies.  

• M and W: M in lot 2, W in lot 1 → OK.  

• L or W in lot 1: W in lot 1, L not in lot 1 → OK.  

• M or O in lot 2: M in lot 2, O not in lot 2 → OK.  

• More trees on lot 3 than lot 1: lot 3 has 3, lot 1 has 2 → OK.  

All constraints satisfied.

Option E:  
Lot 1: W (1 tree)  
Lot 2: P, S (2 trees)  
Lot 3: H, M, O (3 trees)  

Check:  
• H, O, +1: lot 3 has H, O, M → satisfies.  

• M and W: M in lot 3, W in lot 1 → OK.  

• L or W in lot 1: W in lot 1, L not in lot 1 → OK.  

• M or O in lot 2: M not in lot 2, O not in lot 2 → violates (must have exactly one of M or O in lot 2). → Eliminate E.

Only D satisfies all constraints.

The correct option is: D

context: A landscaper will plant exactly seven trees today—a hickory, a larch, a maple, an oak, a plum, a sycamore, and a walnut. Each tree must be planted on exactly one of three lots—1, 2, or 3—in conformity with the following requirements: The trees planted on one lot are the hickory, the oak, and exactly one other tree. The maple is not planted on the same lot as the walnut. Either the larch or the walnut, but not both, is planted on lot 1. Either the maple or the oak, but not both, is planted on lot 2. More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1.
question: If the hickory is planted on lot 2, then which one of the following trees must be planted on lot 3?
options: A) the larch
B) the maple
C) the plum
D) the sycamore
E) the walnut
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through this step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints  
We have 7 trees: H, L, M, O, P, S, W.  
Three lots: 1, 2, 3.  

1. The trees planted on one lot are the hickory, the oak, and exactly one other tree.  
   → This means there is a lot containing exactly 3 trees: H, O, and one other. The other two lots will contain the remaining 4 trees (2 each, or 3+1? Let’s check: total 7 trees. One lot has 3 trees (H, O, X). The other two lots split the remaining 4 trees. So distribution is 3, 2, 2 in some order.  

2. M and W not on same lot.  

3. Either L or W, but not both, is planted on lot 1.  

4. Either M or O, but not both, is planted on lot 2.

context: Seven librarians—Flynn, Gomez, Hill, Kitson, Leung, Moore, and Zahn—are being scheduled for desk duty for one week—Monday through Saturday. The librarians will be on duty exactly one day each. On each day except Saturday, there will be exactly one librarian on duty, with two on duty on Saturday, subject to the following constraints: Hill must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Leung. Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez. Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore. Kitson must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn. Unless Leung is on desk duty on Saturday, Leung must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Flynn.
question: Which one of the following is an acceptable schedule for the librarians, listed in order from Monday through Saturday?
options: A) Flynn; Hill; Moore; Kitson; Zahn; Gomez and Leung
B) Flynn; Moore; Hill; Leung; Kitson; Gomez and Zahn
C) Hill; Kitson; Moore; Flynn; Gomez; Leung and Zahn
D) Hill; Leung; Flynn; Moore; Zahn; Gomez and Kitson
E) Leung; Flynn; Kitson; Moore; Hill; Gomez and Zahn
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each option against the constraints.

Constraints:
1. Hill earlier than Leung. (H < L)
2. Hill earlier than Gomez. (H < G)
3. Moore earlier than Gomez. (M < G)
4. Flynn earlier than Kitson. (F < K)
5. Flynn earlier than Moore. (F < M)
6. Kitson earlier than Zahn. (K < Z)
7. Unless Leung is on Saturday, Leung earlier than Flynn.  
   → If L ≠ Saturday, then L < F.  
   → If L = Saturday, no restriction on L vs. F.

Option A: F; H; M; K; Z; G and L (Saturday: G, L)  
• H < L? H (Tue) < L (Sat) ✔  

• H < G? H (Tue) < G (Sat) ✔  

• M < G? M (Wed) < G (Sat) ✔  

• F < K? F (Mon) < K (Thu) ✔  

• F < M? F (Mon) < M (Wed) ✔  

• K < Z? K (Thu) < Z (Fri) ✔  

• L = Saturday → no L < F required ✔  

All constraints satisfied.  

Option B: F; M; H; L; K; G and Z (Sat: G, Z)  
• H < L? H (Wed) < L (Thu) ✗ Wait: H is Wed, L is Thu → H(3rd) < L(4th) ✔  

• H < G? H(3rd) < G(Sat) ✔  

• M < G? M(2nd) < G(Sat) ✔  

• F < K? F(1st) < K(5th) ✔  

• F < M? F(1st) < M(2nd) ✔  

• K < Z? K(5th) < Z(Sat) ✔  

• L ≠ Saturday → must have L < F? L(4th) < F(1st)? ✗ (4th not earlier than 1st) → Violates constraint 7.  

✗ Not valid.

Option C: H; K; M; F; G; L and Z (Sat: L, Z)  
• H < L? H(1st) < L(Sat) ✔  

• H < G? H(1st) < G(5th) ✔  

• M < G? M(3rd) < G(5th) ✔  

• F < K? F(4th) < K(2nd) ✗ (F after K) → Violates constraint 4.  

✗ Not valid.

Option D: H; L; F; M; Z; G and K (Sat: G, K)  
• H < L? H(1st) < L(2nd) ✔  

• H < G? H(1st) < G(Sat) ✔  

• M < G? M(4th) < G(Sat) ✔  

• F < K? F(3rd) < K(Sat) ✔  

• F < M? F(3rd) < M(4th) ✔  

• K < Z? K(Sat) < Z(5th) ✗ (K after Z) → Violates constraint 6.  

✗ Not valid.

Option E: L; F; K; M; H; G and Z (Sat: G, Z)  
• H < L? H(5th) < L(1st) ✗ → Violates constraint 1.  

✗ Not valid.

Only A satisfies all constraints.

The correct option is: A

question: Which one of the following CANNOT be on desk duty on Tuesday?

B) Hill
C) Kitson
D) Moore

reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. List the days and constraints  
Days: Mon, Tue, Wed, Thu, Fri, Sat (two on Sat)  
Librarians: F, G, H, K, L, M, Z  

Constraints:  
1.  H < L   (Hill earlier than Leung)  
2.  H < G  and  M < G   (Hill earlier than Gomez, Moore earlier than Gomez)  
3.  F < K  and  F < M   (Flynn earlier than Kitson, Flynn earlier than Moore)  
4.  K < Z   (Kitson earlier than Zahn)  
5. Unless Leung is on Saturday,  L < F .  
   • This means: If  L  is not on Saturday, then  L < F .  

   • Equivalently: If  L \geq F  (i.e., F earlier than L or same day), then L must be on Saturday.  

   • But F and L can’t be same day except possibly Saturday, but F and L could both be on Saturday? Wait, Saturday has 2 people, so they could be together. But if L is on Saturday, the “unless” condition is true, so no restriction. If L is not on Saturday, then L must be before F.  

2. Combine ordering constraints  

From (1)  H < L   
From (3)  F < M  and  F < K   
From (4)  K < Z   
From (2)  M < G  and  H < G   

So:  
•  H < L  and  H < G   

•  F < K < Z   

•  F < M < G   

Also  H  and  M  are both before G, but no direct constraint between H and M.  
Also  H < L  and  F < M < G , and  H < G .  

We need to see where Tuesday fits.

3. Try to see who can be on Tuesday  

We have 6 weekdays (Mon–Sat with 2 on Sat), but Tuesday is a single slot.  

If someone is on Tuesday, they must be early enough to allow all “earlier than” constraints to be satisfied for others.  

4. Test each option for impossibility  

A) Flynn on Tuesday  
If F is on Tuesday, then:  
• F < K, so K must be Wed, Thu, Fri, or Sat.  

• F < M, so M must be after Tuesday.  

• K < Z, so Z after K.  

• M < G, so G after M.  

• H < L and H < G, and H can be Monday (before F) or after F? Wait, H could be Monday: yes.  

• Also L: H < L, so L after H.  

• Constraint 5: If L is not on Saturday, then L < F. But F is Tuesday. If L is not Sat, L must be Monday (only day before Tuesday). But H < L means H before L, so H would have to be before Monday — impossible. So L cannot be Monday (since H must be earlier than L, and only Monday is earlier than Tuesday). So if L is not Sat, impossible. So L must be Sat.  

So L on Sat is possible. Then H can be anytime before Sat (and before L is automatic).  

Seems possible:  
Mon: H, Tue: F, Wed: K, Thu: M, Fri: G, Sat: L, Z (or swap M and K, but F<K and F<M, so K and M after Tue; K<Z; M<G; G on Fri; Z and L Sat).  
Check: H<L: H Mon, L Sat ✓; H<G: H Mon, G Fri ✓; M<G: M Thu, G Fri ✓; F<K: F Tue, K Wed ✓; F<M: F Tue, M Thu ✓; K<Z: K Wed, Z Sat ✓; L on Sat so no L<F required ✓. Works.  
So Flynn can be Tuesday.  

B) Hill on Tuesday  
If H is Tuesday:  
H < L ⇒ L after Tue.  
H < G ⇒ G after Tue.  
No direct constraint on F relative to H.  

F < K < Z and F < M < G.  
We can put F on Monday:  
Mon: F, Tue: H, Wed: K, Thu: M, Fri: G, Sat: L, Z.  
Check: H<L: Tue < Sat ✓; H<G: Tue < Fri ✓; M<G: Thu < Fri ✓; F<K: Mon < Wed ✓; F<M: Mon < Thu ✓; K<Z: Wed < Sat ✓; L on Sat so no L<F required ✓. Works.  
So Hill can be Tuesday.  

C) Kitson on Tuesday  
If K is Tuesday:  
F < K ⇒ F before Tuesday ⇒ F on Monday only.  
K < Z ⇒ Z after Tuesday.  
F < M ⇒ M after Tuesday (since F Monday, M after F).  
M < G ⇒ G after M.  
H < L and H < G.  

Possible schedule:  
Mon: F, Tue: K, Wed: M, Thu: G, Fri: H, Sat: L, Z.  
Check H<L: Fri < Sat ✓; H<G: Fri < Thu? No — H Fri, G Thu violates H<G. So H must be before G. So H must be before Thu in this case.  

Try: Mon: F, Tue: K, Wed: H, Thu: M, Fri: G, Sat: L, Z.  
Check: H<L: Wed < Sat ✓; H<G: Wed < Fri ✓; M<G: Thu < Fri ✓; F<K: Mon < Tue ✓; F<M: Mon < Thu ✓; K<Z: Tue < Sat ✓; L on Sat so no L<F required ✓. Works.  
So Kitson can be Tuesday.  

D) Moore on Tuesday  
If M is Tuesday:  
F < M ⇒ F before Tuesday ⇒ F Monday only.  
M < G ⇒ G after Tuesday.  
F < K ⇒ K after F (Monday) but no constraint relative to M, so K can be after or before M? Wait, F<K and F<M, but no constraint between K and M. So K could be Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, or Saturday. But K<Z must hold.  

Also H<L, H<G.  

Try: Mon: F, Tue: M, Wed: K, Thu: Z, Fri: G, Sat: H, L.  
Check H<L: Sat < Sat? No, H Sat, L Sat — H and L same day? That’s allowed? Two on Sat, but H<L means Hill’s day earlier in week than Leung’s day. If both on Sat, that’s not earlier, so violates H<L. So H and L can’t both be Sat.  

So H must be before L, so L can’t be on a day before or equal to H unless they’re different days.  

Try: Mon: H, Tue: M, Wed: L, Thu: K, Fri: Z, Sat: F, G.  
Check: H<L: Mon < Wed ✓; H<G: Mon < Sat ✓; M<G: Tue < Sat ✓; F<K: Sat < Thu? No, Sat after Thu, violates F<K. So F must be before K. So F can’t be Sat if K is Thu.  

We need F before K and F before M. But M is Tuesday, so F must be Monday. So F fixed Monday. Then K after Monday.  

Try: Mon: F, Tue: M, Wed: H, Thu: K, Fri: Z, Sat: L, G.  
Check: H<L: Wed < Sat ✓; H<G: Wed < Sat ✓; M<G: Tue < Sat ✓; F<K: Mon < Thu ✓; F<M: Mon < Tue ✓; K<Z: Thu < Fri ✓; L on Sat so no L<F required ✓. Works.  
So Moore can be Tuesday.  

E) Zahn on Tuesday  
If Z is Tuesday:  
K < Z ⇒ K before Tuesday ⇒ K Monday only (since only Mon before Tue).  
F < K ⇒ F before K ⇒ impossible because only Monday before Tuesday, but K is Monday, so F would have to be before Monday — no day exists. Contradiction.  

Thus Zahn cannot be Tuesday.  

5. Conclusion  
The one who cannot be on Tuesday is Zahn.  

The correct option is: E

4. Check the “unless” constraint about L and F

5. Test each option for possibility/impossibility

A) F < L

So A is possible.

B) G < K  
But we have K < M < G, so G cannot be before K.  
So B is impossible (contradicts K < M < G).

C) G < Z  
We know K < Z and K < M < G, so G > K, but Z could be before or after G.  
Example: F, K, Z, M, G, … Wait, M < G, so Z could be between M and G? No, K < M < G and K < Z, so Z could be after G or between K and M or between M and G. Let’s test:

But is G < Z possible? Yes: F, K, M, G, Z, L. Let’s check constraints: H before L and G: place H early. K < Z ✓. So possible. So C is possible.

D) H < K  
H just needs to be before L and G. Could H be before K? Yes: H, F, K, M, G, Z, L with L on Sat. Possible. So D possible.

E) Z < M  
We have K < Z and K < M. So Z could be between K and M: F, K, Z, M, G, … Check: H before L, G: place H early. Possible. So E possible.

6. Conclusion

Only B contradicts the fixed order K < M < G (which forces G after K, so G < K is impossible).

The correct option is: B

So contradiction: L cannot be before Thursday if L is not Saturday, because F, K, Z fixed before/on Thu, and H before L.

Actually, let’s check carefully:

If L is not Saturday: L < F < K < Z (Thu) means L, F, K on Mon, Tue, Wed in some order. Plus H before L, so H must be on Mon or Tue or Wed but before L. That’s possible if L is Tue or Wed:

H Mon, L Tue, F ? K before Thu means K on Wed, but F < K means F before Wed → F on Mon or Tue. But L < F means L before F, so L on Mon, F on Tue, K on Wed, Z Thu. Works: H Mon, L Mon? No, H < L means different days. So H Mon, L Tue, F Tue? No, same day not allowed. So H Mon, L Tue, F Wed? But F < K means K after F (Wed), but K < Z means K before Thu, so K must be Wed? Impossible, F and K same day. So no.  

Try H Mon, L Wed, F ? K before Thu means K on Wed? No, L and K same day not allowed. So K must be Tue or Wed, but F < K and L < F. Let’s test:  
If L Wed, F must be after L (Wed) impossible because days after Wed are Thu, Fri, Sat, but F < K < Z(Thu) means F before Thu, so F on Mon, Tue, or Wed. But L Wed means F after Wed impossible. So L cannot be Wed if L < F.  

So L < F < K < Z(Thu) means L, F, K all before Thu. With H before L, that’s 4 people before Thu: H, L, F, K. But only 3 days before Thu. Impossible.  

Thus: If L is not Saturday, we get contradiction.  

Step 5 – Conclusion from Step 4  
L must be Saturday.  

Step 6 – Implications  
If L is Saturday, then (7) is not triggered.  
From (1) H < L, so H is Mon–Fri.  
From (4) F < K, (6) K < Z(Thu), so K is Mon, Tue, or Wed; F before K.  
From (5) F < M, and (3) M < G.  

So relative order: F < K < Z(Thu), F < M < G, H < L(Sat), H < G.  

We need which must be true from options.

Step 7 – Check options

B) H < F? Not necessarily. Could H be after F? Possibly: F Mon, K Tue, Z Thu, M Fri, G Sat? But G can’t be Sat because L is Sat (two on Sat: L and G possible). But H < L and H < G, if G is Sat, H before Sat, maybe H Thu or Fri? But Z is Thu, so H Fri? Then F Mon, H Fri: H after F. So H < F not necessary.

Only A must be true.

Final answer  
The correct option is: A

But H < L (Sat) and K < Z. Z must be after K.  
If K < H, then F < K < H < L (Sat), and K < Z, so Z must be after K but could be before H? No, if K < H, then Z could be between H and L or after L? But L is Sat, so Z could be Sat (other than L) or Fri? Wait, days: Mon–Fri one each, Sat two.  

We have 7 people: F, G, H, K, L, M, Z. L is Sat. So 6 people for Mon–Fri (5 days) + 1 more on Sat (total 2 Sat). That means: 5 on Mon–Fri, 2 on Sat. So one of the non-L people is also Sat.  

So Z could be Sat (with L) or Fri.  

But if K < H, then K’s day is before H’s day. Z’s day after K’s day. So Z’s day ≥ K’s day + 1. If K is before H, then Z could be H’s day? No, only one librarian per day Mon–Fri. So if K Tue, H Thu, then Z could be Wed (between K and H) or Fri or Sat. But Z after K, so possible.  

So H before K is not necessary. So option A is not necessarily true.

Step 6 – Check H before Z (option B)

K < Z. F < K. So F < K < Z.  
We have F < H. But no constraint H < K, so possibly K after H. If K after H, then Z after K, so Z after H.  
If K before H, then Z after K but could be before H? Let’s test: F < K < H < L, then Z after K: Z could be between H and L (i.e., Z on Fri if H on Thu) or Sat. So Z after H in this case.  
If K after H: F < H < K < Z, then Z after H.  
So in all cases, is Z after H?  

Case 1: K before H: F < K < H. Then K < Z. Could Z be between K and H? No, because H is right after K? Not necessarily right after, but days: K on day dK, H on dH, dK < dH. Z must be after K, so Z’s day > dK. Could Z’s day be less than dH? Yes: e.g., K on Tue, H on Thu, Z on Wed. Then Z before H. So H before Z is false in that scenario.  

So option B is not necessarily true.

Step 7 – Check K before M (option C)  
We know F < M and F < K. No direct order between M and K. Could M be before K? Yes: F < M < K possible. Could K be before M? Yes: F < K < M possible. So not necessarily true.

If M before H: F < M < H < L. Also works.  

So M could be before or after H, but must M be before L? L is Sat, so any librarian except the one paired with L on Sat is before L in week? No, "earlier in the week" means day comparison. Since L is Saturday, every other librarian’s day is earlier except the other Saturday librarian. So M is not necessarily the other Saturday librarian. Could M be the other Sat librarian? Then M is not earlier than L (same day). But "earlier in the week" means strictly earlier day. So if M is also Saturday, then M is not earlier than L. So M could be Sat. Is that possible?  

Constraints: M < G. If M is Sat, then G must be after Sat — impossible. So G cannot be after Saturday. So M cannot be Saturday, because then no day for G after M. So M must be Mon–Fri. Thus M is earlier than L (Saturday). So M < L is necessarily true.

Wait, check: If Z is Friday, M is before Friday because G is after M and H, and G could be Sat, so M can be any day before Friday. But what if G is Friday? Then M before Friday. So M before Z. Yes. But careful: G’s day must be after M and after H. If Z is Friday, could G be Friday? No, G can’t be Friday if Z is Friday (one per day). So if Z is Friday, G must be Sat. Then M before Sat, but M could be Friday? No, Friday is Z. So M is before Friday. So M < Z. So indeed in all cases M < Z.  

So both D and E seem necessarily true. But the question says “which one of the following must be true?” So only one is correct. Did I make a mistake in E?  

Check E possibility: Z could be Wednesday? Then K < Z, so K before Wed. But then Z is before H possibly. But M? M could be after Z? Example:  
Order: F Mon, K Tue, Z Wed, H Thu, M Fri, G Sat, L Sat.  
Check constraints:

All good.  
Now M Fri, Z Wed: So M is not earlier than Z. So E is false.  

So E is not necessarily true.  

Thus only D is necessarily true.

Step 10 – Confirm D  
M cannot be Sat (because M < G and G can’t be after Sat). L is Sat, so M (Mon–Fri) is earlier than L (Sat). So D is true.

context: Seven librarians—Flynn, Gomez, Hill, Kitson, Leung, Moore, and Zahn—are being scheduled for desk duty for one week—Monday through Saturday. The librarians will be on duty exactly one day each. On each day except Saturday, there will be exactly one librarian on duty, with two on duty on Saturday, subject to the following constraints: Hill must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Leung. Both Hill and Moore must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Gomez. Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore. Kitson must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Zahn. Unless Leung is on desk duty on Saturday, Leung must be on desk duty earlier in the week than Flynn.
question: Which one of the following, if substituted for the constraint that Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Kitson and Moore, would have the same effect in determining the schedule for the librarians?
options: A) Flynn cannot be on desk duty on Thursday.
B) Only Flynn or Hill can be on desk duty on Monday.
C) Only Hill and Leung can be on desk duty earlier than Flynn.
D) Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Gomez and Kitson.
E) Flynn must be on desk duty earlier in the week than both Moore and Zahn.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Original constraints:
1. H < L (Hill earlier than Leung)
2. H < G and M < G (Hill earlier than Gomez, Moore earlier than Gomez)
3. F < K and F < M (Flynn earlier than Kitson, earlier than Moore)
4. K < Z (Kitson earlier than Zahn)
5. Unless Leung is on Saturday, L < F. (If L is not Saturday, then L < F.)

Step 1 – Understanding the original F < K and F < M effect  
From F < M and M < G, we get F < M < G.  
From F < K and K < Z, we get F < K < Z.  
Also, H < L and H < G.  

Where can F be?  
If L is not Saturday, then L < F. But if L < F and F < M < G and F < K < Z, then L is before F, M, K, Z, G.  
But H < L, so H is even earlier.  

Step 2 – Check if F < K and F < M can be replaced by something else  
We need to see which new constraint would force F to be before both K and M, just like the original.  

Let’s test each option:  

A) Flynn cannot be on desk duty on Thursday.  
• This just blocks Thursday for F, but doesn’t force F before K or M. K or M could be Monday–Wednesday and F on Friday, violating F < M. So no.  

B) Only Flynn or Hill can be on Monday.  
• This forces Monday = F or H.  

• If H is Monday, F could be Tuesday, M could be Monday? No, M can’t be Monday if H is Monday (only one per day except Saturday). Wait, Monday is one person. So if H is Monday, F is not Monday. Then M could be Wednesday, F on Tuesday: F < M okay. But what if F is Friday? Then M earlier than F violates F < M. So not necessarily F < M.  

Actually, let’s check: If F is not Monday, could M be Monday? Yes, if H is not Monday (then F or H only on Monday means Monday is F or H; if M is Monday, that’s impossible). So Monday must be F or H.  
If Monday = H, then F can be Tue–Sat. But M cannot be Monday (since Monday is H), so M is after Monday. But F could be after M unless we force F to be Monday if H is not Monday? Wait, but if H is not Monday, then F must be Monday. So either:  
Case 1: Monday = H → F on Tue–Sat, M on any day after Monday? But M could be Tuesday, F Wednesday: F < M? No, that’s M < F, which violates original but maybe allowed here? We lose F < M. So B doesn’t guarantee F < M. So B fails.  

C) Only Hill and Leung can be on desk duty earlier than Flynn.  
• Means: Anyone earlier than Flynn must be either Hill or Leung.  

• So if K is earlier than Flynn, K would have to be Hill or Leung — impossible since K is Kitson. So K cannot be earlier than Flynn ⇒ F < K.  

• If M is earlier than Flynn, M would have to be Hill or Leung — impossible. So M cannot be earlier than Flynn ⇒ F < M.  

• This exactly gives F < K and F < M.  

• Also, it doesn’t add extra restrictions (like forcing H or L to be after F) because H or L could be after F and that’s fine — constraint only restricts people earlier than F.  

D) F < G and F < K.  
• We already have F < K from original, but F < G is new.  

• But original had F < M, not F < G. Do we still get F < M?  

From original M < G, if we have F < G, that doesn’t force F < M: M could be before F (M < F) and still M < G, F < G. So M and F order is flexible. So D fails.  

E) F < M and F < Z.  
• We have F < M okay, but we lose F < K.  

• Could K be before F? If K < Z and F < Z, that doesn’t force F < K. So E fails.  

Step 3 – Conclusion  
Only C ensures F < K and F < M, which is exactly the original constraint’s effect.  

The correct option is: C

context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: Which one of the following is an allowable structure for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) slot 1: a finance feature; slot 2: an industry feature; slot 3: a second industry feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a graphic
B) slot 1: a graphic; slot 2: a technology feature; slot 3: a second technology feature; slot 4: a graphic; slot 5: a third technology feature
C) slots 1 and 2: a single industry feature; slots 3 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 5: a finance feature
D) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 3: a single industry feature; slot 4: a finance feature; slot 5: a graphic
E) slot 1: a technology feature; slots 2 and 4: a single marketing feature; slot 3: an industry feature; slot 5: a graphic
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go through each option step by step.

Rules summary:
1. At least 3 features per issue.  
2. Each feature occupies 1 or more consecutive slots.  
3. Any slot not containing a feature → graphic.  
4. If there’s a finance or technology feature in the issue, then slot 1 must be a finance or technology feature.  
5. At most one industry feature per issue.  

Option A:
• Slot 1: finance feature  

• Slot 2: industry feature  

• Slot 3: second industry feature  

• Slot 4: graphic  

• Slot 5: graphic  

Violates at most one industry feature rule (two industry features). → Not allowed.

Option B:
• Slot 1: graphic  

• Slot 2: technology feature  

• Slot 3: technology feature  

• Slot 4: graphic  

• Slot 5: technology feature  

Has a technology feature in issue, but slot 1 is graphic → violates "If finance or technology feature exists, slot 1 must be finance or technology". → Not allowed.

Option C:
• Slots 1–2: single industry feature  

• Slots 3–4: single marketing feature  

• Slot 5: finance feature  

Check features count: 3 features (industry, marketing, finance) → okay.  
Consecutive slots: Each feature occupies consecutive slots.  
Slot 1 rule: There is a finance feature in issue → slot 1 must be finance or technology. But slot 1 is industry feature → violates rule. → Not allowed.

Option D:
• Slot 1: technology feature  

• Slots 2–3: single industry feature  

• Slot 4: finance feature  

• Slot 5: graphic  

Features count: 3 features (technology, industry, finance) → okay.  
Consecutive slots: yes.  
Slot 1 rule: has finance/technology → slot 1 is technology → okay.  
At most one industry feature: yes, only one industry feature.  
No rule about marketing missing → okay.  
Features occupy slots 1, 2–3, 4 → slots 1, 2, 3, 4 have features; slot 5 graphic → total 3 features.  
Everything seems fine. → Allowed.

Option E:
• Slot 1: technology feature  

• Slots 2–4: single marketing feature  

• Slot 3: industry feature — wait, this is contradictory: slots 2–4 is a single marketing feature, so slot 3 cannot be a separate industry feature. Description is inconsistent: it says "slots 2 and 4: a single marketing feature" — but slots 2 and 4 are not consecutive; maybe typo? But as written, not consecutive slots → violates consecutive slots rule. → Not allowed.

Only D satisfies all rules.

The correct option is: D

context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: If an issue of the newsletter has no technology feature and if there is a finance feature that occupies both slots 4 and 5, then which one of the following is required for that issue?
options: A) A finance feature occupies slot 1.
B) A finance feature occupies slot 2 or slot 3 or both.
C) A marketing feature occupies slot 2.
D) An industry feature or a marketing feature occupies slot 2.
E) An industry feature or a marketing feature occupies slot 3.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break it down.  

Given constraints from the general policy:  
1. At least 3 features per issue.  
2. Each feature occupies 1 or more consecutive slots.  
3. 4 types: Finance (F), Industry (I), Marketing (M), Technology (T).  
4. If an issue has any F or T feature, then an F or T feature must occupy slot 1.  
5. At most one I feature.  
6. Non-feature slots contain graphics.  

Specifics for this question:  
• No technology feature.  

• A finance feature occupies slots 4 and 5 (so it’s a 2-slot feature, F in slots 4–5).  

• Since there’s an F feature, rule 4 applies: an F or T feature must occupy slot 1. But T is absent, so slot 1 must be F.  

So immediately, A) A finance feature occupies slot 1 is true. But is it “required” for this issue?  
Yes — given the conditions, slot 1 must be F.  

Check if any other option is required:  
• Slot 1 is F.  

• Slots 4–5 are F.  

• That’s at least 2 features (F in slot 1, F in slots 4–5). But we need at least 3 features.  

• So at least one more feature in slots 2–3.  

Could that feature be F? Possibly, but F features can be adjacent or separate. But if slot 2 is F, then slot 1–2 would be one F feature (since consecutive slots with same type = one feature). But then slot 4–5 is a separate F feature. That’s 2 F features, but still only 2 features total (F in 1–2, F in 4–5) — that’s 2 features, not enough. So we’d need a third feature in slot 3.  

So to meet “at least 3 features,” the simplest is: slot 1 = F (1 slot), slot 4–5 = F (1 feature), and slot 2 or 3 or both must contain at least one feature of type I or M (since T is out, F is possible but must be careful not to merge with slot 1’s F and reduce feature count).  

But could slot 2 be F? If slot 2 is F, then slot 1 and 2 merge into one F feature (feature#1: slots 1–2), slot 3 could be M (feature#2), slot 4–5 F (feature#3). That works. So slot 2 is not required to be M or I.  

So B) “A finance feature occupies slot 2 or 3 or both” is not required — could be M or I instead.  
C) “Marketing occupies slot 2” — not required, could be I or F.  
D) “Industry or Marketing occupies slot 2” — not required, could be F in slot 2 (merged with slot 1 F).  
E) “Industry or Marketing occupies slot 3” — not required, could be F in slot 3 (but if slot 3 is F, it cannot merge with slot 4’s F unless slot 2 is also F, but that’s possible; but anyway not required).  

Only A is necessarily true: because F exists in the issue, slot 1 must be F or T, but T is absent, so slot 1 = F.  

The correct option is: A

The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: Which one of the following is NOT allowed for an issue of the newsletter?
options: A) There is exactly one industry feature, and it occupies slot 1.
B) There is exactly one finance feature, and it occupies slot 2.
C) There is exactly one technology feature, and it occupies slot 3.
D) Each feature except the feature occupying slot 1 is either a finance feature or a marketing feature.
E) Each feature except the feature occupying slot 5 is either an industry feature or a marketing feature.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

Rules recap:

1. 5 slots numbered 1–5.
2. At least 3 features per issue (so at most 2 graphics).
3. Each feature occupies 1 or more consecutive slots.
4. 4 types: Finance (F), Industry (I), Marketing (M), Technology (T).
5. Any multi-slot feature must occupy consecutive slots.
6. If an issue has any F or T feature, then a F or T feature must occupy slot 1.
7. At most one I feature.

Check each option for violation:

A) Exactly one I feature, occupies slot 1.  
• Slot 1 is I.  

• Rule 6: If there’s any F or T feature, slot 1 must be F or T. But here slot 1 is I. So that means the issue cannot have any F or T feature at all.  

• So only I and M features allowed.  

• Possible? Yes: e.g., I in slot 1, M in slot 3, M in slot 5 (3 features total).  

• No rule broken. Allowed.

B) Exactly one F feature, occupies slot 2.  
• Rule 6: There is an F feature (in slot 2), so slot 1 must be F or T.  

• But slot 1 is not F (F is only in slot 2) and not T (no T mentioned).  

• So slot 1 must be a graphic or some other feature type? Wait, slot 1 could be a graphic only if slot 1 is not part of a feature. But if slot 1 is a graphic, then slot 1 is not F or T feature, violating rule 6.  

• So slot 1 must be F or T feature. But the option says exactly one F feature, in slot 2. So slot 1 cannot be F (else more than one F feature? Actually, "exactly one F feature" means F appears only in that feature; if slot 1 is F, then that’s the F feature, not slot 2. So impossible for slot 2 to be F if slot 1 is F unless they’re the same feature, but then it would occupy slots 1 and 2, so slot 2 is part of the same F feature, not a separate F feature. But the statement says: exactly one F feature, and it occupies slot 2. That means the F feature is only in slot 2, so slot 1 is not F.  

• Could slot 1 be T? Yes, possible: slot 1 T, slot 2 F, etc. That satisfies rule 6.  

• But wait: slot 1 T is allowed? Yes, rule 6 says F or T in slot 1 if there’s any F or T in the issue. There is F in slot 2, so slot 1 must be F or T. Slot 1 could be T. So no violation yet.  

• But is there any other rule broken?  

• The only constraint is at most one I feature, but here I is not mentioned, so could be 0 I features.  

• So seems allowed: e.g., T in slot 1, F in slot 2, M in slot 4, graphic in slot 3 and 5.  

• So allowed.

C) Exactly one T feature, occupies slot 3.  
• Rule 6: There is a T feature (in slot 3), so slot 1 must be F or T.  

• Could slot 1 be T? No, because exactly one T feature, in slot 3. So slot 1 cannot be T.  

• Could slot 1 be F? Yes: slot 1 F, slot 3 T. That satisfies rule 6.  

• So possible: e.g., F in slot 1, T in slot 3, M in slot 5.  

• Allowed.

D) Each feature except the feature occupying slot 1 is either F or M.  
• So slot 1’s feature can be I or T or F or M.  

• But if slot 1’s feature is I or M, then any F or T elsewhere? No: because if there’s F or T anywhere, slot 1 must be F or T. So if slot 1 is I or M, then there can be no F or T feature in the issue.  

• But option says: every feature except slot 1’s feature is F or M. So the other features are F or M.  

• If there’s an F feature in other slots, then issue has F → slot 1 must be F or T. But slot 1 is not F or T (since other features are F or M, and slot 1’s feature is different type from others? Not necessarily: slot 1 could be M, others could be F or M. But if there’s an F in others, then issue has F → slot 1 must be F or T. But slot 1 is M → violation.  

• So to avoid violation: if any other feature is F, then slot 1 must be F or T. But if slot 1 is F, then slot 1’s feature is F, but then the rule “each feature except slot 1’s feature is F or M” means other features are F or M, that’s fine.  

• If slot 1 is T, then others are F or M, that’s fine.  

• So possible arrangements: slot 1 = F, other features F or M; or slot 1 = T, other features F or M.  

• But what if slot 1 = I? Then no F or T in issue, so others must be M only (since others must be F or M, but F not allowed). So possible: slot 1 I, others M.  

• Similarly slot 1 = M, others must be M or F, but F not allowed (since F would require slot 1 F or T), so others must be M only.  

• So possible in all cases. Allowed.

E) Each feature except the feature occupying slot 5 is either I or M.  
• So slot 5’s feature is not I or M → so it must be F or T.  

• Other features (including possibly slot 1’s feature) are I or M.  

• But if there’s an F or T feature in slot 5, then issue has F or T → rule 6: slot 1 must be F or T.  

• But slot 1’s feature is one of the “other features” (since not slot 5’s feature), so must be I or M.  

• Contradiction: slot 1 must be F or T, but is I or M.  

• So impossible.  

Thus E is not allowed.

The correct option is: E

context: Each issue of a business newsletter has five slots, numbered 1 through 5. The policy of the newsletter requires that there are at least three features per issue, with each feature completely occupying one or more of the slots. Each feature can be one of four types—finance, industry, marketing, or technology. Any slot not containing a feature contains a graphic. The newsletters policy further requires that each issue be structured as follows: Any feature occupying more than one slot must occupy consecutively numbered slots. If an issue has any finance or technology feature, then a finance or technology feature must occupy slot 1. An issue can have at most one industry feature.
question: If, in a particular issue of the newsletter, slot 1 is occupied by the only industry feature in that issue, then which one of the following is required for that issue?
options: A) There is an industry feature that occupies slots 1 and 2, and only those slots.
B) There is an industry feature that occupies slots 1, 2, and 3, and only those slots.
C) There is a marketing feature that occupies slot 2 or slot 3 or both.
D) There is a marketing feature that occupies one or more of slots 2, 3, and 4.
E) There is a marketing feature that occupies slot 3 or slot 5 or both.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.  

Step 1 – Restate constraints  
1. 5 slots numbered 1–5.  
2. At least 3 features per issue (so at most 2 graphics).  
3. Each feature occupies 1 or more consecutive slots.  
4. Four types: Finance (F), Industry (I), Marketing (M), Technology (T).  
5. If there’s any F or T feature, then a F or T feature must occupy slot 1.  
6. At most one industry feature per issue.  

Step 2 – Given condition for this particular issue  
Slot 1 is occupied by the only industry feature in that issue.  
So slot 1 = Industry feature.  

Step 3 – Check rule 5  
Rule 5 says: if there’s any F or T feature, then slot 1 must be F or T.  
But slot 1 is I here.  
So this means: the issue cannot have any F or T features at all.  
Why? Because if it had any F or T, slot 1 would have to be F or T, but it’s I. Contradiction.  
So F=0, T=0 in this issue.  

Step 4 – Possible features  
Only possible types: I (Industry) and M (Marketing).  
We have exactly 1 I feature (occupies slot 1, maybe more consecutive slots).  
We need at least 3 features in the issue.  
So: 1 I feature + at least 2 M features.  

Step 5 – Structure of the issue  
Slot 1 is I. I can be 1 slot only, or 1+2, or 1+2+3, etc., but must be consecutive starting at slot 1.  

If I occupies only slot 1: then slots 2–5 must be filled with at least 2 M features (and maybe graphics, but at most 2 graphics because at least 3 features total; we already have I, so need 2 more features, so M features ≥ 2).  

If I occupies more than 1 slot: e.g., slots 1–2: then slot 3–5 must have at least 2 M features. Similarly for longer I.  

Step 6 – Where can M features be?  
We know there are at least 2 M features. They can be anywhere except slot 1 (since slot 1 is I).  
They can be in slots 2–5, but each M feature occupies 1+ consecutive slots.  

Step 7 – Check options  
A) I occupies slots 1 and 2 only. Not necessarily true — I could be slot 1 only, or 1–3, etc. So not required.  
B) I occupies slots 1–3 only. Not necessarily true.  
C) M feature occupies slot 2 or slot 3 or both. Is this required?  
Let’s test: Could M features avoid slot 2 and slot 3 entirely?  
If I is slot 1 only: then slot 2 could be graphic. Then to have 2 M features, they’d need to be in slots 3–5. But if slot 3 is graphic, then M features must be in slots 4–5, but that’s only 2 consecutive slots, enough for 2 M features only if each is length 1 (slot 4 = M1, slot 5 = M2). That’s possible. So M features could be in slots 4 and 5 only, avoiding slot 2 and slot 3. So C is not required.  

D) M occupies one or more of slots 2, 3, and 4.  
Test: Can M avoid slots 2, 3, and 4 entirely?  
If M avoids 2,3,4, then M only in slot 5. But we need at least 2 M features. Impossible because only slot 5 available for M, can’t fit 2 separate M features there. So at least one M feature must be in slots 2, 3, or 4. Yes, that’s forced.  

E) M occupies slot 3 or slot 5 or both.  
Test: Could M avoid slot 3 and slot 5? Then M only in slots 2 and/or 4.  
Example: I in slot 1 only, slot 2 = M1 (1 slot), slot 4 = M2 (1 slot), slot 3 and 5 graphics. That works: Features: I, M1, M2 → 3 features. No M in slot 3 or 5. So E is not required.  

Step 8 – Conclusion  
Only D is necessarily true: an M feature must occupy at least one of slots 2, 3, or 4.  

The correct option is: D

context: Six entertainers—Robinson, Shahpari, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton, and Zane—are being scheduled for the six performances on the opening day of a community festival. Each entertainer will perform at one of six times—in the morning at 9:00 A.M., 10:00 A.M., or 11:00 A.M., or in the afternoon at 2:00 P.M., 3:00 P.M., or 4:00 P.M.—with no two entertainers performing at the same scheduled time. The order in which the entertainers perform is subject to the following constraints: Robinson must perform at some time before Zane. Yeaton's performance must be the next performance after Wu's. Tigay must perform in the afternoon. Zane must perform in the morning.
question: Which one of the following could be the order, from first to last, in which the entertainers are scheduled to perform?
options: A) Robinson, Shahpari, Zane, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton
B) Robinson, Wu, Yeaton, Zane, Shahpari, Tigay
C) Robinson, Zane, Tigay, Shahpari, Wu, Yeaton
D) Shahpari, Robinson, Zane, Wu, Tigay, Yeaton
E) Wu, Yeaton, Zane, Shahpari, Tigay, Robinson
reasoning_cot:
Let’s check each constraint against the options.  

Constraints:  
1. Robinson before Zane. (R < Z)  
2. Yeaton’s performance is the next after Wu’s. (WY consecutive, in that order)  
3. Tigay in the afternoon (times: 2:00, 3:00, 4:00 PM → positions 4, 5, or 6 in the list).  
4. Zane in the morning (times: 9:00, 10:00, 11:00 AM → positions 1, 2, or 3 in the list).  

Option A: Robinson, Shahpari, Zane, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton  
• R before Z: ✓ (1st before 3rd)  

• WY consecutive? W is 5th, Y is 6th → ✓  

• Tigay in afternoon? Tigay is 4th → ✓ (4th slot is 2:00 PM, which is afternoon)  

• Zane in morning? Zane is 3rd → ✓ (11:00 AM is morning)  

All constraints satisfied.  

Option B: Robinson, Wu, Yeaton, Zane, Shahpari, Tigay  
• R before Z: ✓ (1st before 4th)  

• WY consecutive? W is 2nd, Y is 3rd → ✓  

• Tigay in afternoon? Tigay is 6th → ✓  

• Zane in morning? Zane is 4th → ✗ (4th slot is 2:00 PM, not morning)  

Fails.  

Option C: Robinson, Zane, Tigay, Shahpari, Wu, Yeaton  
• R before Z: ✓ (1st before 2nd)  

• WY consecutive? W is 5th, Y is 6th → ✓  

• Tigay in afternoon? Tigay is 3rd → ✗ (3rd slot is 11:00 AM, not afternoon)  

Fails.  

Option D: Shahpari, Robinson, Zane, Wu, Tigay, Yeaton  
• R before Z: ✓ (2nd before 3rd)  

• WY consecutive? W is 4th, Y is 6th → ✗ (Tigay is between them)  

Fails.  

Option E: Wu, Yeaton, Zane, Shahpari, Tigay, Robinson  
• R before Z? R is 6th, Z is 3rd → ✗ (R after Z)  

Fails.  

Only A satisfies all constraints.  

The correct option is: A

context: Six entertainers—Robinson, Shahpari, Tigay, Wu, Yeaton, and Zane—are being scheduled for the six performances on the opening day of a community festival. Each entertainer will perform at one of six times—in the morning at 9:00 A.M., 10:00 A.M., or 11:00 A.M., or in the afternoon at 2:00 P.M., 3:00 P.M., or 4:00 P.M.—with no two entertainers performing at the same scheduled time. The order in which the entertainers perform is subject to the following constraints: Robinson must perform at some time before Zane. Yeaton's performance must be the next performance after Wu's. Tigay must perform in the afternoon. Zane must perform in the morning.
question: If Wu is scheduled to perform in the morning, then which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Robinson is scheduled to perform at 10:00 A.M.
B) Shahpari is scheduled to perform at 3:00 P.M.
C) Tigay is scheduled to perform at 2:00 P.M.
D) Yeaton is scheduled to perform at 3:00 P.M.
E) Zane is scheduled to perform at 11:00 A.M.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down.

Given constraints:
1. Robinson before Zane (R < Z).
2. Yeaton’s performance is next after Wu’s (W → Y consecutively, in that order).
3. Tigay in the afternoon (2:00, 3:00, or 4:00 P.M.).
4. Zane in the morning (9:00, 10:00, or 11:00 A.M.).
5. Wu in the morning (given in the “if” condition).

Morning slots: 9:00, 10:00, 11:00.  
Afternoon slots: 2:00, 3:00, 4:00.

Zane is in morning, Wu is in morning, and W→Y consecutively.  
If W and Y are both in the morning, possible consecutive morning slots:  
(9,10) or (10,11).  

So possible W–Y pairs:  
• W at 9, Y at 10  

• W at 10, Y at 11  

Zane must be after Robinson, so R must be in the morning (since Z is in morning and R < Z).  

Thus morning people: R, Z, W, Y. That’s 4 people in morning slots.  
But morning has only 3 slots → contradiction.  

So W and Y cannot both be in the morning.  

Therefore, W in morning → Y must be in afternoon.  

So W–Y consecutive across morning–afternoon boundary:  
Only possible morning–afternoon consecutive: 11:00 A.M. → 2:00 P.M.  

Thus:  
W at 11:00 A.M., Y at 2:00 P.M.  

Morning slots: 9:00, 10:00, 11:00 (W at 11:00).  
Morning people: R, Z, W, and one more (Shahpari or Tigay? No, Tigay in afternoon, so Tigay not in morning).  
Morning: R, Z, W, and S? Wait, total 6 people: R, S, T, W, Y, Z.  

Morning must have R, Z, W, and one of S or T? But T is afternoon, so morning people = R, Z, W, S. That’s 4 people for 3 slots → impossible.  

Hold on — I made a mistake:  
Morning slots: 9, 10, 11.  
People in morning: Z (morning), W (morning 11), R (morning, because R before Z and Z in morning, so R in morning too).  
That’s R, Z, W all in morning. Morning has 3 slots, so only these 3 can be in morning.  

Thus S, T, Y must be in afternoon.  

But Y is at 2:00 P.M. (first afternoon slot) from W at 11:00 A.M.  

So afternoon: Y (2:00), then two slots 3:00 and 4:00 for S and T.  

Morning order:  
Slots 9, 10, 11 occupied by R, Z, W in some order with R before Z and W at 11:00.  

So W fixed at 11:00.

question: What is the earliest time that Wu could be scheduled to perform?
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

1. Fixed time-of-day constraints:  
• Tigay → afternoon (2:00, 3:00, or 4:00 PM)  

• Zane → morning (9:00, 10:00, or 11:00 AM)  

• Robinson before Zane (so Robinson must be in the morning too, because if Robinson were in the afternoon, Zane would have to be after him, but Zane is in the morning — impossible).  

So: Robinson and Zane are both in the morning, with Robinson before Zane.  

2. Wu–Yeaton constraint:  
Yeaton’s performance must be the next after Wu’s (Wu → Yeaton consecutively, in that order).  

3. Morning slots:  
Morning: 9, 10, 11 AM (3 slots)  
Afternoon: 2, 3, 4 PM (3 slots)  

Morning already has Robinson and Zane (2 people).  
If Wu is in the morning, then Yeaton must also be in the morning (because Wu → Yeaton consecutively).  
That would fill all 3 morning slots: Robinson, Zane, Wu, Yeaton → but that’s 4 people in morning — impossible.  
So Wu cannot be in the morning.  

4. Wu must be in the afternoon.  
So Wu is in one of 2, 3, 4 PM.  
Earliest possible Wu time = 2:00 PM.  

Check if 2:00 PM possible:  
If Wu at 2:00 PM, Yeaton at 3:00 PM.  
Morning: Robinson, Zane, and the 3rd morning slot is someone else (Shahpari or Tigay? But Tigay is afternoon, so morning’s 3rd person is Shahpari).  
Afternoon: Wu (2:00), Yeaton (3:00), Tigay (4:00) works fine.  
Robinson before Zane in morning: possible (e.g., Robinson 9:00, Shahpari 10:00, Zane 11:00).  

No rule prevents Wu at 2:00 PM.  

5. Could Wu be earlier than 2:00 PM?  
No, because Wu can’t be in morning.  

So earliest possible Wu = 2:00 PM.  

The correct option is: D

reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.

Morning: 3 slots (9, 10, 11). Zane is in morning, so Z occupies 1 morning slot.  
R is before Z, so R must be in morning as well (since afternoon is after morning; if R were in afternoon, R couldn’t be before Z because Z is in morning).  
So R is in morning.  
Thus morning has R, Z, and one more person.

3. Afternoon slots:
Afternoon: 3 slots (2pm, 3pm, 4pm). T is in afternoon (given), so T occupies 1 afternoon slot.  
WY is a block of 2 consecutive performances. Where can WY go?

4. Possible positions for WY block:
If WY entirely in morning: morning already has R, Z, and WY (4 people) — impossible (morning has only 3 slots). So WY cannot both be in morning.  
If WY entirely in afternoon: afternoon has T, W, Y (3 people) — possible. Then morning is R, Z, and the 6th person (Shahpari).  
If WY crosses morning-afternoon boundary: W in last morning slot (11am), Y in first afternoon slot (2pm) — possible? Let’s check:  
Morning: R, Z, W (W at 11am), Y at 2pm. Afternoon: Y, T, and Shahpari? Wait, afternoon: Y (2pm), T (3pm or 4pm), and Shahpari (the remaining afternoon slot). That works.  

So two possible cases for WY:  
Case 1: WY both in afternoon.  
Case 2: WY across boundary (W in morning last slot, Y in afternoon first slot).

5. Who must be in afternoon?
T is fixed in afternoon.  
Y: is Y always in afternoon?  
• In Case 1: Y in afternoon.  

• In Case 2: Y in afternoon.  

So Y is always in afternoon.  
Thus T and Y are fixed in afternoon.

W: must W be in afternoon?  
• In Case 1: W in afternoon.  

• In Case 2: W in morning (last morning slot).  

So W is not necessarily in afternoon.  

Shahpari: could be in morning or afternoon depending on arrangement.  

Thus the only ones guaranteed in afternoon: T and Y.

6. Check options:
A) Tigay only — no, Y also must be in afternoon.  
B) Tigay, Wu — no, Wu not necessarily.  
C) Tigay, Yeaton — yes.  
D) Tigay, Wu, Yeaton — no, Wu not necessarily.

Final answer: C.

The correct option is: C

Park's bowl can be displayed only if it is next to Olivera's bowl and next to Serra's bowl. Reigel's bowl can be displayed only in either position 1 or position 6. Serra's bowl cannot be displayed in either position 2 or position 4. Neiman's bowl can be displayed only in position 5.
question: If Park's bowl is displayed in position 4, then the bowl displayed in position 2 must be
options: A) Larsen's, Mills's, or Vance's
B) Larsen's, Neiman's, or Vance's
C) Larsen's, Serra's, or Vance's
D) Mills's, Reigel's, or Vance's
E) Mills's, Serra's, or Vance's
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through this step by step.

Step 1 – Understanding the fixed conditions  
• 6 bowls displayed out of 8 potters.  

• Larsen → not Mills (so at most one of L, M is in the display).  

• Park → must be next to Olivera and next to Serra (so Park must be between Olivera and Serra, or they on either side of Park).  

• Reigel → only in position 1 or 6.  

• Serra → not in position 2 or 4.  

• Neiman → only in position 5.  

Step 2 – Park in position 4  
If Park is in 4, then Park must be next to Olivera and next to Serra.  
Positions next to 4: 3 and 5.  
So Olivera and Serra must be in positions 3 and 5 (in some order).  

But Neiman must be in position 5 (fixed).  
So 5 = Neiman, not Olivera or Serra.  
This is a contradiction? Wait — check: If Park in 4, neighbors are 3 and 5.  
For Park to be next to Olivera and Serra, Olivera must be in 3 or 5, Serra in 3 or 5.  
But 5 is Neiman (fixed), so 5 cannot be Olivera or Serra.  
Thus both Olivera and Serra must be in position 3 — but impossible, only one bowl in position 3.  

So Park cannot be in 4?  
But the question says: If Park’s bowl is displayed in position 4 — so maybe the “next to” condition means adjacent to both, but not necessarily both in adjacent positions? Let’s check wording:  

Park's bowl can be displayed only if it is next to Olivera's bowl and next to Serra's bowl.

That means: Park must be adjacent to Olivera AND adjacent to Serra.  
So Olivera and Serra must be in two different positions, both adjacent to Park.  

Adjacent positions to 4: 3 and 5.  
So Olivera in 3, Serra in 5, or Olivera in 5, Serra in 3.  

But 5 is Neiman (fixed).  
So 5 cannot be Olivera or Serra.  
Thus impossible.  

So the hypothetical “Park in 4” is impossible given Neiman fixed in 5.  

Step 3 – Rethink  
Maybe I misread: Neiman’s bowl can be displayed only in position 5 — but maybe Neiman is not necessarily displayed?  
We have 6 bowls displayed out of 8 potters, so 2 potters’ bowls are not displayed.  
So maybe Neiman is one of the 2 not displayed. Then position 5 is someone else.  

Yes! That’s it: Neiman’s bowl can be displayed only in position 5 — meaning if Neiman is displayed, it must be in 5. But Neiman might not be displayed at all.  

So for Park in 4 to be possible, Neiman must not be displayed (because if Neiman displayed → in 5 → then 5 not available for Olivera/Serra, which is required for Park in 4).  

So Neiman is out.  

Step 4 – Assign neighbors for Park in 4  
Positions adjacent to 4: 3 and 5.  
So Olivera in 3 or 5, Serra in 3 or 5, but not same position.  
So {Olivera, Serra} = {3, 5} in some order.  

Thus positions 3 and 5 are occupied by Olivera and Serra.  

Step 5 – Remaining positions and potters  
Displayed: Park(4), Olivera(3 or 5), Serra(5 or 3), plus 3 more bowls from remaining potters: Larsen, Mills, Reigel, Vance (Neiman out, Olivera, Serra, Park in).  

Remaining potters: {Larsen, Mills, Reigel, Vance, (Olivera, Serra, Park already in)}.  
We need 6 total displayed: we have 3 (Park, O, S) + 3 more from {L, M, R, V} (4 people) → so 1 of {L, M, R, V} is not displayed.  

Positions left: 1, 2, 6 (since 3, 4, 5 taken by O, P, S in some arrangement).  

Actually: positions:  
• 3: Olivera or Serra  

• 4: Park  

• 5: Serra or Olivera  

So 3,4,5 filled.  
Remaining: positions 1, 2, 6.  

We must fill 1, 2, 6 with 3 bowls from {L, M, R, V}.  

Step 6 – Constraints on positions 1 and 6  
Reigel: only in 1 or 6. So if Reigel displayed, must be in 1 or 6.  
We have 3 people for 3 spots {1, 2, 6}, so all of {L, M, R, V} except one not displayed.  

If Reigel not displayed, then {L, M, V} fill {1, 2, 6} in some order.  
If Reigel displayed, then Reigel in 1 or 6, and {L, M, V} minus one fill the other two spots.  

Step 7 – Focus on position 2  
We want: who can be in position 2?  

From {L, M, R, V}, can Reigel be in 2? No, Reigel only in 1 or 6. So Reigel not in 2.  

So position 2 is occupied by one of {L, M, V} (since Neiman out, O, S, P in 3,4,5, R can’t be in 2).  

So possible occupants of position 2: L, M, or V.  

That matches option A: Larsen’s, Mills’s, or Vance’s.  

Check others:  
B: includes Neiman — impossible (Neiman not displayed).  
C: includes Serra — impossible (Serra in 3 or 5).  
D: includes Reigel — impossible (Reigel can’t be in 2).  
E: includes Serra — impossible.  

So only A fits.  

Step 8 – Verify Larsen–Mills conflict  
Larsen and Mills cannot both be displayed. But both could be in the candidate set for position 2?  
We said position 2 is L, M, or V. But if position 2 is M, then L cannot be displayed. That’s fine — the question asks “must be” in the sense of which set of possible potters for position 2.  
So indeed possible:  
• If L displayed → in 1, 2, or 6.  

• If M displayed → in 1, 2, or 6.  

• V displayed similarly.  

So position 2’s possible occupants are {L, M, V}.  

The correct option is: A

• Check Serra not in 2 or 4: Serra in 2 — violates Serra constraint? Yes! Constraint says: Serra cannot be in 2 or 4. So Serra in 2 is not allowed.  

→ So Case 1 fails.  

Case 2: Park in 5 → Serra in 6 (to be next to Park).

• Remaining positions: 2, 3, and we have used L, O, P, S. Need 2 more bowls from {N, R, V} (Mills out).

• So displayed: L, O, P, S, plus V in 2 or 3, and one of N or R? But N can’t be in 5, so N not displayed; R can’t be in 1 or 6, so R not displayed. So we have only 5 displayed: L, O, P, S, V. We need 6 total. We’re short 1.

→ Case 2 fails.  

Thus Park cannot be displayed in either possible placement without violating constraints.
