context: An economics department is assigning six teaching assistants—Ramos, Smith, Taj, Vogel, Yi, and Zane—to three courses—Labor, Markets, and Pricing. Each assistant will be assigned to exactly one course, and each course will have at least one assistant assigned to it. The assignment of assistants to courses is subject to the following conditions: Markets must have exactly two assistants assigned to it. Smith and Taj must be assigned to the same course as each other. Vogel and Yi cannot be assigned to the same course as each other. Yi and Zane must both be assigned to Pricing if either one of them is.
question: If Vogel is assigned to the same course as Zane, which one of the following CANNOT be true?
options: A) Ramos is assigned to Labor.
B) Smith is assigned to Labor.
C) Taj is assigned to Markets.
D) Ramos is assigned to Pricing.
E) Smith is assigned to Pricing.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through the constraints step by step.  

Given:  
• 6 assistants: R, S, T, V, Y, Z  

• 3 courses: L, M, P  

• Each course has ≥1 assistant.  

• Markets (M) has exactly 2 assistants.  

• S and T are together.  

• V and Y are not together.  

• If Y or Z is in P, then both Y and Z are in P.  

• Extra condition for this question: V and Z are in the same course.  

Step 1: Use V and Z together.  
V and Y cannot be together, so Y cannot be in the same course as V.  
Since V and Z are together, Y cannot be in the same course as Z either.  

But the rule says: If Y or Z is in P, then both Y and Z are in P.  
But if Z is in P, then V is in P (since V and Z together), so Y would have to be in P (by the Y/Z rule), but then V and Y would be together → violates “V and Y not together.”  
Thus: Z cannot be in P (because that would force Y into P, which would put V and Y together).  

So Z is not in P, and Y is not in P either (because if Y were in P, then Z would be in P, contradiction).  

So Y and Z are both not in P.  

Step 2: Where are V and Z?  
They are together, but not in P (since Z not in P). So V and Z are in either L or M.  

M has exactly 2 assistants. Could V and Z be in M? Possibly, but then M would be {V, Z} exactly.  

Step 3: S and T together.  
They could be in L or M or P. But P currently has no one yet, and P must have at least 1 assistant. Could S and T be in P? Yes, because Y and Z are not in P, so P could have S and T and maybe R.  

But let’s check constraints: If S and T are in P, that’s fine because Y/Z rule only involves Y and Z, not S and T.  

Step 4: Try possibilities to see which option CANNOT be true.  

We know:  
• M = exactly 2.  

• V and Z together in L or M.  

• Y is not with V, so Y is in the course that V is not in.  

Case 1: V and Z in M. Then M = {V, Z}.  
Then Y cannot be in M, so Y is in L or P. But Y not in P (since Z not in P forces Y not in P). So Y in L.  
Remaining: R, S, T to place in L and P.  
S and T together: They could both be in L (then L = {Y, S, T}, P = {R}), or both in P (then L = {Y}, P = {R, S, T}).  
Both valid.  

Case 2: V and Z in L. Then Y not in L, so Y in M or P. But Y not in P, so Y in M.  
M has exactly 2, so M = {Y, ?}. The other in M must be R or S or T. But S and T must be together, so if one of S or T is in M, both are in M, but then M would have 3 (Y, S, T) → impossible because M has exactly 2.  
So S and T cannot be in M in this case. So the other person in M is R. So M = {Y, R}.  
Then S and T must be together in P (since L already has V and Z, and P must have at least 1, so S and T in P works).  
So L = {V, Z}, M = {Y, R}, P = {S, T}.  

Step 5: Check options for impossibility.  

Option A: Ramos in Labor.  
• In Case 1 (V, Z in M; Y in L; S, T in P; R in L) → possible.  

• In Case 2: Ramos in M, so not in L. But maybe another case? Actually in Case 2, R in M fixed, so R in L impossible in that case, but question asks “CANNOT be true” meaning impossible in all possible valid assignments. Since it’s possible in Case 1, A can be true.  

Option B: Smith in Labor.  
• Case 1: S in L possible (with T and Y in L, P = {R}).  

• Case 2: S in P only, so S in L impossible in Case 2, but possible in Case 1, so B can be true.  

Option C: Taj in Markets.  
• Markets has exactly 2. If T in M, then S in M, so M = {S, T}.  

But V and Z together: where? Could be in L or P.  
Check Y/Z rule: If V and Z in P, then Y in P (by rule) → possible? M={S,T}, P={V,Z,Y}, L={R}. That’s valid: V and Z together in P, Y in P, V and Y together? Violates V and Y not together! So V and Z cannot be in P if Y also in P. So V and Z cannot be in P in this scenario.  
So V and Z in L. Then Y not with V, so Y not in L, so Y in M or P. But M full (S, T), so Y in P. But then Y in P forces Z in P, but Z in L → contradiction.  
So T in Markets impossible.  

Let’s check carefully:  
T in M → S in M → M = {S, T}.  
V, Z together in L or P.  
If V,Z in L: Y not in L, so Y in P. But Y in P forces Z in P, but Z in L → impossible.  
If V,Z in P: Y in P (by rule) → P contains V, Z, Y. But V and Y together → violates V and Y not together.  
So indeed T in M is impossible in all scenarios.  

So C is impossible.  

Step 6: Verify others can be true.  

D: Ramos in Pricing — possible in Case 1: M={V,Z}, L={Y,S,T}, P={R}. Works.  
E: Smith in Pricing — possible in Case 2: L={V,Z}, M={Y,R}, P={S,T}. Works.  

So only C is impossible.  

The correct option is: C

question: If no other assistant is assigned to the same course as Ramos, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) Taj is assigned to Labor.
B) Vogel is assigned to Labor.
C) Yi is assigned to Markets.
D) Zane is assigned to Markets.
E) Smith is assigned to Pricing
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through this step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the constraints  
• 6 assistants: R, S, T, V, Y, Z.  

• 3 courses: L, M, P.  

• M has exactly 2 assistants.  

• S and T together.  

• V and Y not together.  

• If Y or Z is in P, then both Y and Z are in P.  

• New condition: No other assistant is assigned to the same course as R → R is alone in his course.  

Step 2 – Implications of R being alone  
Since R is alone, his course has exactly 1 person.  
M has exactly 2 people.  
So the remaining course must have 6 − 1 − 2 = 3 people.  

So distribution: (1, 2, 3) among the 3 courses.  

Step 3 – Which course is R in?  
Possibilities: R in L, M, or P?  

If R in M: M has 2 people, but R is alone → impossible (M would have only R, contradicting M=2).  
So R not in M.  

So R in L or P.  

Step 4 – Consider S and T  
S and T are together, so they can’t be with R (since R is alone).  
So S and T must be in the 2-person course or the 3-person course, but not in R’s course.  

Step 5 – Consider M’s occupants  
M has exactly 2 people. Could S and T be in M? Possibly.  
If S and T are in M, then M is full (S, T).  

Then R is alone in either L or P. The remaining 3 people (V, Y, Z) must be in the remaining course (the 3-person course).  

Step 6 – Check Y and Z rule  
If Y and Z are both in the 3-person course, that’s fine with the rule (if either is in P, both are in P).  
But is that 3-person course L or P?  

Case 1: R in L alone → then 3-person course is P (V, Y, Z).  
Rule: Y in P → Z in P (OK, Z is there). V and Y together? Yes, but V and Y not allowed together → conflict! So impossible.  

So if S, T in M, then R cannot be in L (because then P gets V, Y, Z together, violating V and Y separate).  

Case 2: R in P alone → then 3-person course is L (V, Y, Z).  
Now V and Y together in L → conflict! So also impossible.  

Thus S and T cannot both be in M.  

Step 7 – So S and T are in the 3-person course  
Then M’s 2 people are not S and T.  
So M has 2 people from {V, Y, Z, R?} but R is alone in his course, so R not in M.  
So M’s 2 are from {V, Y, Z} possibly plus one more? Wait, total 6: R (1), M (2), other course (3).  

The 3-person course contains S and T, plus one more person.  

So:  
R’s course: R alone.  
M: 2 people (not S, T, not R).  
Other course: S, T, + 1 more.  

Step 8 – Who is the third with S and T?  
Possibilities: V, Y, or Z.  

But V and Y can’t be together. So if V is with S and T, then Y can’t be there, so Y must be in M.  
If Y is with S and T, then V can’t be there, so V in M.  

Also Y and Z rule: If Y in 3-person course (with S, T), then Z must also be in that course → but that would make 4 people in that course (S, T, Y, Z) impossible (only 3 allowed). So Y cannot be in the 3-person course.  

So Y not in 3-person course.  

Similarly, if Z in 3-person course, then Y must be in same course as Z (Y and Z rule) → so Y in 3-person course → but that’s impossible because Y not in 3-person course (we just saw that leads to 4 people). So Z cannot be in 3-person course either.  

Thus the third person with S and T must be V.  

So: 3-person course = S, T, V.  

Step 9 – Remaining people  
Remaining: Y, Z, R to place.  
R is alone in his course.  
Y and Z left for M? M needs 2 people.  

So M = Y, Z.  
Then R alone in the remaining course.  

Courses:  
R in L alone (say) → M = Y, Z → P = S, T, V.  
Or R in P alone → M = Y, Z → L = S, T, V.  

Step 10 – Check rules  
V and Y not together: In our assignment, V is with S, T; Y is in M with Z → separate, OK.  

Y and Z rule: Y in M (not P), Z in M (not P) → so the trigger condition “Y or Z in P” is false, so no problem.  

M has 2: Y, Z — OK.  

R alone: OK.  

So the only possible assignments are:  
• Case A: L = R alone, M = Y, Z, P = S, T, V.  

• Case B: P = R alone, M = Y, Z, L = S, T, V.  

Step 11 – What must be true?  
From both cases:  
Y is in M.  
Z is in M.  
V is in the 3-person course (L or P) with S, T.  
R is alone in the other course.  

So Y is always in Markets.  

Check options:  
A) Taj in Labor? No, in both cases T is with S, V in the 3-person course (L or P), not necessarily Labor.  
B) Vogel in Labor? Not necessarily; in case B, V in L; in case A, V in P.  
C) Yi in Markets? Yes, in both cases Y in M.  
D) Zane in Markets? Yes actually Z also in M in both cases — but the question says “which one of the following must be true?” Only one can be correct; maybe they want the less obvious one? Let’s check E.  
E) Smith in Pricing? No, in case A, S in P; in case B, S in L. So not necessarily.  

Both C and D seem always true. But if two are always true, the question should have only one correct. Did I make a mistake?  

Wait — are Y and Z both in M in all cases? Yes:  
We deduced 3-person course = S, T, V. Remaining for M: Y, Z. R alone in last course. So indeed Y and Z both in M.  

So C (Yi in Markets) and D (Zane in Markets) are both true. But the answer choices are singular “which one must be true” — in LSAT, only one is correct. Did I err?  

Let’s check Y, Z rule: If Y in M (not P), Z in M (not P) → condition not triggered, so fine.  

But maybe they intend “must be true” and only one is listed that is always true? But here both C and D are always true. That suggests a flaw in my reasoning.  

Where’s the flaw? Step 8: I concluded Y cannot be in 3-person course because that forces Z there too, making 4 people. Correct. Z cannot be in 3-person course because that forces Y there too, making 4 people. Correct. So indeed the third with S, T must be V. So V in 3-person course, Y and Z left for M. So yes, Y and Z both in M.  

So both C and D are true. But the question says “which one must be true” — maybe they want the one that is not also deducible from the other, but since both are true, the intended answer might be the one they list. Looking at options, maybe they expect C. But let’s see official logic game solutions style — sometimes they pick the less obvious.  

Given standard test design, only one option is correct. Did I mis-constrain?  

Check if M could have one of Y, Z and the other in R’s course? No — R is alone, so the other of Y, Z can’t be with R. So Y, Z must be together in M. Yes.  

So indeed C and D are both necessarily true. But if the question has only one answer, maybe they made a mistake, or I misread.  

Given the options, C is “Yi is assigned to Markets” — that is true. D is also true. But if I must choose one they accept, it’s C.  

Wait — maybe I made error: The condition “Yi and Zane must both be assigned to Pricing if either one of them is” — if Y in M, then condition not triggered, so Z can be elsewhere. But in our setup, Z can’t be with R (R alone), can Z be in 3-person course without Y? If Z in 3-person course, then is Y in P? No, Y in M. But then the rule says: if Z in P, then Y in P. But Z not in P here. So no trigger. So maybe Z can be in 3-person course without Y!  

That’s the flaw: I said Z in 3-person course forces Y there — wrong! The rule is only triggered if Z in P (Pricing), not any course. So if Z in 3-person course (L or P? If it’s P, then Y must be in P. If it’s L, then no trigger).  

So my step 8 is wrong: Z can be in 3-person course if that course is not P.  

So let’s restart that step.  

We have: R alone, M 2 people, other course 3 people (S, T, +1).  

Who can be +1? V, Y, or Z.  

If Y is +1 (with S, T in 3-person course), then is that course P? If it’s P, then Z must be in P → makes 4 people (S, T, Y, Z) impossible. So if Y in 3-person course, that course cannot be P. So that course is L. Then M has 2 from {V, Z} plus? Wait, M needs 2 people total, from remaining {V, Z} only 2, so M = V, Z. Then R alone in P.  

Check V and Y: Y in L, V in M — OK. Y and Z rule: Y in L, Z in M — no trigger, OK.  

So possible: L = S, T, Y; M = V, Z; P = R alone.  

So in this scenario, Y not in M. So C is not necessarily true.  

So my earlier “must be true” for C is wrong.  

Similarly, if Z is +1 in 3-person course:  
If that course is P, then Y in P → 4 people impossible. So that course not P, so it’s L. Then 3-person course L = S, T, Z. Remaining {V, Y} in M (since M needs 2). R alone in P.  

Check V and Y: together in M — not allowed! So impossible. So Z cannot be +1 in 3-person course unless the course is P, which is impossible. So Z cannot be the third.  

So third person can be V or Y (we saw Y possible), not Z.  

So possible cases:  
1. Third = V: then M = Y, Z (we saw earlier).  
2. Third = Y: then M = V, Z (we just found).  

What about third = Z? Impossible.  

So in case 1: Y in M, Z in M.  
In case 2: Y in L, Z in M.  

So what must be true?  
Y in M? No — in case 2, Y in L.  
Z in M? Yes — in both cases Z in M.  

So the must-be-true is: Zane is assigned to Markets.  

That’s option D.  

Step 12 – Conclusion  
The only invariant: Z is always in M.  

\[
\boxed{D}
\]

The correct option is: D

context: There are exactly six computers—P, Q, R, S, T, and U—on a small network. Exactly one of those computers was infected by a virus from outside the network, and that virus was then transmitted between computers on the network. Each computer received the virus exactly once. The following pieces of information concerning the spread of the virus have been established: No computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers on the network. S transmitted the virus to exactly one other computer on the network. The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S. Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q. Either T or U transmitted the virus to P.
question: One possible route of the virus from the first computer in the network infected to Q is
options: A) from R to P to T to Q
B) from T to S to R to Q
C) from T to S to U to Q
D) from U to P to R to Q
E) from U to T to P to R to Q
reasoning_cot:
Let’s break this down step by step.  

1. Understanding the constraints  
• 6 computers: P, Q, R, S, T, U.  

• Exactly one was infected from outside (the "source").  

• Virus spread: each computer got it exactly once.  

• Transmission constraints:  

  • No computer transmitted to more than 2 others.  

  • S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer.  

  • The computer that transmitted to R also transmitted to S.  

  • Either R or T transmitted to Q.  

  • Either T or U transmitted to P.  

2. Interpreting the clues  

(a) "The computer that transmitted to R also transmitted to S" means:  
• Let that computer be X. Then X → R and X → S.  

• So R and S got the virus from the same computer.  

(b) S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer. So S is not the source unless source can transmit to 1 or 2 others (source can transmit to 1 or 2; S’s outdegree is exactly 1).  

(c) Either R or T transmitted to Q: Q’s infector is R or T.  

(d) Either T or U transmitted to P: P’s infector is T or U.  

3. Possible source  

The source infected from outside, then spread inside.  
We need to figure possible transmission tree satisfying:  
• Each computer infected exactly once.  

• R and S have same infector.  

• S’s outdegree = 1.  

4. Try clue implications  

If R and S have same parent X, then S’s only transmission is to someone else (not R, since R is a sibling in infection tree).  

Also, Q’s parent is R or T.  
P’s parent is T or U.  

5. Check options  

We are asked: "One possible route of the virus from the first computer in the network infected to Q" — meaning a possible infection path from the source to Q.  

We test each option for consistency with the constraints.  

Option A: R → P → T → Q  
• This path says R infected P, P infected T, T infected Q.  

• But P’s parent must be T or U, not R. So impossible immediately.  

• Eliminate A.  

Option B: T → S → R → Q  
• This path: T infected S, S infected R, R infected Q.  

• Check constraints:  

  • R and S have same parent? No — here S’s parent is T, R’s parent is S. Violates "the computer that transmitted to R also transmitted to S" (they must be same, but here different).  

• Eliminate B.  

Option C: T → S → U → Q  
• Path: T infected S, S infected U, U infected Q.  

• But Q’s infector must be R or T, not U. Violates.  

• Eliminate C.  

Option D: U → P → R → Q  
• Path: U infected P, P infected R, R infected Q.  

• Check:  

  • P’s parent is U (ok, since P’s infector is T or U).  

  • R’s parent is P. S’s parent must be same as R’s parent (P). So P infected both R and S.  

  • S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer: S’s child could be someone else (not R, since R is sibling). That’s possible.  

  • Also, Q’s infector is R (ok, since Q’s infector is R or T).  

  • Possible? We must check if U is source or not. If U infected P, maybe U is source or not. But path from first computer to Q: first computer is source. If source is U, then U→P→R→Q is a possible infection route.  

  • But is U as source possible? We must ensure all 6 computers are infected exactly once. We’d need to fit S and T somewhere. S is child of P (since P infected both R and S). Then S infects 1 computer (maybe T). Then T infects? But P’s infector is U, so P is not source. U could be source. Let’s sketch:  

    ◦ U → P → R and S.  

    ◦ S → T (S’s one transmission).  

    ◦ T → Q and maybe one more? Q is infected by R according to path D, but here T also infects Q? Contradiction: Q’s infector in path D is R, but in my sketch T also infects Q? No, in path D, R infects Q. But in my full graph, T must infect someone (maybe someone else).  

    ◦ Wait, but constraint: Q’s infector is R or T. If R infects Q, that’s fine. Then T could infect someone else (maybe no one if T is last?). But each computer infected exactly once, so T must be infected by someone (S infects T). Then T could infect P? No, P already infected by U. So T could infect e.g., U? But U is source, can’t be infected. So T must infect a computer not yet infected: only Q left? But Q infected by R. So maybe T infects nobody? Then T’s outdegree 0. Possible.  

  • This seems possible:  

    U (source) → P → R → Q, and P → S → T.  
    Check:  
    ◦ R and S have same parent P. ✓  

    ◦ S transmitted to exactly 1 computer (T). ✓  

    ◦ Q’s infector is R. ✓  

    ◦ P’s infector is U (ok, T or U). ✓  

    ◦ All 6 infected exactly once. ✓  

    ◦ No computer transmitted to >2 others: P transmitted to R and S (2), others: U→P (1), R→Q (1), S→T (1), T→0. ✓  

So D is possible.  

Option E: U → T → P → R → Q  
• Path: U→T→P→R→Q.  

• Check: P’s infector is T or U? Here P’s infector is T (ok).  

• But R and S have same parent: R’s parent is P, so S’s parent must be P. So P→S also.  

• Then S’s outdegree=1, so S infects someone else (not R).  

• But in path, after P→R→Q, where is S? S must be infected by P, so S could be infected before/after R, but S’s child? Could be e.g., nobody if S is last? But all must be infected: computers are P,Q,R,S,T,U. In path: U→T→P→R→Q, missing S. So S must be infected by P, so after P, both R and S infected. Then S must infect someone (outdegree 1), only uninfected left is … after P infects R and S, uninfected are Q and maybe none? Wait, at time P is infected: uninfected are Q, R, S? No, R and S get it from P, so after P, uninfected are Q only. So S must infect Q? But Q is infected by R. Contradiction: Q can’t be infected twice. So impossible.  

Thus E fails.  

6. Conclusion  

Only D is consistent.  

The correct option is: D

context: There are exactly six computers—P, Q, R, S, T, and U—on a small network. Exactly one of those computers was infected by a virus from outside the network, and that virus was then transmitted between computers on the network. Each computer received the virus exactly once. The following pieces of information concerning the spread of the virus have been established: No computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers on the network. S transmitted the virus to exactly one other computer on the network. The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S. Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q. Either T or U transmitted the virus to P.
question: Which one of the following could be the computer that was infected from outside the network?
options: A) P
B) Q
C) R
D) S
E) T
reasoning_cot:
Let’s go step by step.  

1. Understanding the constraints  
• 6 computers: P, Q, R, S, T, U.  

• Exactly one was infected from outside (the source).  

• Virus transmitted between computers; each computer received it exactly once.  

• Transmission network: each computer transmits to at most 2 others.  

• S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer.  

• The computer that transmitted to R also transmitted to S.  

  • That means R and S share the same infector.  

• Either R or T transmitted to Q.  

• Either T or U transmitted to P.  

Each computer receives exactly once ⇒ transmission graph is a directed tree (acyclic) with one root (the outside-infected computer).  

2. Interpreting "S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer"  
S has outdegree 1 in the transmission tree.  
S is not a leaf (since it transmitted to 1 other), but it is not a big spreader.  

3. "The computer that transmitted to R also transmitted to S"  
Let X = infector of R and S.  
X transmitted to both R and S.  
X’s outdegree is at least 2 (R and S). Max outdegree is 2 (since "at most 2").  
So X transmitted to exactly R and S.  

Thus:  
X → R  
X → S  

S transmitted to exactly 1 other ⇒ S is not X.  

So X is a node with outdegree 2 (R and S).  

4. Figuring possible X  
Possible X: P, Q, T, U (not R or S, since they are children of X).  

But wait: X could be any of the 6 except R and S? Actually, X could be root or not, but if X is root, fine. If X is not root, it was infected by someone else.  

Also, if X transmitted to R and S, then R and S are not the source (since they have an infector inside network).  

5. Either R or T transmitted to Q  
So Q’s infector is R or T.  

6. Either T or U transmitted to P  
So P’s infector is T or U.  

7. Try to deduce source constraints  
If X transmitted to R and S, then X cannot be R or S (obvious).  
Also, since R and S are not the source (they have an infector), the source is among {P, Q, T, U}.  

Also, S transmitted to exactly 1 other ⇒ S’s child is someone.  

8. Try possible sources  

Case: Source = P  
P infects … must infect enough to cover all 6.  
But P’s infector? Wait, P is source ⇒ P infected from outside ⇒ P’s infector is outside, so inside network P has no infector.  
But constraint "Either T or U transmitted to P" would be violated if P is source (since no one transmitted to P).  
So P cannot be source.  

Case: Source = Q  
Q’s infector? If Q is source, no one infected Q from inside.  
But "Either R or T transmitted to Q" ⇒ impossible (since Q infected from outside, not from R or T).  
So Q cannot be source.  

Case: Source = R  
But R is child of X (X transmitted to R and S).  
So R cannot be source (since source has no infector inside).  
So R not source.  

Case: Source = S  
S is child of X (X transmitted to R and S).  
So S cannot be source.  

Case: Source = T  
T is source ⇒ T infected from outside.  
Now: T or U transmitted to P ⇒ T could be P’s infector (ok).  
Also R or T transmitted to Q ⇒ T could be Q’s infector (ok).  
We need to satisfy X transmitted to R and S, where X is someone else (since T is source, could X be T? Possibly, but then T transmitted to R and S. Then S transmitted to 1 other (ok).  

But check: T → R and T → S. Then S transmitted to 1 other (say S → ?).  
Then T must also infect Q (since R or T transmitted to Q, and if T is source, maybe T infects Q too).  
But T’s outdegree: T → R, S, Q, possibly P. That’s 4 children — violates "at most 2".  
So T cannot be X.  

So X must be someone else (not T). So X transmitted to R and S. Then T is source, so T infected X first?  
Let’s build: T → X → R, S. Then S → (1 other).  

But X’s infector is T (since T is source).  

Then T’s children: X and maybe P (since T or U transmitted to P, so T could be P’s infector) and maybe Q (since R or T transmitted to Q, so T could be Q’s infector).  
That’s T → X, P, Q possibly — 3 children — violates "at most 2".  
So T can’t be source unless outdegree ≤ 2.  

Let’s test: T’s children: X and P (2 children) ok. Then Q’s infector must be R (since R or T transmitted to Q, and T is not Q’s infector here). So R infects Q.  

But R’s infector is X. So R must infect Q after being infected by X. Possible.  

We need to assign all 6:  
Tree: T → X, T → P.  
X → R, X → S.  
S → U (say).  
R → Q.  

Check: T’s outdegree 2 (X, P). X’s outdegree 2 (R, S). S’s outdegree 1 (U). R’s outdegree 1 (Q). U’s outdegree 0. Q’s outdegree 0.  

All received exactly once:  
P from T, Q from R, R from X, S from X, U from S, X from T.  

All constraints:  
• S transmitted to 1 other (U) ok.  

• X transmitted to R and S (ok).  

• R or T transmitted to Q: R transmitted to Q (ok).  

• T or U transmitted to P: T transmitted to P (ok).  

Everything fits.  

So T as source works.  

Case: Source = U  
U transmitted to P (since T or U transmitted to P).  
Also U is source, so U infects others.  
But U must infect T if T is to infect Q or be infector of P? Wait, T or U transmitted to P: U could do it.  
R or T transmitted to Q: so if U is source, maybe T infects Q, so U infects T.  

But X transmitted to R and S: X is someone else.  

We’d need to check if we can build tree with U root, outdegree ≤ 2, etc. Likely possible, but let’s check if T works already.  

Given T works, and U might also work, but the question asks “Which one could be the computer infected from outside?” — meaning at least one option works.  

We found T works.  

We should check if U works quickly:  

U → T, U → P (2 children).  
T → Q (since R or T transmitted to Q).  
We need X who transmitted to R and S: X could be T? Then T → R, T → S, but T already has infector U, and T’s outdegree would be Q, R, S = 3 — too many. So X cannot be T.  

X could be U? Then U → R, U → S, but U already transmits to T and P (too many). So X not U.  

X could be P? Then P → R, P → S, but P’s infector is U. Then S transmits to 1 other — possible. But then who infects X? Wait X is P here, so P is not root. Then all nodes infected: U root → T, P; T → Q; P → R, S; S → (one other) — but 6 computers: P, Q, R, S, T, U all assigned? We have U infects T and P; T infects Q; P infects R and S; S infects … but all 6 already infected: U, T, P, Q, R, S — no room for S to infect another (since only 6 computers). So S outdegree 0 — contradicts “S transmitted to exactly 1 other”. So impossible.  

So U as source fails because can’t satisfy S has outdegree 1.  

Thus only T works.  

9. Conclusion  
The only possible source is T.  

The correct option is: E

context: There are exactly six computers—P, Q, R, S, T, and U—on a small network. Exactly one of those computers was infected by a virus from outside the network, and that virus was then transmitted between computers on the network. Each computer received the virus exactly once. The following pieces of information concerning the spread of the virus have been established: No computer transmitted the virus to more than two other computers on the network. S transmitted the virus to exactly one other computer on the network. The computer that transmitted the virus to R also transmitted it to S. Either R or T transmitted the virus to Q. Either T or U transmitted the virus to P.
question: If T did not transmit the virus to any other computer on the network, which one of the following must be true?
options: A) P transmitted the virus to S.
B) Q transmitted the virus to R.
C) U transmitted the virus to S.
D) P did not transmit the virus to any other computer on the network.
E) R did not transmit the virus to any other computer on the network.
reasoning_cot:
Let’s reason through this step by step.  

Step 1 – Understanding the setup  
• 6 computers: P, Q, R, S, T, U.  

• Exactly one computer got the virus from outside (the "source").  

• The virus spread: each computer got it exactly once.  

• Transmission constraints:  

  1. No computer transmitted to more than 2 others.  
  2. S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer.  
  3. The computer that transmitted to R also transmitted to S.  
  4. Either R or T transmitted to Q.  
  5. Either T or U transmitted to P.  
• Extra condition for this question: T did not transmit to any other computer.  

Step 2 – Implications of T not transmitting  
If T did not transmit to any computer, then T cannot be the one who gave the virus to Q (from condition 4: R or T gave to Q ⇒ now only R possible).  
So: R transmitted to Q.  

Also, from condition 5: T or U transmitted to P ⇒ since T did not transmit, U transmitted to P.  

Step 3 – Condition 3: same computer transmitted to R and S  
Let’s call that computer X.  
X transmitted to R and S.  
X could be P, Q, T, or U (but not R or S themselves).  

Also, S transmitted to exactly 1 other computer. So S is not the source unless the source transmitted to 2 others (but S transmitted to only 1). Step 5 – Build transmission tree constraints

• R transmitted to Q (from Step 2).

If X = P: then P transmitted to R and S. But U transmitted to P. So P got it from U, then P gave to R and S. That’s fine: P transmitted to 2 others.  

If X = Q: then Q transmitted to R and S. But R transmitted to Q (from Step 2). That’s a cycle: Q→R and R→Q impossible because each computer gets virus exactly once. Contradiction: R gave to Q means R infected before Q got it, but Q gave to R means Q infected before R got it — impossible. So X ≠ Q.

Check other options:  
• B) Q transmitted to R — false, P transmitted to R.  

• C) U transmitted to S — false, P transmitted to S.  

• D) P did not transmit to any other computer — false, P transmitted to 2 computers.  

• E) R did not transmit to any other computer — false, R transmitted to Q.

The correct option is: A

(4) Either R or T infected Q. So Q’s infector is R or T.  

(5) Either T or U infected P. So P’s infector is T or U.

We have a directed tree (each gets virus exactly once) rooted at the external source, with all edges representing infections, each node has indegree 1 except source has indegree 0.

This is a known LSAT logic game. The key is:  
The common infector of R and S (M) has outdegree 2 (R and S). S has outdegree 1.

Having revisited this LSAT question, the completely determined condition occurs when U transmitted the virus to P.
